Provision.Text: His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Natural Resources, pursuant to section 5a of the Explosives Actb, makes the annexed Explosives Regulations, 2013.

Section.Text: This Part sets out the scheme and application of these Regulations and exempts some explosives from provisions of the Explosives Act. It also defines certain terms that are used in the Regulations, including “explosives”. Finally, it explains the function of the notes and asterisks that are used in the Regulations.
Section.Note: Note: Section 29 of the Explosives Act states that “Nothing in the Act relieves any person . . . of the obligation to comply with the requirements of any Act of Parliament relating to explosives or components of explosives or the requirements of any licence law, or other law or by-law of any province or municipality, lawfully enacted in relation to explosives, especially requirements in relation to the acquisition, possession, storage, handling, sale, transportation or delivery of explosives or components of explosives. . . .”

Section.Text: The notes that appear beneath some provisions do not form part of these Regulations but are included for convenience only.
When a term that is defined in section 6 is used in these Regulations, an asterisk appears in front of the term the first time that it is used in a section.

Subsection.Text: These Regulations are divided into 20 Parts. Some Parts apply to all *explosives and some apply only to specific types of explosive. The final Part applies to restricted components.

Subsection.MarginalNote: General requirements, prohibitions and safety precautions
Subsection.Text: Part 2 sets out the general requirements, prohibitions and safety precautions that apply to every person who is carrying out an *activity involving an explosive or is in the vicinity of an explosive.

Part 3 indicates how to obtain an authorization of an explosive, how an authorized explosive is classified, how to obtain permission to change an authorized explosive, when an authorization may be cancelled and when an authorized explosive must be recalled.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Importing and exporting explosives and transporting explosives in transit
Subsection.Text: Part 4 indicates how to obtain a permit to import or export explosives or to transport them in transit and sets out the requirements for carrying out those activities.

Part 5 indicates how to obtain a factory licence or manufacturing certificate and sets out the circumstances in which explosives may be *manufactured without a licence or certificate. It also sets out the requirements for manufacturing explosives.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Magazine licences and storage in licensed magazine
Subsection.Text: Part 6 indicates how to obtain a magazine licence and sets out the requirements for storing explosives in a licensed magazine.

Part 7 sets out the terms and conditions that apply to all holders of licences, permits and certificates, indicates how to obtain an amendment or renewal and sets out the circumstances in which a licence, permit or certificate may be suspended or cancelled.
Part 8 sets out the screening and supervision requirements that apply to people who have, or could have, access to high risk explosives.
Part 9 sets out the requirements for transporting explosives, including transporting them in transit.
Parts 10 to 15 set out the requirements for the acquisition, storage and sale of the following types of explosives:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: military explosives and law enforcement explosives – Part 10;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: *industrial explosives – Part 11;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: blank cartridges for tools – Part 12;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: special purpose explosives – Part 13;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: small arms cartridges, propellant powder and percussion caps – Part 14; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: model and high power rocket motors – Part 15.

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: Part 14 also authorizes, and sets out requirements for, the manufacture of small arms cartridges and black powder cartouches.

Subsection.Text: Parts 16 to 18 set out the requirements for the acquisition, storage, sale and use of the following types of fireworks:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: consumer fireworks – Part 16;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: *special effect pyrotechnics – Part 17; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: display fireworks, including firecrackers – Part 18.

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: Parts 17 and 18 also indicate how to obtain a fireworks operator certificate.

Subsection.Text: Part 19 sets out the fees to be paid for obtaining an authorization, permit, licence or certificate.
Part 20 restricts the sale and acquisition of certain components of explosives and sets out requirements for their sale and storage.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: These Regulations apply to all *explosives except the following, to which only Part 5 applies:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: safety and strike-anywhere matches;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: life-saving devices (for example, signals, flares and parachute release devices) that are being carried in an aircraft, train, vessel or vehicle as equipment that is necessary for its safe operation or for the safety of its occupants;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: automotive explosives (for example, pyrotechnic seat belt pretensioners and modules containing pyrotechnic inflators), whether or not in their original packaging, that the competent authority of their country of origin has classified as Class 9 under the Model Regulations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, published by the United Nations;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: explosives diluted to less than 1% by weight, including diluted explosives used as reagents (for example, 1H-tetrazole), training kits for sniffer dogs and kits to test the functioning of machines that detect trace levels of explosives; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: Christmas crackers containing less than 2 mg of *explosive substance.

Subsection.Text: Paragraphs 6(b) to (d) and subsections 9(2) and (3) of the Explosives Act do not apply to the explosives set out in subsection (1).
Paragraph 6(e) and section 20 of the Explosives Act do not apply to the explosives set out in paragraphs (1)(a), (b), (d) and (e).

Section 21 of the Explosives Act applies to the explosives set out in subsection (1) only in respect of the activities referred to in paragraph 6(a) of that Act, and to the explosives set out in paragraph 1(c) only in respect of the activities referred to in paragraph 6(e) of that Act.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Explosives under control of allied armed forces
Subsection.Text: Explosives that are under the control of any armed forces that are cooperating with the Canadian Forces are deemed to be under the direction or control of the Minister of National Defence.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 2 of the Explosives Act and these Regulations, explosive includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an *explosive substance or *explosive article that is not *manufactured or used to produce an explosion, detonation or pyrotechnic effect but is included in Class 1 of Schedule 1 to the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any substance numbered UN 1442, AMMONIUM PERCHLORATE as set out in columns 1 and 2 of Schedule 1 to the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a multi-ingredient kit that is used to manufacture an explosive.
Paragraph.Note: Note: The term explosive is defined in section 2 of the Explosives Act as “any thing that is made, manufactured or used to produce an explosion or a detonation or pyrotechnic effect, and includes any thing prescribed to be an explosive by the regulations, but does not include gases, organic peroxides or any thing prescribed not to be an explosive by the regulations”.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 2 of the Explosives Act, military device means a shell, bomb, projectile, mine, missile, rocket, shaped charge, grenade, perforator and any other explosive article that is manufactured exclusively for military or law enforcement purposes.
The following definitions apply in these Regulations.

Definition.Text: activity involving an explosive means acquiring, possessing, selling, offering for sale, storing, *manufacturing, transporting, transporting in transit, importing, exporting or delivering an *explosive or using fireworks. (activité visant un explosif)
attended means to be constantly monitored by a person and, unless these Regulations provide otherwise, includes monitoring by a person using electronic means. (surveillé)
compatible means, in relation to a material, that the material

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: will not react chemically with an *explosive or raw material so as to affect the functioning of the explosive or raw material or to increase the likelihood of an ignition of the explosive or raw material; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: will not be degraded by an explosive or raw material so as to affect its function or increase the likelihood of an ignition of the explosive or raw material. (compatible)

Definition.Text: decontaminate means to completely remove, clean or purge an *explosive substance from a building, room, area, vehicle, equipment or container. (décontamination)
explosive article means an article that contains one or more *explosive substances. (objet explosif)

explosive substance means a solid or liquid substance — or a mixture of solid and liquid substances — that is capable, by chemical reaction, of producing a gas at a temperature, pressure and speed that is capable of causing damage to surrounding structures or infrastructure. It includes a substance — or a mixture of substances — that is designed to produce an effect of heat, light, sound, gas or smoke, or a combination of such effects, by means of a non-detonative self-sustaining exothermic chemical reaction, even if the substance or mixture does not produce a gas. (matière explosive)
industrial explosive has the same meaning as in section 213. (explosif industriel)

local authority means, in relation to *special effect pyrotechnics or display fireworks, the municipal, provincial or territorial organization or office that has authority to authorize their use in a locality. (autorité locale)
manufacturing has the same meaning as in section 53. (fabriquer)
product name means the trade name or part number of an explosive, or both in the case of an explosive that has both a trade name and a part number. (nom de produit)
pyrotechnic event has the same meaning as in section 361. (activité pyrotechnique)
small arms cartridge has the same meaning as in subsection 268(1). (cartouches pour armes de petit calibre)
special effect pyrotechnics has the same meaning as in section 361. (pièces pyrotechnique à effets spéciaux)

storage unit means a building, structure, place or container in which *explosives are stored and that is not licensed. However, it does not include a dwelling or any structure, place or container in a dwelling. (unité de stockage)
vendor magazine licence has the same meaning as in section 144. (licence de poudrière (vendeur))
vulnerable place refers to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any building in which people live, work or assemble;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: public roads, railways and other transportation infrastructure;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: pipelines and energy transmission lines; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any place where a substance that increases the likelihood of a fire or explosion is likely to be stored. (lieu vulnérable)

Subsection.Text: The definition manufacturing in subsection (3) does not apply in Part 20.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: Nothing in these Regulations has the effect of preventing an inspector from carrying out their duties under the Explosives Act.

Any document, other than a document referred to in subsection 173(3) or (4) or 183(3) or section 426 or subsection 498(1), and any information that is required by these Regulations to be in writing, may be delivered in hard copy or by electronic means.

Heading.Label: PART 2
Heading.TitleText: General Requirements, Prohibitions and Safety Precautions

Section.Text: This Part sets out requirements, prohibitions and safety precautions that apply to every person who is carrying out an *activity involving an explosive or who is in the vicinity of *explosives.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A person must be at least 18 years old to carry out an *activity involving an explosive. However, this requirement does not apply to a person who acquires *small arms cartridges for their own personal use. It also does not apply when these Regulations provide for an exception.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A person may carry out an *activity involving an explosive only if the *explosive is authorized under Part 3.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The following *explosives are, in the opinion of the Minister, intrinsically unsafe and must not be acquired, possessed, used or sold:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: trick fireworks (for example, cigarette loads, dancing crackers and exploding golf balls); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: explosives containing chemicals that are not *compatible with one another.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A person must not sell or otherwise transfer an *explosive to another person if they have reasonable grounds to suspect that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the other person is not authorized by the Explosives Act or these Regulations to acquire the explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the explosive will be used for a criminal purpose; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the other person is under the influence of alcohol or another performance-diminishing substance.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A person must not acquire an *explosive that the Chief Inspector of Explosives has authorized with restrictions unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the authorization is restricted to specified people or bodies or classes of people or bodies, they are a person or body or member of a class of people or bodies specified in the authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the authorization is restricted to specified purposes, they intend to use the explosive for a purpose specified in the authorization; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the authorization is restricted to specified people or bodies or classes of people or bodies and to specified purposes, they are a person or body or member of a class of people or bodies specified in the authorization and intend to use the explosive for a purpose specified in the authorization.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A person must not carry out an *activity involving an explosive if they are under the influence of alcohol or another performance-diminishing substance. A person who has taken a prescription drug may carry out such an activity if they have medical proof that they need the drug and that it will not impede their ability to safely carry out the activity.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A person must not smoke while they are carrying out *an activity involving an explosive or if they are within 8 m of an *explosive.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A person must not alter, deface or obscure any printing or label on an *explosive or its packaging unless they are ordered to do so by an inspector to correct an error.
However, after removing an explosive from its packaging, a person may alter the printing or label on the packaging to reflect the remaining quantity.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A person must not include in a document required by these Regulations any information that is false or misleading. A person must not submit a document that, by reason of non-disclosure of facts, is false or misleading.

A person who is carrying out an *activity involving an explosive must ensure that they, and any person under their supervision, have knowledge of the activity being carried out and of the measures that must be taken to minimize any likelihood of harm to people and property that could result from the activity, including measures to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prevent an accidental ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: limit the spread of any fire or the extent of any explosion; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: protect people from the effects of any fire or explosion.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A person who is carrying out an *activity involving an explosive must take measures that minimize the likelihood of harm to people or property that could result from the activity, including measures to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prevent an accidental ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: limit the spread of any fire or the extent of any explosion; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: protect people from the effects of any fire or explosion.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A person who is in control of an *explosive must ensure that only people authorized by them or by law have access to the explosive.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A person may use fireworks only for the purpose for which they were designed.

This Part sets out *activities involving an explosive that may be carried out even if the *explosive is not authorized. It also sets out the procedure for obtaining authorization of an explosive and when permission is required to change an explosive that has been authorized. It deals as well with the classification and reclassification of explosives, their recall and the cancellation of an authorization.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The duties and functions of the Chief Inspector of Explosives that are set out in sections 32 to 40 may be performed by an inspector designated by the Chief Inspector.
Despite section 11, the following *activities involving an explosive may be carried out even though the *explosives are not authorized:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacture of up to 1 kg of explosives to be used in conducting an experiment, demonstration, test or analysis at a school, college, university or other learning institution;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacture of up to 5 kg of explosives to be used in conducting an experiment, demonstration, test or analysis by a government or law enforcement agency;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacture of up to 5 kg of explosives to be used in conducting an experiment, test or analysis at a private or commercial laboratory;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacture of black powder charges for ceremonial use;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacture of *small arms cartridges or black powder cartouches for personal use;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the assembly and use of special purpose pyrotechnics, as defined in section 361;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the sending of a sample of an explosive to the Chief Inspector of Explosives, at his or her request, for authorization testing;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the importation of an explosive, if the conditions set out in section 45 are met;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the exportation of an explosive, if the conditions set out in section 45 are met; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the transportation in transit of an explosive.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: An *explosive may be authorized for an indefinite period or for a specified period.
An authorization for an indefinite period is issued if the explosive is intended to be used in ongoing or recurring activities. The authorization may be issued with restrictions.

An authorization for a specified period is issued if the explosive is intended to be used for a specific purpose within a specified period (for example, a chemical analysis, a product trial, scientific research or a tour or international competition involving fireworks).

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The following people may apply to have an *explosive authorized:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a person who proposes to manufacture the explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a foreign manufacturer of the explosive; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a person who has permission to apply from a manufacturer of the explosive.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: An applicant for an authorization for an indefinite period must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address of the applicant and of the manufacturer if the applicant is not the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a short description of the explosive and its properties, as well as its *product name;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the circumstances in which it will be used;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for an *explosive article, a technical drawing of the article, prepared to scale, that sets out its dimensions, its components and the materials of its construction;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the composition of the explosive and the percent tolerance or range of each of its ingredients;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the composition of any substitute explosive and the percent tolerance or range of each of its ingredients;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the results of any tests conducted by or on behalf of a foreign state that has authorized the explosive or a similar explosive, or the classification of the explosive by a foreign state;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the anticipated classification of the explosive under section 36;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an explosive to be *manufactured in Canada for the first time, a description of the manufacturing operations that will be used;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: for an explosive article, a description of its performance characteristics, the way in which it functions and the instructions for its use;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any packaging or container in which the explosive will be handled, used, stored or displayed for sale;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the packaging or container in which the explosive will be transported and stored, and the safety standards to which the packaging or container must conform under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the information that will be printed on the explosive and its packaging;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the safety instructions, in both English and French, that will accompany the explosive, including procedures for preventing accidents when handling, storing, using or destroying the explosive and the procedures to follow if the explosive is lost or stolen; and

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: the period after the manufacture of the explosive during which it will remain suitable for use in the circumstances described in paragraph (c).

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: An applicant for an authorization for a specified period, if the explosive is for use other than at a tour or international competition involving fireworks, must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address of the applicant and of the manufacturer if the applicant is not the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the period for which the authorization is requested;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a short description of the explosive and its properties, as well as its *product name;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the circumstances in which it will be used;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of the explosive that will be used during the period;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: every location where it will be used;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a product trial, the location where the explosive will be manufactured;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: for an *explosive article, a technical drawing of the article prepared to scale that includes its dimensions, its components and the materials of its construction;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the composition of the explosive and the percent tolerance or range of each of its ingredients;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the composition of any substitute explosive and the percent tolerance or range of each of its ingredients;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: for an explosive article, a description of its performance characteristics, the way in which it functions and instructions for its use;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any packaging or container in which the explosive will be handled, used or displayed for sale;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the packaging or container in which the explosive will be transported and stored and the safety standards with which the packaging or container must comply under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the safety instructions, in both English and French, that will accompany the explosive, including procedures for preventing accidents when handling, storing, using or destroying the explosive and the procedures to follow if the explosive is lost or stolen;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: the delivery system, if the explosive is to be transported in bulk; and

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: the method to be used to destroy any of the explosive that is not used before the authorization expires.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.MarginalNote: Application for specified period — tour or competition
Section.Text: An applicant for an authorization for a specified period, if the explosive is for use at a tour or international competition involving fireworks, must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address of the applicant and of the manufacturer if the applicant is not the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a short description of the *explosive and its properties, as well as its *product name;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the transport classification issued by the country of origin;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the places and dates of the tour or international competition at which the explosive will be used;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the controls that will be put in place to ensure that the explosive is used only for the tour or international competition for which it is authorized;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the precautions that will be taken to minimize the likelihood of harm to people and property; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the method to be used to destroy any of the explosive that is not used.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The applicant for an authorization must pay the applicable fees set out in Part 19.

Subsection.Text: The Chief Inspector of Explosives must authorize the use of an *explosive for an indefinite period if the Chief Inspector determines, on the basis of the results of one or more of the following tests, that the explosive can be safely *manufactured, handled, stored, transported, used and destroyed:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a test listed in the table to this Part that is conducted on the explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a test listed in the table to this Part that is conducted on a similar explosive; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a test that was conducted on this or a similar explosive by or on behalf of a foreign state that has authorized the explosive or similar explosive and that is equivalent to a test listed in the table to this Part.

Subsection.Text: The authorization must be given with restrictions if the Chief Inspector determines, based on the type, hazard classification, UN number and the circumstances in which the explosive will be used, that it can safely be used only by a specific person, body or class of people or bodies, or for a specific purpose.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The Chief Inspector of Explosives must authorize an *explosive for a specified period if the Chief Inspector determines, on the basis of the information in the application and the results of any sample testing, that the explosive can be safely *manufactured, handled, stored, transported, used and destroyed.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: If a sample of an *explosive is required for a test listed in the table to this Part, the Chief Inspector of Explosives must notify the applicant, specify the quantity of the explosive required and indicate the address to which the sample may be sent.
A person must not send a sample of an explosive for testing unless they have been requested to do so by the Chief Inspector.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The Chief Inspector of Explosives must give the applicant written notice of whether the *explosive has been authorized.
If the explosive has not been authorized, the notice must include the reasons for the refusal to authorize.
If the explosive has been authorized, the notice must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the classification of the explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an authorization for an indefinite period, any restrictions respecting the people or bodies or classes of people or bodies that may use the explosive and any restrictions respecting the purposes for which it may be used;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an authorization for a specified period, the period for which the explosive is authorized, the quantity authorized, the place of *manufacture and the place of use; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the explosive was authorized.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The Chief Inspector of Explosives must classify each authorized *explosive by type, hazard category and UN number in accordance with this section.
Each authorized explosive is classified according to its intended use as one of the following types:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: E — high explosives:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: E.1 — blasting explosives,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: E.2 — perforating explosives,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: E.3 — special-application explosives;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: I — initiation systems;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: P — propellant powder:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: P.1 — black powder and hazard category PE 1 black powder substitutes,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: P.2 — smokeless powder and hazard category PE 3 black powder substitutes;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: C — cartridges:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: C.1 — *small arms cartridges,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: C.2 — blank cartridges for tools,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: C.3 — percussion caps;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: D — military explosives and law enforcement explosives;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: F — fireworks:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: F.1 — consumer fireworks,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: F.2 — display fireworks,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: F.3 — special effect pyrotechnics,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: F.4 — fireworks accessories;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: R — rocket motors:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: R.1 — model rocket motors,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: R.2 — high-power rocket motors,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: R.3 — rocket motor accessories; or

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: S — special purpose explosives:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: S.1 — low-hazard special purpose explosives,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: S.2 — high-hazard special purpose explosives.

Subsection.Text: Each authorized explosive is also classified for the purposes of *manufacturing and storage into one or more of the following potential effects (PE) categories, if applicable. The classification is made according to hazard, determined on the basis of manufacturing operations, the quantity of explosive and how the explosive will be packaged:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: PE 1 — mass explosion hazard;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: PE 2 — serious projection hazard but not a mass explosion hazard;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: PE 3 — fire hazard and either a minor blast or minor projection hazard, or both, but not a mass explosion hazard; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: PE 4 — fire hazard or slight explosion hazard, or both, with only local effect.

Subsection.Text: Each authorized explosive is assigned a UN number as set out in column 1 of Schedule 1 to the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations on the basis of its type, hazard category and the circumstances in which it will be used.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A person who has obtained the authorization of an *explosive must obtain the written permission of the Chief Inspector of Explosives before changing the explosive in a way that would render any of the following information inaccurate:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an authorization for an indefinite period, any information required under paragraphs 28(d) to (f) or (l) to (n); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an authorization for a specified period, any information required under paragraphs 29(h) to (j), (m) or (n).

Subsection.Text: The Chief Inspector of Explosives must give permission if the proposed change would not affect the performance or classification of the explosive. The Chief Inspector must notify the holder in writing when permission is given.
If permission is refused, the Chief Inspector must notify the holder in writing that permission is refused and that a new application for authorization is required.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The Chief Inspector of Explosives must reclassify an authorized *explosive if periodic testing or new information reveals that its classification is no longer appropriate.
The Chief Inspector must give the person who obtained the authorization written notice of the explosive’s new classification.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The Chief Inspector of Explosives must cancel the authorization of an *explosive in any of the following circumstances:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person who obtained the authorization has not paid the applicable fee within 30 days after the date of an invoice from the Department of Natural Resources;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: periodic testing or new information reveals that the explosive can no longer be safely *manufactured, handled, stored, transported, used or destroyed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Chief Inspector is unable to determine whether the explosive can still be safely manufactured, handled, stored, transported, used or destroyed;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person who obtained the authorization requests the cancellation; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacturer is no longer in business and the Chief Inspector has reasonable grounds to believe that the explosive is no longer in any person’s possession.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: If the authorization of an *explosive is cancelled because the explosive is no longer safe when *manufactured, handled, stored, transported, used or destroyed in the normal way, the Chief Inspector of Explosives must, by written notice, require any manufacturer, any importer and any seller of the explosive to recall any of the explosive that they have manufactured, imported or sold.

If a batch or lot of explosives cannot be safely handled, stored, transported, used or destroyed because of a manufacturing defect, the Chief Inspector of Explosives must, by written notice, require the manufacturer or importer and any seller of the batch or lot to recall it.

A person who receives a notice to recall an explosive must immediately recall the explosive and either make it safe or destroy it in a manner that will not increase the likelihood of an accidental ignition during or after the destruction.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The Minister must keep an up-to-date list of all *explosives that are authorized for an indefinite period. The list must set out the following information for each explosive:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person who obtained the authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name and classification of the explosive; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any restrictions imposed by the Chief Inspector of Explosives.

Subsection.Text: However, the Minister is not required to include on the list an explosive that is classified as a military explosive or law enforcement explosive.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The Minister must remove from the list of authorized explosives any *explosive for which the authorization is cancelled.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Provision.Text: Tests for physical properties — including consistency, reaction rate, rate of moisture-absorption, tendency for separation, exudation, behaviour at both high and low temperatures, density and specific gravity
Tests for chemical composition — including the determination of the percentage of each ingredient in the explosive

Tests for stability — including the determination of the stability of the explosive by subjecting it to varying environmental conditions, such as high temperatures, that might produce spontaneous ignition of the explosive or a variation of its sensitivity
Tests for ignition behaviour
Tests to determine the potential for mass explosion in a fire
Tests to determine whether ignition of an explosive article might ignite other explosive articles when stored or transported together
Tests for mechanical sensitivity — including sensitivity to friction and impact
Tests for sensitivity to electrostatic discharge
Tests for sympathetic initiation and detonation
Tests for velocity of detonation
Tests for explosive strength
Tests for or calculation of the composition of gases that evolve on explosion
Performance tests
Tests for minimum burning pressure
Packaging tests
Any other tests that are necessary for the purpose of authorizing an explosive

Heading.Label: PART 4
Heading.TitleText: Importing and Exporting Explosives and Transporting Explosives in Transit

Section.Text: This Part sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the circumstances in which *explosives may be imported, exported or transported in transit without a permit;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the information that a person must include in an application for a permit to import or export explosives or transport them in transit; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the requirements that permit holders must meet, including the information that permit holders must provide to the Chief Inspector of Explosives after explosives are imported, exported or transported in transit.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: annual permit means a permit for multiple importations, exportations or transportations in transit during a one-year period. (permis annuel)
secure storage site means a site at which the Minister or a province has authorized storage of the type and quantity of explosive that is to be transported in transit. (lieu de stockage sûr)
single use permit means a permit for a single importation, exportation or transportation in transit. (permis à utilisation unique)

Subsection.Text: A reference to the mass of an *explosive in this Part is a reference to its net quantity (the mass of the explosive excluding the mass of any packaging or container and, in the case of an *explosive article, also excluding any component that is not an *explosive substance).

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.MarginalNote: Import, export or transport in transit
Section.Text: A person may import, export or transport in transit an *explosive set out in the table to this section without a permit if the following conditions are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the explosive is imported, exported or transported in transit for personal use and not for commercial purposes;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the explosive enters or leaves Canada with the person importing or exporting it or, if the explosive is transported in transit, it remains with the person transporting it at all times; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of *small arms cartridges, the cartridges do not include a tracer, incendiary or similar military component or device; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of the explosive being imported, exported or transported in transit is not more than the quantity set out in the table.

row.entry: Model rocket motors that have a maximum total impulse of 80 newton-seconds (NFPA alpha designations A to E, as indicated on the motor or its packaging)
Percussion caps (primers) for small arms cartridges
Empty primed small arms cartridge cases
Black powder and hazard category PE 1 black powder substitutes
8 kg, in containers of 500 g or less
Smokeless powder and hazard category PE 3 black powder substitutes
8 kg, in containers of 4 kg or less

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for an import permit must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must state whether a single use permit or an annual permit is requested and include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the applicant has a customs broker, the broker’s name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address and the name of a contact person;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name and UN number of each *explosive to be imported;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of each explosive to be imported or, if the application is for an annual permit, the estimated quantity of each explosive to be imported during the year;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the purpose for which each explosive is imported (personal, industrial or commercial use, reloading, field trial or other testing, sale, consignment, *pyrotechnic event, fireworks display or other purpose);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person who obtained the authorization of each explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the country of origin of each explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the Canadian port of entry through which each explosive will pass;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the address of the person to whom each explosive will be delivered and the location where it will be stored;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an explosive to be stored in a licensed factory or a licensed magazine, the number and expiry date of the factory or magazine licence and, for each explosive that will be stored there, the quantity of that explosive authorized by the licence to be stored;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an explosive to be stored in a magazine owned by a person other than the applicant, proof that the other person has agreed to have the explosive stored in their magazine; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the application.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for an import permit must pay the applicable fees set out in Part 19.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.TitleText: Requirements To Be Met by Import Permit Holder

Subsection.Text: A holder of an import permit must ensure that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of each *explosive to be imported must not exceed the quantity of the explosive that the holder is authorized by a factory licence, a magazine licence or these Regulations to store; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the packaging in which each explosive is imported must conform to the description of the packaging set out in the explosive’s authorization.

Subsection.Text: A holder of an import permit must ensure that the following information is displayed on each explosive to be imported:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the person who obtained the explosive’s authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: either the date of its *manufacture and the shift during which it was manufactured, if any, or its lot number;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: its *product name; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: instructions, in both English and French, for its safe handling, storage, use and destruction.

Subsection.Text: A holder of an import permit must ensure that the information

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is legibly printed on the explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is legibly printed on a label affixed to the explosive, if it is not possible to comply with paragraph (a);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is contained in a barcode or matrix code that is printed on the explosive, or on a label affixed to it, and can be read by a device that is available to the general public (for example, a smartphone), if it is not possible to comply with paragraph (a) and (b); or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: is legibly printed on the packaging containing the explosive or on a label affixed to the packaging, if it is not possible to comply with paragraphs (a) to (c).

Subsection.Text: Paragraph 2(d) does not apply in the case of fireworks that are imported for use at a tour or international competition if the instructions are printed in a language understood by the person who will use the fireworks.
A holder of an import permit must ensure that the following information is legibly printed on the packaging, or on a label affixed to the packaging, of each explosive to be imported:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the words “Ammunition/Munitions”, “Explosives/Explosifs”, “Fireworks/Pièces pyrotechniques”, “Pyrotechnics/Pièces pyrotechniques” or “Rocket Motors/Moteurs de fusée”, as the case may be, on the outer packaging and any inner packaging;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name of the explosive and the name and address of the person who obtained its authorization, on the outer packaging;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a type F explosive, whether it is type F.1, F.2, F.3 or F.4, on the outer packaging; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a type S explosive, whether it is type S.1 or S.2, on the outer packaging.

Subsection.Text: A holder of an import permit must ensure that the information to be printed on an explosive and its packaging is printed on them before the explosive is distributed and in any case no later than 15 days after the date on which the explosive is released under section 31 of the Customs Act.

A holder of an import permit must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives a report using the form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The report must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the holder’s name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the holder’s permit number and its expiry date;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name and UN number of each explosive that was imported and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity and UN number of each type of explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the country of origin of each explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the means of transport used;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the Canadian port of entry through which each explosive passed; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the report and the name of the person who completed the report.

Subsection.Text: A holder of an annual permit must submit the report before the permit is renewed or, if the permit is not renewed, within a year after it expires. The report must be submitted even if no explosives were imported during the year for which the permit was valid.
A holder of a single use permit must submit the report within 30 days after the date on which the explosives were imported.
Subsections (7) to (9) do not apply to a holder that reports the importation of explosives by electronic means in accordance with section 4 of the Reporting of Imported Goods Regulations.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: An applicant for an export permit must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must state whether a single use permit or an annual permit is requested and include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the applicant has a freight forwarder, their name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address and the name of a contact person;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name and UN number of each *explosive to be exported;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of each explosive to be exported or, if the application is for an annual permit, the estimated quantity of each explosive to be exported during the year;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person who obtained the authorization of each explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the country of origin of each explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the Canadian port of exit through which each explosive will pass;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address of the person to whom each explosive will be delivered;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of a permit, or other proof, establishing that each explosive may lawfully enter the country of destination;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of a permit, or other proof, establishing that each explosive may lawfully transit any country through which it will be transported if the country requires permission for the in transit transportation of the explosive; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the application.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.TitleText: Requirements To Be Met by Export Permit Holder

Subsection.Text: A holder of an export permit must ensure that the following information is legibly printed on the packaging, or on a label affixed to the packaging, of each *explosive to be exported:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the words “Ammunition/Munitions”, “Explosives/Explosifs”, “Fireworks/Pièces pyrotechniques”, “Pyrotechnics/Pièces pyrotechniques” or “Rocket Motors/Moteurs de fusée”, as the case may be, on the outer packaging and any inner packaging;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name of the explosive and the name and address of the person who obtained its authorization, on the outer packaging;

Subsection.Text: A holder of an export permit must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives a report using the form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The report must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the holder’s name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the holder’s permit number and its expiry date;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name and UN number of each explosive that was exported and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity and UN number of each type of explosive that was exported;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the country of origin of each explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the means of transport used;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the Canadian port of exit through which each explosive passed; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the report and the name of the person who completed the report.

Subsection.Text: A holder of an annual permit must submit the report before the permit is renewed or, if the permit is not renewed, within a year after it expires. The report must be submitted even if no explosives were exported during the year for which the permit was valid.
A holder of a single use permit must submit the report within 30 days after the date on which the explosives were exported.
Subsections (2) to (4) do not apply to a holder that reports the importation of explosives by electronic means in accordance with section 4 of the Reporting of Imported Goods Regulations.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: An applicant for an in transit permit must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must state whether a single use permit or an annual permit is requested and include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the applicant has a freight forwarder, their address, telephone number, fax number and email address and the name of a contact person;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name and UN number of each *explosive to be transported in transit;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if an explosive to be transported is not on the list of authorized explosives referred to in subsection 41(1), the name or *product name of the explosive, a description of the explosive and its UN number;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of each explosive to be transported or, if the application is for an annual permit, the estimated quantity of each explosive to be transported during the year;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the manufacturer of each explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the country of origin of each explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the anticipated dates of entry into and departure from Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the Canadian port of entry and port of exit through which each explosive will pass;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the location in Canada of secure storage sites that may be used if the transportation is interrupted and, if any of the sites is a licensed factory or a licensed magazine, the number and expiry date of the factory or magazine licence and, for each explosive that might be stored there, the quantity of that explosive that is authorized by the licence to be stored;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: if any of the secure storage sites is a magazine that is owned by a person other than the applicant, proof that the other person has agreed to have the explosive stored in their magazine if an interruption in transportation occurs;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address of the person to whom each explosive will be delivered;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of a permit, or other proof, establishing that each explosive may lawfully enter the country of destination;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of a permit, or other proof, establishing that each explosive may lawfully transit any country through which it will be transported if the country requires permission for the in transit transportation of the explosive; and

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the application.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.TitleText: Requirements To Be Met by In Transit Permit Holder

Subsection.Text: A holder of an in transit permit must ensure that the following information is legibly printed on the packaging, or on a label affixed to the packaging, of each *explosive to be transported in transit:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name or *product name of the explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the UN number of the explosive; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity to be transported.

Subsection.Text: If anything interrupts an in transit transportation of explosives, the holder of the in transit permit must ensure that the explosives are stored in a secure storage site and are *attended.

A holder of an in transit permit must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives a report using the form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The report must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the permit holder’s name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the holder’s permit number and its expiry date;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name or *product name, the UN number and a description of each explosive that was transported in transit; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity and UN number of each type of explosive that was transported in transit;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the country of origin of each explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the means of transport used;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the Canadian port of entry and port of exit through which each explosive passed; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the report and the name of the person who completed the report.

Subsection.Text: A holder of an annual permit must submit the report before the permit is renewed or, if the permit is not renewed, within a year after it expires. The report must be submitted even if no explosives were transported in transit during the year for which the permit was valid.
A holder of a single use permit must submit the report within 30 days after the date on which the explosives entered Canada.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: This Part sets out the rules for manufacturing *explosives. However, it does not apply to the manufacture of *small arms cartridges or black powder cartouches for personal use or to repackaging under a vendor magazine licence.

Division 1 (sections 55 to 105) sets out how to obtain a division 1 factory licence or a satellite site certificate, as well as the requirements for holders of the licence or certificate and for workers at, and visitors to, the factory or satellite site.

Division 2 (sections 106 to 132) sets out how to obtain a division 2 factory licence or a manufacturing certificate, as well as the requirements for holders of the licence or certificate and for workers at, and visitors to, the workplace.

Division 3 (sections 133 to 142) sets out the manufacturing activities that do not require a factory licence or manufacturing certificate and the requirements for people who carry out those activities.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: In this Part, manufacturing includes the following activities:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: making or manufacturing an *explosive substance from raw material or from another explosive substance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: making or manufacturing an *explosive article, including the assembly of an article from explosive and non-explosive components;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: altering or remaking an explosive substance or explosive article by modifying its chemical composition (for example, by gassing or blending) or by subjecting it to physical processes with the input of energy (for example, pneumatic handling, pumping, shearing or thickening);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: dividing an *explosive into its components or unmaking, breaking up or in any manner destroying it;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: packaging explosives; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: testing an unauthorized explosive or testing an explosive to assess its potential for a use other than its authorized use.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A reference to the mass of an *explosive in this Part is a reference to its net quantity (the mass of the explosive excluding the mass of any packaging or container and, in the case of an *explosive article, also excluding any component that is not an *explosive substance).

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 1
Heading.TitleText: Manufacturing Explosives under a Division 1 Factory Licence or a Satellite Site Certificate

Section.Text: The following definitions relating to sites and authorizations apply in this Division.

Definition.Text: client site means a blast site at which a mobile process unit is used to manufacture *explosives away from a factory or satellite site.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: licence de fabrique de la section 1

Definition.Text: division 1 factory licence means a licence that is issued under paragraph 7(1)(a) of the Explosives Act and authorizes the manufacture of explosives at a factory.
satellite site means a site that is located away from a factory and at which explosives that are intended for use at a client site are manufactured and temporarily stored.

satellite site certificate means a manufacturing certificate that is issued to the holder of a division 1 factory licence under paragraph 7(1)(c) of the Explosives Act and authorizes the manufacture of explosives at a satellite site.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The following definitions relating to facilities and equipment at factories, satellite sites or client sites apply in this Division.

Definition.Text: factory magazine means a magazine that is located at a factory or satellite site.
mobile process unit means a vehicle or portable machine that is used at a factory, satellite site or client site to carry out an explosives manufacturing operation.
process unit means a building, structure, room or place in which an explosives manufacturing operation is carried out at a factory.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: installation de stockage de matières premières

Definition.Text: raw material storage facility means a facility where non-explosive raw material and packaging material are stored at a factory or satellite site.

transport unit means a vehicle or container in which *explosives or raw material are conveyed from one place to another at a factory or satellite site without using a public road. It includes a tow motor, forklift, wagon, handcart and basket, but does not include a conveyor or pipeline.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The following definitions relating to people at factories, satellite sites or client sites apply in this Division.

Definition.Text: competent person means a person who has been certified as trained in accordance with section 83.

worker means a person who is at a factory or satellite site to carry out a manufacturing operation or some other kind of work (for example, maintenance of facilities or repair of equipment) for the holder of a division 1 factory licence.

Subsection.Text: A holder of a division 1 factory licence may manufacture *explosives if the holder complies with this section.
Each explosive to be manufactured must be specified in the division 1 factory licence or a satellite site certificate.
Explosives must be manufactured at one of the following locations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the factory specified in the division 1 factory licence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a satellite site specified in a satellite site certificate; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a client site specified in the licence or a certificate.

Subsection.Text: A manufacturing operation may be carried out in a process unit or factory magazine, and maintenance and other work may be done to a process unit, factory magazine, raw material storage facility or transport unit, only if the manufacturing operation, maintenance or other work is specified in the division 1 factory licence or a satellite site certificate. However, the minor servicing authorized by these Regulations does not have to be specified in the licence or certificate.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.MarginalNote: Acquisition, storage and sale of explosives

Subsection.Text: A holder of a division 1 factory licence may acquire and store *explosives and may sell explosives without a vendor magazine licence.

A holder who acquires or sells explosives must comply with Parts 10 to 18. However, they are not required to comply with the provisions of those Parts that apply to the storage of explosives if the explosives are stored at the factory or a satellite site.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for a division 1 factory licence or a satellite site certificate must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must state whether a licence or a certificate is requested and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address of both the applicant and a contact person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: each type of *explosive to be manufactured;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the application is for a satellite site certificate, the number of the applicant’s division 1 factory licence and the dates on which the operations at the satellite site will begin and end;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the address of the factory or satellite site; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address of a contact person at the factory or satellite site.

Subsection.Text: The application must include the following documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a factory site and area plan or a satellite site and area plan that shows

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the topography of the site,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the location of every process unit, factory magazine and raw material storage facility, and every building or structure that contains such a unit, magazine or facility,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the location of any other building or structure, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the distance in metres between each process unit, factory magazine, raw material storage facility, building and structure;

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the area surrounding the site that is exposed to the hazards (for example, debris or blast effect) that could result from an ignition of the explosives to be manufactured or stored at the site,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: each *vulnerable place within that area, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the distance in metres between each vulnerable place and each process unit, factory magazine and raw material storage facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: layout sketches, diagrams or drawings that show

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the workplace areas, storage areas and emergency exits of every process unit, factory magazine, raw material storage facility and every building or structure that contains such a unit, magazine or facility,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the equipment to be used in each process unit, including piping and instrumentation diagrams and equipment layout drawings, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the manufacturing operations to be carried out, including process flow sheets or process schematic drawings.

Subsection.Text: The application must include the following information about the factory or satellite site:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its geographical coordinates;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the size of, and construction materials used for, each building at the site and all lighting, heating, ventilation and air conditioning systems, electrical installations, grounding and measures for protection from fire and lightning;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of all site and building security features (for example, fencing, barriers and warning signs);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the principal manufacturing equipment to be used and its safety features;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of each mobile process unit to be used;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any other mobile equipment, including transport units, to be used and how the equipment will be powered; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any safety features at the site to be put in place to minimize the likelihood of harm to people or property (for example, diking, sumps, blowout panels, means of blast containment, barriers, alarms or pressure relief and control systems).

Subsection.Text: If the manufacture of explosives is to be carried out at a client site, the application must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address of a contact person at the client site;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the client site;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the distance in kilometres between the factory and the client site; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the distance in kilometres between any satellite site and the client site.

Subsection.Text: The application must include a description that sets out,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for each explosive to be manufactured at the factory, a satellite site or a client site,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: its *product name and its UN proper shipping name,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the date on which the explosive was authorized or its authorization file number,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: its UN number, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: its hazard category; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for each explosive to be stored at the factory or a satellite site,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: its UN proper shipping name,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: its UN number, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: its hazard category.

Subsection.Text: The application must include the following information about manufacturing operations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the operations to be carried out in each process unit and factory magazine;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the explosives, and of any other thing that is flammable, that is liable to spontaneously combust or that is otherwise dangerous, that will be stored in each process unit, factory magazine, raw material storage facility, building and structure;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the results of a quantified risk assessment or hazard operability review of any manufacturing operation to be used to manufacture an explosive if that operation has not previously been used in Canada to manufacture that explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum quantity of explosives and raw material that will be in each process unit, factory magazine, raw material storage facility, building and structure at any one time;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum number of people who will be in each process unit, factory magazine, raw material storage facility, building and structure at any one time; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the minimum distance in metres that must be maintained between each process unit, factory magazine and raw material storage facility and each vulnerable place shown on the area plan, as set out in the National Standard of Canada Standard CAN/BNQ 2910–510/2015 entitled Explosives — Quantity Distances as amended from time to time.

Subsection.Text: If type E, I or D explosives are to be manufactured or stored, the application must include a security plan that includes the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an assessment of the security risks resulting from the presence of the explosives at the factory, satellite site or client site;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the measures that will be taken to minimize those risks;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the procedures that will be followed to respond to security incidents; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the procedures that will be followed to report security incidents.

Subsection.Text: The application must include a list of the following documents, along with the dates on which they were made and the dates of any amendments:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any environmental assessment of the factory, satellite site or client site or of the operations to be carried out there;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the documents that set out the rules, procedures and protocols designed to ensure compliance with the Explosives Act, these Regulations and the licence, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: operating procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: maintenance procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: training manuals,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: emergency response plans, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: spill contingency plans;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if manufacturing operations are to be carried out in a quarry, a letter of understanding signed by the quarry operator that sets out the safety measures that will be taken at the quarry;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if activities that could increase the likelihood of an ignition (for example, welding) are to be carried out, a document that sets out the rules governing those activities; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if explosives are to be destroyed, a document that sets out the method of destruction to be used.

Subsection.Text: Every process unit, factory magazine, raw material storage facility, building and structure that is shown on the site plan and every vulnerable place that is shown on the area plan must be identified by a number, letter or distinctive name, which must be used to identify the unit, magazine, building or structure in every drawing, sketch or description included in the application.
Every drawing, sketch or plan must be drawn to scale, or be a reasonable approximation of actual distances and dimensions, and must include a legend.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: An applicant for a division 1 factory licence or a satellite site certificate must pay the applicable fees set out in Part 19.

Heading.Label: SUBDIVISION c
Heading.TitleText: Requirements for Holders of Division 1 Factory Licences
Facilities at Factories and Satellite Sites

Section.Text: A holder of a division 1 factory licence must ensure that the requirements relating to process units, factory magazines, raw material storage facilities and transport units set out in sections 63 to 68 are met at the factory and, if they also hold a satellite site certificate, at each satellite site.

Subsection.Text: Every process unit, factory magazine and raw material storage facility must be located at an acceptable distance from surrounding structures and infrastructure and from places where people are likely to be present.
