Acceptable distance is determined by the Minister on the basis of risk of harm to people or property, taking into account the quantity and type of *explosives that are to be manufactured, the raw material to be used, the manufacturing operations to be carried out, the strength, proximity and use of surrounding structures and infrastructure and the number of people likely to be in the vicinity of the unit, magazine or facility.

Every process unit, factory magazine and transport unit must be designed, constructed and installed to conform to good engineering practices. It must be constructed in a manner that prevents the accumulation of explosives or raw material in cracks and cavities and that minimizes the harm to people and property that could result from an ignition of the explosives or raw material. The construction materials must be *compatible with the explosives to be manufactured, stored or transported and with the raw material to be used.
Every factory magazine must also be constructed so that it is well ventilated and resistant to theft, weather and fire.

Every raw material storage facility must be designed, constructed and installed to conform to good engineering practices. The construction materials must be compatible with the raw material to be stored in the facility.

Every process unit, factory magazine, raw material storage facility and transport unit must have a means of escape that will permit all people in the unit, magazine or facility to leave it quickly and easily in an emergency.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Lighting, electrical fixtures and wiring systems
Subsection.Text: The lighting, electrical fixtures and wiring systems that are used in a process unit, factory magazine, raw material storage facility or transport unit must not increase the likelihood of an accidental ignition.

Precautions that eliminate any possibility of an accidental ignition of electrostatic sensitive material (for example, grounding and control of humidity) must be taken in every process unit, factory magazine, raw material storage facility and transport unit.

Every process unit or building in which a process unit is located must be protected from lightning strikes if it would not be safe to shut down manufacturing operations in the process unit during a thunderstorm.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: All tools, accessories and equipment that are in a process unit, factory magazine, raw material storage facility or transport unit must be designed, constructed and installed to conform to good engineering practices.

Every thing that is in a process unit, factory magazine, raw material storage facility or transport unit must be made from materials that are *compatible with the *explosives and raw material in the unit, magazine or facility.

However, a thing that is not compatible with an explosive or raw material in a process unit, factory magazine or raw material storage facility but is required for manufacturing or maintenance (such as a cleaning fluid or solvent) may be brought into the unit, magazine or facility for immediate use. It must be removed as soon as the circumstances permit after its use unless the division 1 factory licence or satellite site certificate authorizes its storage in the unit, magazine or facility.

All equipment designed to control safety-critical parameters on pumps, and on other process equipment that puts energy into explosives, must be installed and maintained in good condition so that the equipment operates while the pumps and process equipment are in use.
A motorized transport unit that contains explosives must be equipped with two easily accessible fire extinguishers, each with a rating of at least 4-A :40-B:C.

An open-flame device, an open-element electrical appliance or a device (for example, a heat sealer) with a surface temperature above the decomposition temperature of the explosives or raw material with which it may come in contact must not be stored in a process unit unless the division 1 factory licence or satellite site certificate authorizes one to be stored in the unit.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: All raw material, *explosive substances and *explosives waste must be kept in closed containers that prevent spills and contamination. The contents of each container must be clearly identified on a label attached to the container.
Any spill of explosives, raw material or other material must be cleaned up as soon as the circumstances permit so as to eliminate any possibility of an ignition.

If the likelihood of an ignition could be increased as a result of foreign matter (for example, bolts, gravel or grit) being present in or mixed with any raw material, or explosive used as raw material, the material must be carefully examined and passed through a sieve or treated to remove or exclude the foreign matter before manufacturing operations begin.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Removal of explosives from process unit
Subsection.Text: All explosives and raw material must be removed from a process unit as soon as the circumstances permit after manufacturing operations are completed, unless the division 1 factory licence or satellite site certificate authorizes storage of the explosives or raw material in the unit.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Removal of explosives from transport unit
Subsection.Text: All explosives and raw material must be removed from a transport unit as soon as the circumstances permit after their transport is completed. A transport unit that contains explosives must be *attended in person. However, it may be left unattended during a thunderstorm.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Destruction of waste and contaminated material
Subsection.Text: All explosives waste and explosives-contaminated material must be destroyed in a manner that does not increase the likelihood of an accidental ignition during or after the destruction.

Any building or equipment that is no longer being used to manufacture explosives must be *decontaminated as soon as the circumstances permit. The building or equipment must be inspected by a supervisor to verify that it no longer contains any explosives.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A record must be made for each period during which a process unit operates. The record must be kept for two years after the date on which it is made and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for each unit,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the dates on which the period of its operation began and ended,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a short description of the *explosives, and the properties of the explosives, manufactured during the period,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the quantity of explosives manufactured, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the maintenance of and repairs to the unit, the dates on which the work was carried out and the name of the worker who did the work; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for any equipment in the unit whose malfunction could increase the likelihood of an ignition,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the dates on which the period of its operation began and ended,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the manufacturing operations for which the equipment was used, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the maintenance of and repairs to the equipment, the dates on which the work was carried out and the name of the person who did the work.

Subsection.Text: A record must be made for each *decontamination of equipment that was used in a process unit. The record must describe the contamination and the means of decontamination and include the names of the workers who carried out the decontamination and the name of the supervisor who inspected the equipment after the decontamination. The record must be kept for two years after the date on which the equipment is disposed of.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: On the approach of and during a thunderstorm, the following procedures must be followed:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all manufacturing operations in a process unit that can be safely shut down must be shut down;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all entrances to any factory magazine containing *explosives must be closed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any transport unit containing explosives must be immediately moved to an isolated safe place; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all people at the factory or satellite site must be immediately moved to a safe place and, until the storm passes, must not be permitted to return.

Subsection.Text: However, any manufacturing operation in a process unit that could, if stopped, increase the likelihood of harm to people or property may be carried on during a thunderstorm until the operation can be safely shut down.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: Every process unit, factory magazine and transport unit and all equipment that is used to manufacture *explosives must be maintained in good operating condition.

Minor servicing of a process unit, factory magazine or transport unit, or of equipment that is used to manufacture explosives, may be done while the unit, magazine or equipment is in use if the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the servicing is routine and is integral to the use of the unit, magazine or equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the servicing is done by a competent person.

Subsection.Text: All other maintenance or repair work that is done at the factory or a satellite site in or to a process unit, factory magazine, transport unit or equipment that is used to manufacture explosives must be done by a competent person who has been issued a work permit by the licence holder.

A work permit must set out the procedures to be followed during the maintenance or repair work and the measures that must be taken before, during and after the work to eliminate any possibility of an ignition.

If any transport unit or equipment at the factory or a satellite site is contaminated, it must be *decontaminated at the factory before it is taken outside the factory for maintenance, repair or disposal.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Work done outside factory or satellite site
Subsection.Text: If maintenance or repair work is done outside the factory or a satellite site on manufacturing equipment whose malfunction could increase the likelihood of an ignition (for example, pumps or safety trips), it must be done by a competent person.

A logbook of all maintenance and repair work done in or to every process unit, factory magazine and transport unit, and to any manufacturing equipment whose malfunction could increase the likelihood of an ignition, must be kept for two years after the date on which the last entry is made. The work permits for this maintenance and repair work must also be kept for two years after the date on which the work is completed.

For each progressive cavity pump, a separate logbook that sets out the operating history of the pump and the maintenance and repair work done to it must be kept at the factory for the life of the pump.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A holder of a division 1 factory licence must ensure that the signage requirements set out in sections 70 to 72 are met at the factory and, if they also hold a satellite site certificate, at each satellite site.

A sign that warns against unauthorized entry must be posted at each entrance to a factory or satellite site in a clearly visible location. The sign must also warn of danger from *explosives and indicate the precautions that must be taken to eliminate the possibility of an accidental ignition.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.MarginalNote: Exterior signs — process units and factory magazines

Subsection.Text: On the outside of each process unit and factory magazine, a sign that sets out either the number, letter or distinctive name specified in the division 1 factory licence or satellite site certificate for that unit or magazine or the activities for which the unit or magazine is used, must be posted at each entrance in a clearly visible location.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Interior signs — process units and factory magazines
Subsection.Text: On the inside of each process unit and factory magazine, a sign that sets out the following information must be posted at the main entrance in a clearly visible location:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of each type of *explosive and the quantity of raw material that are authorized to be in the unit or magazine at any one time;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of people who are authorized to be in the unit or magazine at any one time; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any other conditions or restrictions specified in the licence or certificate that apply to the unit or magazine.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.MarginalNote: Interior signs — raw material storage facilities
Section.Text: On the inside of each raw material storage facility, a sign that sets out the raw material, and the properties of the raw material, that is authorized to be stored in the facility, and the quantity of raw material that is authorized to be stored at any one time, must be posted at the main entrance in a clearly visible location. The sign must also indicate the precautions that must be taken to eliminate the possibility of an ignition of the raw materials.

A holder of a division 1 factory licence must ensure that the labelling requirements set out in section 74 are met at the factory and, if they also hold a satellite site certificate, at each satellite site.

Subsection.Text: The following information must be displayed on each *explosive that is manufactured at the factory or satellite site:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the person who obtained the explosive’s authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: either the date of its *manufacture and the shift during which it was manufactured, if any, or its lot number;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: its *product name; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: instructions, in both English and French, for its safe handling, storage, use and destruction.

Subsection.Text: The information must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: legibly printed on the explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: legibly printed on a label affixed to the explosive, if it is not possible to comply with paragraph (a);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: contained in a barcode or matrix code that is printed on the explosive, or on a label affixed to it, and can be read by a device that is available to the general public (for example, a smartphone), if it is not possible to comply with paragraphs (a) and (b); or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: legibly printed on the packaging containing the explosive or on a label affixed to the packaging, if it is not possible to comply with paragraphs (a) to (c).

Subsection.Text: The following information must be legibly printed on the packaging, or on a label affixed to the packaging, of the explosive:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the words “Ammunition/Munitions”, “Explosives/Explosifs”, “Fireworks/Pièces pyrotechniques”, “Pyrotechnics/Pièces pyrotechniques” or “Rocket Motors/Moteurs de fusée”, as the case may be, on the outer packaging and any inner packaging;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name of the explosive and the name and address of the person who obtained its authorization, on the outer packaging;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a type F explosive, whether it is type F.1, F.2, F.3 or F.4, on the outer packaging; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a type S explosive, whether it is type S.1 or S.2, on the outer packaging.

Subsection.Text: The manufacturer’s division 1 factory licence number must be printed in a legible and permanent manner on the outer packaging of every industrial explosive.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A holder of a division 1 factory licence must ensure that the worker and visitor safety requirements set out in sections 76 to 79 are met at the factory and, if they also hold a satellite site certificate, at each satellite site.

Subsection.Text: Only people authorized by the holder of a division 1 factory licence may have access to the factory or a satellite site.

A visitor may be authorized to enter the factory or a satellite site only if they have attended an orientation session on visitor safety within the 12 months before the date on which they enter. If any of the safety procedures have changed since their last orientation session, they must attend a new session before their entry is authorized.
A visitor may be authorized to enter any part of the factory or a satellite site if they are at least 17 years old and remain under the supervision of a competent person.

Up-to-date lists of the personal protective equipment, clothing and devices that are needed to protect workers and visitors from the hazards to which they could be exposed while at the factory or a satellite site must be maintained and must be made available to all workers and visitors.
Every worker and visitor must be required to wear the personal protective equipment, clothing and devices that are needed to protect them.

Every worker and visitor must be required to confine or cover any loose hair and confine, cover or remove any loose clothing, jewellery or other accessories if the hair, clothing or accessories could increase the likelihood of an ignition or the likelihood of harm to the worker or visitor.

Every worker and visitor must be required to deactivate any electronic device in their possession (for example, a cellphone or two-way radio) in any part of the factory or a satellite site where the device, if activated, could increase the likelihood of an ignition.

Section.Text: A worker or visitor must not be authorized to enter the factory or a satellite site if there are reasonable grounds to believe that they are under the influence of or carrying alcohol or another performance-diminishing substance. However, a worker or visitor who has taken a prescription drug may be permitted to enter if they have medical proof that the drug is needed and that it will not impede their ability to carry out their functions or to visit safely.

Subsection.Text: Smoking must be prohibited at the factory and any satellite site.

Fire-producing devices (for example, matches and lighters) must not be permitted in the factory or any satellite site unless they are authorized by the division 1 factory licence or satellite site certificate.

Section.Text: A holder of a division 1 factory licence must ensure that the training requirements for workers set out in sections 81 to 84 are met at the factory and, if they also hold a satellite site certificate, at each satellite site.
Every employee at a factory or satellite site must be required to meet the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they must be a competent person; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: they must be at least 17 years old, participating in the training program referred to in section 82 and under the direct supervision of a competent person.

Subsection.Text: Every employee must be trained to carry out their duties at the factory or a satellite site in a safe and lawful manner. The training must be given by a competent person.

The training must include all information necessary to ensure the security of the factory or satellite site and the safety of the employee, other people at the factory or site and the general public. It must also include a review of the Explosives Act, these Regulations and the division 1 factory licence or satellite site certificate.
A holder of a division 1 factory licence must certify as trained any employee who is at least 18 years old if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the employee has completed the training referred to in section 82; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the holder has reasonable grounds to believe that the employee understands the hazards to which they could be exposed at the factory or satellite site and is competent to carry out their duties in a manner that is safe, lawful and ensures the security of the site.

Subsection.Text: Evidence of an employee’s certification may be either a training record or a document signed by the person who provided the training or, in the case provided for in paragraph (1)(b), by the holder of the division 1 factory licence. It must be given to the employee and record the employee’s name, the operating procedures the employee is competent to carry out and the date on which the certification will expire.

An employee’s training certification must expire not more than five years after the date of the certification. If a change occurs in the operating procedures for which the employee was certified, the employee must be trained in the new operating procedures but the expiry date of the certification must remain the same.

A training record and a record of work experience must be made and kept up to date for each employee at the factory or satellite site where they perform their duties. These records must be kept for two years after the date on which the employee’s certification expires.

Section.Text: Every worker at a factory or satellite site who is not an employee must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be trained to carry out their work in a manner that is safe and lawful and ensures the security of the factory or satellite site; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: remain under the supervision of a competent person while at the factory or satellite site.

Heading.TitleText: Operation of the Factory or Satellite Site

Section.Text: A holder of a division 1 factory licence must ensure that the operational requirements set out in sections 86 to 91 are met at the factory and, if they also hold a satellite site certificate, at each satellite site.

Subsection.Text: Operating procedures, including procedures to minimize the likelihood of an accidental ignition, must be put in place for every manufacturing operation.

The operating procedures must be kept up to date and reviewed annually. If a manufacturing operation is to be changed, the procedures for carrying out that operation must be reviewed and modified as needed before the change is implemented.

Before any temporary or permanent technological or organizational change to manufacturing operations is implemented, an evaluation of the risk that the change could increase the likelihood of an ignition or a security incident must be carried out and a management of change procedure must be put in place for each change that could increase the likelihood of an ignition or a security incident.
Each change must be approved by the holder of the division 1 factory licence before it is made.
A record of each change must be kept for two years after the date on which the change is made.

If a security plan was included in the application for a division 1 factory licence or a satellite site certificate, it must be implemented and a copy of the plan must be kept at the factory or satellite site.

The security plan must be updated to reflect any change in circumstances that could adversely affect the security of the factory or satellite site. A copy of the updated plan must be kept at the factory and satellite site and another copy must be sent to the Chief Inspector of Explosives as soon as the circumstances permit.
A copy of the most recent version of the plan must be made available to the people who are responsible for implementing it.
All operating procedures must be routinely audited. Every audit must include the following verifications:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether facilities and equipment are being operated and maintained in a manner that ensures the security of the factory or satellite site and minimizes the likelihood of harm to people and property; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether these Regulations and the terms and conditions of the division 1 factory licence and any satellite site certificate are being complied with.

Subsection.Text: Any deficiency found during an audit must be corrected as soon as the circumstances permit.

A record of each audit must be made and the record must include a copy of the action plan to correct any deficiencies found and set out the corrections made. It must be kept for two years after the date on which the audit is conducted.
A procedure must be put in place to ensure that the audits are conducted in a complete and timely manner.

A record of each *explosive in the factory or at a satellite site (including any explosive that is used as raw material) must be kept for two years after the date on which the record is made. It must set out, for each explosive,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name and a short description of the explosive and its properties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive was received, the quantity received and the date of reception;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive was used to manufacture another explosive, the quantity used and the date of use;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive was manufactured at the factory or a satellite site, the quantity manufactured and the date of manufacture;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive was stored, the quantity stored, the magazine in which it was stored and the dates on which it was placed in and removed from the magazine;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive was shipped from the factory or a satellite site, the quantity shipped, the date of shipment and the name and address of the person to whom it was shipped; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive was destroyed at the factory, the quantity destroyed and the date of destruction.

Subsection.Text: Any system used for inventory control or tracking of an explosive must not increase the likelihood of an ignition.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A copy of the division 1 factory licence and all documents referred to in the licence must be kept at the factory. A copy of the satellite site certificate and all documents referred to in the certificate must be kept at each satellite site.
A copy of this Division must be made available to workers at the factory and each satellite site.
A copy of the operating procedures for each process unit, factory magazine and transport unit must be kept in the unit or magazine to which they relate and must be made available to the workers.

Section.Text: A holder of a division 1 factory licence must ensure that the mobile process unit requirements set out in sections 93 to 100 are met at the factory and, if they also hold a satellite site certificate, at each satellite site.

Subsection.Text: Every mobile process unit must be designed and constructed to conform to good engineering practices. It must be constructed in a manner that prevents the accumulation of *explosives or raw material in cracks and cavities and that minimizes the harm to people and property that could result from an ignition of the explosives or raw material. The construction materials must be *compatible with the explosives to be manufactured and transported and with the raw material to be used.
Every mobile process unit must have a means of escape that will permit all people in the unit to leave it quickly and easily in an emergency.
All tools, equipment, hoses and hydraulic systems in or on a mobile process unit must be designed, constructed and installed to conform to good engineering practices.

Every thing that is in or on a mobile process unit must be made from materials that are compatible with the explosives and raw material with which they could come into contact during manufacturing operations.

All equipment designed to control safety-critical parameters on pumps, and on other process equipment that puts energy into explosives, must be installed and maintained in good condition so that the equipment operates while the pumps and process equipment are in use.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: If the likelihood of an ignition could be increased as a result of foreign matter (for example, bolts, gravel or grit) being present in or mixed with any raw material, or *explosive used as raw material, the material must be carefully examined and passed through a sieve or treated to remove or exclude the foreign matter before manufacturing operations begin.

Explosives and raw material must not be loaded into or unloaded from a mobile process unit except at the factory or a satellite site or at a client site specified in the division 1 factory licence or satellite site certificate. However, in the case of a mechanical breakdown, unloading may be carried out at the location of the breakdown if the Minister is notified of the breakdown and determines that precautions that minimize the likelihood of ignition have been taken.
A mobile process unit that contains explosives must be *attended in person except when it is at the factory or a satellite site.
A mobile process unit that has not been *decontaminated must be kept at the location specified in the licence or certificate.

The explosives and raw material in the tanks and hoppers on a mobile process unit must be unloaded if the unit will not be used for three consecutive days. However, the fuel oil tank and prill hopper do not have to be unloaded.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A mobile process unit must be cleaned if it will not be used, or has not been used, for 30 consecutive days.
A mobile process unit must be decontaminated before it is removed from service.

All decontamination of a mobile process unit must be carried out at the factory specified in the division 1 factory licence. After decontamination, a unit must be inspected by a supervisor to verify that it no longer contains any *explosives.
All explosives waste and explosives-contaminated material must be destroyed in a manner that does not increase the likelihood of an accidental ignition during or after the destruction.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: Operating procedures, including procedures to minimize the likelihood of an ignition, must be put in place for every manufacturing operation to be carried out in a mobile process unit.
A copy of the operating procedures for each mobile process unit must be kept in the unit and must be made available to workers.
A record must be made for each period during which a mobile process unit operates. The record must be kept for two years after the date on which it is made and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the dates on which the period of its operation began and ended;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a short description of the *explosives manufactured during the period and of their properties;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of explosives manufactured; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the maintenance of and repairs to the unit, the dates on which the work was carried out and the name of the person who did the work.

Subsection.Text: A record must be made for each *decontamination of equipment that is used in a mobile process unit. The record must describe the contamination and the means of decontamination and include the names of the workers who carried out the decontamination and the name of the supervisor who inspected the equipment after the decontamination. The record must be kept for two years after the date on which the equipment is disposed of.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: Every mobile process unit must be maintained in good operating condition.
Minor servicing of a mobile process unit may be done while it is in use if the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the servicing is routine and integral to the use of the unit; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the servicing is done by a competent person.

Subsection.Text: All other maintenance or repair work, if it is done at the factory, must be carried out by a competent person who has been issued a work permit by the licence holder.

A work permit must set out the procedures to be followed during the maintenance or repair work and the measures that must be taken before, during and after the work to eliminate any possibility of an ignition.
A mobile process unit must be *decontaminated at the factory before it is taken outside the factory for maintenance or repair.

If maintenance or repair work is done outside the factory on manufacturing equipment that is in or on a mobile process unit and whose malfunction could increase the likelihood of an ignition (for example, pumps or safety trips), it must be done by a competent person.

In the case of a mechanical breakdown of a vehicle used as a mobile process unit, repairs to the vehicle may be done at the location of the breakdown only if doing the repair work will not increase the likelihood of an ignition and the work is done by a competent person.
If doing the repair work could increase the likelihood of ignition, the unit must be towed to the factory for repair.

A logbook of all maintenance and repair work done to a mobile process unit, or to any manufacturing equipment in or on the unit whose malfunction could increase the likelihood of an ignition, must be kept for two years after the date on which the last entry is made. The work permits for the maintenance and repair work must also be kept for two years after the date on which the work is completed. The logbook and permits must be kept at the factory.

For each progressive cavity pump, a separate logbook that sets out the operating history of the pump and the maintenance and repair work done to it must be kept at the factory for the life of the pump.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A mobile process unit may be used to *manufacture *explosives at a client site, but only if the unit and the site are both specified in the division 1 factory licence or satellite site certificate.
All manufacturing operations at a client site must be carried out by a competent person.

Before manufacturing operations begin, every one at the client site must be informed of the precautions that must be taken while dewatering, driving over loaded boreholes, handling charging hose and carrying out charging operations.
Any thing or activity that could increase the likelihood of an accidental ignition must not be allowed within 15 m of a mobile process unit and its charging hose.

A person must not be permitted to be within 15 m of a mobile process unit and its charging hose while the unit is operating if there are reasonable grounds to believe that the person is under the influence of or is carrying alcohol or another performance-diminishing substance. A person who has taken a prescription drug may be permitted to enter the area if they have medical proof that the drug is needed and will not impede their ability to function safely.
A person must not be permitted to smoke within 15 m of a mobile process unit and its charging hose.

On the approach of a thunderstorm, if a mobile process unit is at the surface at a client site, all manufacturing operations in the unit must be shut down and all people in the vicinity of the unit must be immediately moved to a safe place. Until the storm passes, the operations must remain shut down and the people must not be permitted to return to the vicinity of the unit.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.MarginalNote: Packaging at satellite or client site

Subsection.Text: Blasting explosives in bulk that are manufactured in a mobile process unit may be packaged at a satellite or client site, but only if the explosives

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have been removed to prepare the unit for cleaning or *decontamination;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are to be used as samples for laboratory analysis;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have been used to calibrate the process equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: are to be used to charge boreholes that the unit cannot access during its operations at a client site; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: are to be used to charge boreholes that present unforeseen conditions rendering their use unsafe if they are left unpackaged.

Subsection.Text: The packaging must prevent the explosives from leaking or spilling and minimize the likelihood of an accidental ignition.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.Label: SUBDIVISION d
Heading.TitleText: Requirements for Workers, Visitors and Other People

Subsection.Text: Before entering a factory or satellite site, every worker who is not an employee and every visitor must obtain the authorization of the holder of the division 1 factory licence. A visitor must be at least 17 years old.
While at a factory or satellite site, a visitor must remain under the supervision of a competent person.

A worker or visitor who is under the influence of or is carrying alcohol or another performance-diminishing substance must not enter a factory or satellite site. However, a worker or visitor who has taken a prescription drug may enter if they have medical proof that they need the drug and that it will not impede their ability to carry out their functions or to visit safely.

Every worker and visitor at a factory or satellite site must wear the personal protective equipment, clothing and devices that are needed to protect them from the hazards to which they could be exposed.

Every worker and visitor must confine or cover any loose hair and confine, cover or remove any loose clothing, jewelry or other accessories if the hair, clothing or accessories could increase the likelihood of an ignition or the likelihood of harm to the worker or visitor.

Every worker and visitor must deactivate any electronic device in their possession (for example, a cellphone or two-way radio) in any part of a factory or satellite site where the device, if activated, could increase the likelihood of an ignition.
Every worker and visitor at a factory or satellite site must take the precautions that they are directed to take to minimize the likelihood of an accidental ignition.
Workers and visitors must not smoke at a factory or satellite site.

Section.Text: A worker at a factory or satellite site may carry out a task only if they

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have been trained in that task and understand the hazards to which they could be exposed; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are at least 17 years old, participating in a training program and under the direct supervision of a competent person.

Subsection.Text: A person at a client site must not be within 15 m of an operating mobile process unit and its charging hose if they are under the influence of or are carrying alcohol or another performance-diminishing substance. However, a person who has taken a prescription drug may enter the area if they have medical proof that they need the drug and that it will not impede their ability to function safely.

A person at a client site must not be in possession of any thing, or carry out any activity, within 15 m of a mobile process unit and its charging hose if the thing or activity could increase the likelihood of an accidental ignition.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 2
Heading.TitleText: Manufacturing Explosives under a Division 2 Factory Licence or a Manufacturing Certificate

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Division.

Definition.Text: competent person means a person described in subsection 122(2). (personne compétente)

division 2 factory licence means a licence that is issued by the Minister under paragraph 7(1)(a) of the Explosives Act authorizing a manufacturing activity referred to in section 53 at a workplace. (licence de fabrique de la section 2)

manufacturing certificate means a certificate that is issued by the Minister under paragraph 7(1)(c) of the Explosives Act and authorizes an activity referred to in section 107 at a workplace. (certificat de fabrication)

worker means a person who is at a workplace to carry out a manufacturing operation or some other kind of work (for example, maintenance of facilities or repair of equipment) for the holder of a division 2 factory licence. (travailleur)
workplace means a building, room or area where an activity involving the manufacture of *explosives, including their storage, is carried out. (lieu de travail)

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A holder of a division 2 factory licence or manufacturing certificate may carry out those of the following activities that are specified in the licence or certificate at a workplace specified in the licence or certificate:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the owner of a surface mine or quarry, the blending of ammonium nitrate and fuel oil at a blast site at the mine or quarry;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacture of *small arms cartridges for sale, and the storage of up to 225 kg of *explosives contained in the cartridges and up to 75 kg of propellant powder in bulk to be used in manufacturing the cartridges;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacture of any explosives for the purpose of conducting an experiment, demonstration, test or analysis at a school, college, university or other learning institution or by a law enforcement or government agency and the storage of up to 5 kg of the manufactured explosives;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacture of any explosives for the purpose of conducting an experiment, test or analysis by a private or commercial laboratory and the storage of up to 5 kg of the manufactured explosives;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacture of consumer fireworks for personal use and the storage up to 25 kg of the manufactured fireworks;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacture of display fireworks for personal use and the storage up to 25 kg of the manufactured fireworks;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacture of rocket motors for personal use and the storage of up to 25 kg of manufactured rocket motors and propellant powder (combined quantity) to be used in manufacturing the motors;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacture and storage of black powder charges for ceremonial use;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the preparation and storage of display fireworks at a location other than the site of the display;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the mixing of non-explosive components for the purpose of manufacturing *industrial explosives at the site where they will be used;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the preparation and packaging of assortments of explosives for the purpose of sale by a person who does not hold a vendor magazine licence; or

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: any other activity relating to the manufacture and storage of explosives (for example, assembling a net-throwing device for sale, re-packing deteriorated explosives or destroying explosives).

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A holder of a manufacturing certificate may acquire an *explosive if it is specified in the certificate and will be used to manufacture another explosive whose manufacture is authorized by the certificate.

A holder of a division 2 factory licence or manufacturing certificate that authorizes the storage of an explosive must comply with the terms and conditions of the licence or certificate. The holder must also comply with the provisions that apply to storage in Parts 10 to 18. However, they are not required to comply with those provisions if the explosive is stored at the workplace.

A holder of a division 2 factory licence or manufacturing certificate that authorizes the manufacture of an explosive for sale may sell that explosive. The holder must comply with the terms and conditions of the licence or certificate and with the provisions that apply to sale in Parts 10 to 18.

A holder of a division 2 factory licence or manufacturing certificate that authorizes the manufacture of fireworks must comply with the provisions that apply to the use of fireworks in Parts 16 to 18.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for a division 2 factory licence or a manufacturing certificate must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must state whether the application is for a licence or a certificate and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address of both the applicant and a contact person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the type of *explosive, and the quantity, to be manufactured or stored;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the application is for a certificate, the period for which the certificate is requested;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the workplace, all equipment in the workplace that is related to the manufacture of explosives and all protective barriers in the workplace;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of all equipment in the workplace that is not related to the manufacture of explosives, but could increase the likelihood of an ignition; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the number of people authorized in the workplace when explosives are present.

Subsection.Text: The application must include a site plan that shows

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the workplace within any building or structure;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the topography of any outdoor area included in the workplace;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the barriers and equipment described in paragraphs (1)(d) and (e); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the distance in metres between the barriers and equipment described in paragraphs (1)(d) and (e).

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the workplace within the locality;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the area surrounding the site that is exposed to the hazards (for example, debris or blast effect) that could result from an ignition of the explosives to be manufactured or stored at the site;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: each *vulnerable place within that area; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the distance in metres between the workplace and each vulnerable place.

Subsection.Text: The applicant for a division 2 factory licence or a manufacturing certificate must pay the applicable fees set out in Part 19.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A holder of a division 2 factory licence or a manufacturing certificate must ensure that the requirements relating to the workplace set out in sections 111 to 115 are met in the workplace.

Subsection.Text: The workplace must have a means of escape that will permit all people in the workplace to leave it quickly and easily in an emergency.
The lighting, electrical and heating systems that are used in the workplace must not increase the likelihood of an ignition.
Every thing that is in a workplace must be made from materials that are *compatible with the *explosives and raw material in the workplace.

However, a thing that is not compatible with an explosive or raw material in the workplace but is required for manufacturing may be brought to the workplace for immediate use. It must be removed as soon as the circumstances permit after its use, unless the division 2 factory licence or manufacturing certificate authorizes its storage in the workplace.
An open-flame device or open-element electrical appliance must not be stored in a part of the workplace where explosives are being manufactured.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When *explosives are being manufactured or stored at a workplace, no other activities may be carried out there.
All manufacturing operations at the workplace must be carried out by a competent person.

The workplace must be kept clean, dry and organized. Any spill of explosives, raw material or other material must be cleaned up as soon as the circumstances permit to eliminate any possibility of an ignition.

If the likelihood of an ignition could be increased as a result of foreign matter (for example, bolts, gravel or grit) being present in or mixed with any raw material, or explosive used as raw material, the material must be carefully examined and passed through a sieve or treated to remove or exclude the foreign matter before manufacturing begins.

All raw material, *explosive substances and explosives waste must be kept in closed containers that prevent spills and contamination. The contents of each container must be clearly identified on a label attached to the container.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Disposal of waste and contaminated material
Subsection.Text: All explosives waste and explosives-contaminated material must be destroyed in a manner that does not increase the likelihood of an accidental ignition during or after the destruction.

Unless the division 2 factory licence or manufacturing certificate provides otherwise, explosives must be removed as soon as the circumstances permit after they are manufactured from the part of the workplace where they were manufactured to the part of the workplace where they will be stored.

A workplace that is no longer being used to manufacture explosives must be *decontaminated as soon as the circumstances permit. Contaminated equipment at the workplace must be decontaminated before it is removed.

On the approach of a thunderstorm, all manufacturing operations in the workplace must be shut down and all people in the workplace must be immediately moved to a safe place. Until the storm passes, the operations must remain shut down and the people must not be permitted to return.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: Maintenance and repair work done at or to a workplace, or to equipment in it, must be carried out by a competent person.
Any work that involves the use of a device that produces heat, flame or sparks or involves grinding or impact must be done in a manner that does not increase the likelihood of an ignition.

Section.Text: A sign that warns against unauthorized entry must be posted at each entrance to the workplace.
A holder of a division 2 factory licence or a manufacturing certificate must ensure that the labelling requirements set out in section 117 are met at the workplace.

Subsection.Text: The following information must be legibly printed on each *explosive that is manufactured in the workshop, or if that is not possible, on a label affixed to the explosive or, if even that is not possible, on the packaging containing the explosive or a label affixed to its packaging:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name of the explosive and the name and address of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the explosive was manufactured and, if the manufacturer carries out manufacturing operations in shifts, the shift during which it was manufactured; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: instructions, in both English and French, for its safe handling, storage, use and destruction.

Subsection.Text: The following information must be legibly printed on the packaging containing the explosive or on a label affixed to its packaging:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the words “Ammunition/Munitions”, “Explosives/Explosifs”, “Fireworks/Pièces pyrotechniques”, “Pyrotechnics/Pièces pyrotechniques” or “Reloaded Cartridges/Cartouches rechargées”, as the case may be, on the outer packaging and any inner packaging;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name of the explosive and the name and address of the person who obtained its authorization, on the outer packaging;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a type F explosive, whether it is type F.1, F.2, F.3 or F.4, on the outer packaging; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a type S explosive, whether it is type S.1 or S.2, on the outer packaging.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.TitleText: Safety of People at the Workplace

Section.Text: A holder of a division 2 factory licence or a manufacturing certificate must ensure that the requirements relating to personal safety set out in sections 119 and 120 are met at the workplace.
Every person at a workplace, other than a worker, must be kept under the direct supervision of a competent person at all times.

Subsection.Text: Every person at a workplace must be required to wear the personal protective equipment, clothing and devices that are needed to protect them from the hazards to which they could be exposed.

Every person at a workplace must be required to confine or cover any loose hair and to confine, cover or remove any loose clothing, jewellery or other accessories if the hair, clothing or accessories could increase the likelihood of an ignition or the likelihood of harm to the person.

Every person at a workplace must be required to deactivate any electronic device in their possession (for example, a cellphone or two-way radio) in any part of the workplace where the device, if activated, could increase the likelihood of an ignition.

A person must not be authorized to enter the workplace if there are reasonable grounds to believe that they are under the influence of or are carrying alcohol or another performance-diminishing substance. However, a person who has taken a prescription drug may be authorized to enter if they have medical proof that the drug is needed and that it will not impede their ability to function safely.
Smoking must be prohibited in the workplace.
Fire-producing devices (for example, matches and lighters) must not be permitted in the workplace unless they are authorized by the division 2 factory licence or manufacturing certificate.

Section.Text: A holder of a division 2 factory licence or a manufacturing certificate must ensure that the training requirements set out in sections 122 and 123 are met at the workplace.

Subsection.Text: A person must not be permitted to manufacture *explosives at a workplace unless they meet the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they are a competent person; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: they are at least 17 years old, participating in a training program and under the direct supervision of a competent person.

Subsection.Text: A competent person is a person who meets the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they are at least 18 years old; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the holder of the division 2 licence or manufacturing certificate believes on reasonable grounds that the person understands the hazards to which they could be exposed in the workplace and is competent to carry out their duties in manner that is safe and lawful and ensures the security of the workplace.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A training record and a record of work experience must be kept for each worker for two years after the date on which it is made.
A holder of a division 2 factory licence or manufacturing certificate must have knowledge of the following matters and must ensure that these matters are communicated to the workers at the workplace:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the provisions of the Explosives Act and these Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the terms and conditions of the licence or certificate, including the maximum quantity of *explosives and raw material and the maximum number of people authorized to be in the workplace at any one time;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all safety rules respecting the manufacture of explosives at the workplace;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the personal protective equipment that is needed to protect people from the hazards to which they could be exposed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: all emergency plans for the workplace, including the evacuation plan;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the hazards of, and safe handling practices for, the explosives and raw material at the workplace;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the precautions that must be taken to minimize the likelihood of harm to people and property during manufacturing operations, including harm resulting from chemical incompatibility;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of the equipment at the workplace;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the maintenance and repair of the equipment, including *decontamination; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for inspecting the workplace or equipment after maintenance and repair work has been done.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A holder of a division 2 factory licence or a manufacturing certificate must ensure that the management requirements set out in sections 126 to 128 are met at the workplace.
Operating procedures must be put in place for each of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: every activity specified in the division 2 factory licence or manufacturing certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the destruction of *explosives, explosives waste and explosives-contaminated material;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the management of spills and their clean-up;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the response to emergency situations;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the *decontamination of the workplace and all tools and equipment.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A record of each *explosive in the workplace (including any explosive that is used as raw material) must be kept for two years after the date on which the record is made. It must set out, for each explosive,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name and a short description of the explosive and its properties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive was received, the quantity received and the date of reception;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive was used to manufacture an explosive, the quantity used and the date of use;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive was manufactured in the workplace, the quantity manufactured and the date of manufacture;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive was stored, the quantity stored, the place in which it was stored and the dates on which it was placed in and removed from storage;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive was shipped from the workplace, the quantity shipped, the date of shipment and the address of the person to whom it was shipped; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive was destroyed at the workplace, the quantity destroyed and the date of destruction.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A copy of the division 2 factory licence or the manufacturing certificate and all documents that are referred to in the licence or certificate must be kept at the workplace.
A copy of this Division must be made available to workers at the workplace.

Heading.Label: SUBDIVISION d
Heading.TitleText: Requirements for People at a Workplace

Subsection.Text: Before entering, a visitor to a workplace must obtain the permission of the holder of the division 2 factory licence or manufacturing certificate. They must remain under the supervision of a competent person at all times.

A person must not enter a workplace if they are under the influence of or are carrying alcohol or another performance-diminishing substance. However, a person who has taken a prescription drug may enter if they have medical proof that they need the drug and that it will not impede their ability to function safely.
Every person at a workplace must wear the personal protective equipment, clothing and devices that are needed to protect them from the hazards to which they could be exposed.

Every person at a workplace must confine or cover any loose hair and confine, cover or remove any loose clothing, jewellery or other accessories if the hair, clothing or accessories could increase the likelihood of an ignition or the likelihood of harm to the person.

Every person must deactivate any electronic device in their possession (for example, a cellphone or two-way radio) in any part of the workplace where the device, if activated, could increase the likelihood of an ignition.

Section.Text: A person must not smoke at a workplace.

Subsection.Text: A person must not manufacture *explosives at a workplace unless they meet the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they are a competent person; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: they are at least 17 years old, participating in a training program and under the direct supervision of a competent person.

Subsection.Text: A person must not carry out a task at a workplace unless they have been trained in that task and understand the hazards to which they could be exposed. They must take the precautions that they are directed to take to minimize the likelihood of an accidental ignition.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 3
Heading.TitleText: Manufacturing that Does Not Require a Licence or Certificate

Section.Text: A person who manufactures an *explosive under the authority of this Division must comply with Parts 10 to 18.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A school, college, university or other learning institution, or a law enforcement or government agency, that complies with subsection (2) may manufacture up to 50 g of *explosives for the purposes of an experiment, demonstration, test or analysis.
The institution or agency must ensure that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacturing must be carried out with the consent of the management of the institution or agency by one of its employees or by a person who is at all times under the direct supervision of an employee;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the employee must know how to carry out the manufacturing in a manner that minimizes the likelihood of harm to people and property and be aware of the precautions that must be taken to minimize the likelihood of harm to people and property;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: every person who carries out the manufacturing must be at least 18 years old;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that will eliminate any possibility of an accidental ignition must be taken;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: explosives must not be removed from the location where they are manufactured except for the purpose of destroying them; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: all explosives must be destroyed in a manner that does not increase the likelihood of an accidental ignition during or after the destruction.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A person who complies with subsection (2) may assemble *explosives by combining *explosive articles (for example, a detonator with a booster, a detonating cord with an explosive cartridge or fireworks with fireworks accessories) at the place where the explosives will be used.
The person who carries out the activity must ensure that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the explosive articles must be on the list of authorized explosives referred to in subsection 41(1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the explosive articles must not be altered, except that cartridges may be cut or slit and detonating cord and fuses may be cut or trimmed; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of an accidental ignition must be taken.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A person who complies with subsection (2) may carry out any of the following activities underground at an underground mine or underground construction project:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: pneumatically transferring *explosives;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: pumping, thickening or gassing either emulsion explosives or water gel explosives while charging boreholes; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: blending emulsion explosives or water gel explosives with ammonium nitrate or ammonium nitrate/fuel oil mixtures while charging boreholes.

Subsection.Text: The person who carries out the activity must ensure that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the explosives must be on the list of authorized explosives referred to in subsection 41(1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment used to pump, thicken, gas or blend emulsion explosives or water gel explosives must be designed to minimize the likelihood of an ignition, including an ignition resulting from pumping against a blocked outlet or from running the pump without any feed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all progressive cavity pumps must be equipped with at least two independent safety shutdown systems to prevent an excessive rise in temperature;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the person is assisted by another person, the other person must be trained to operate the equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a preventive maintenance procedure must be put in place for the equipment, including the pumps;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: maintenance must be performed by workers who are knowledgeable about the equipment to be maintained; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of an ignition must be taken.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A person who complies with subsection (2) may pneumatically transfer *explosives at a surface mine or a quarry.
The person who carries out the activity must ensure that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the explosives must be on the list of authorized explosives referred to in subsection 41(1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the device used for pneumatic charging must have a maximum capacity of 100 kg and the explosives used in the pneumatic charging must be in bags, each with a maximum capacity of 30 kg; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of an ignition must be taken.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A person who complies with subsection (2) may mix together the ingredients of a multi-ingredient kit.
The person who carries out the activity must ensure that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the kit must be on the list of authorized *explosives referred to in subsection 41(1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the mixing must be carried out at the place where the explosive to be manufactured will be used;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of an ignition must be taken;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive to be manufactured is classified as type F.3, the person mixing the ingredients must hold a fireworks operator certificate — pyrotechnician; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if the explosive to be manufactured is a special purpose explosive, the person mixing the ingredients must hold a fireworks operator certificate — pyrotechnician or a licence issued under the Firearms Act.
Paragraph.Note: Note: Section 10 provides that a person must be at least 18 years old to carry out an *activity involving an explosive.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A person who complies with subsection (2) may remove *explosives from, or repackage explosives at, the site of an accident or spill.
The person who carries out the activity must ensure that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of an ignition must be taken;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any packaging used must prevent the explosives involved from leaking or spilling and minimize the likelihood of an accidental ignition; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Chief Inspector of Explosives must be notified of the accident or spill within 12 hours after the removal or repackaging begins.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A person who complies with subsection (2) may pump *explosives numbered UN 0332 and classified as Class 1.5, Compatibility Group D under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations classified as Class 1.5, Compatibility Group D under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations in activating an emergency response assistance plan approved by the Minister of Transport under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992.
The person who carries out the activity must ensure that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: written permission must be obtained from a holder of a division 1 factory licence that authorizes the manufacture of blasting explosives in bulk to store the pumped explosives at the holder’s factory and to *decontaminate the pumping equipment there;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an air-powered diaphragm pump that is safe for pumping the explosives must be used;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the explosives and contaminated equipment must be stored at the factory; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the follow-up report that is required under section 8.3 of the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations must be submitted to the Chief Inspector of Explosives within 30 days after the date on which the explosives are pumped.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A person who complies with subsection (2) may destroy deteriorated, expired or misfired *industrial explosives by placing them in a borehole with other *explosives and igniting the other explosives.
The person who carries out the activity must ensure that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the explosives to be destroyed and the other explosives must have similar properties (for example, similar density and propensity to detonate); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the presence of the other explosives at the time of the ignition must not increase the likelihood of harm to people or property.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A government or law enforcement agency (for example, a police explosives disposal unit) may break up, unmake or destroy an *explosive if it does so in the course of its duties.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.Label: PART 6
Heading.TitleText: Magazine Licences and Storage in a Licensed Magazine

Section.Text: This Part sets out how to obtain a vendor magazine licence, a user magazine licence or a user magazine zone licence. It also sets out the rules applicable to holders of these licences.
The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: distribution establishment means an establishment where explosives are stored for sale to distributors or retailers, whether or not the explosives are sold to users. (établissement de distribution)
magazine site means the area, including any building or structure, that is used in connection with the storage of explosives in a magazine. (site de poudrière)
retail establishment means an establishment where explosives are stored for sale that is not a distribution establishment. (établissement de vente au détail)

user magazine licence means a licence that is issued under paragraph 7(1)(a) of the Explosives Act and authorizes the storage of explosives by a person who has acquired them for use or conveyance. (licence de poudriére (utilisateur))

user magazine zone licence means a licence that is issued under paragraph 7(1)(a) of the Explosives Act and authorizes the storage of type E or I explosives by a person who has acquired them for use. It also authorizes the holder to move the storage of explosives from one site to another. (licence de poudrière (utilisateur-zone))

vendor magazine licence means a licence that is issued under paragraph 7(1)(a) of the Explosives Act and that authorizes the storage of explosives by a person who has acquired them for sale or for sale and use. (licence de poudrière (vendeur))

Subsection.Text: An applicant for a magazine licence must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must state whether a vendor magazine licence, a user magazine licence or a user magazine zone licence is requested and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address of both the applicant and a contact person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the address and geographical coordinates of the magazine site;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number of magazines for which the licence is requested;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of each type of *explosive to be stored in each magazine;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if the application is for a vendor magazine licence, an indication of whether the site will be a retail establishment or a distribution establishment; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if the site will be a distribution establishment, an indication of whether explosives will be repackaged there.

Subsection.Text: The application must include the following documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a plan of the magazine site that shows

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the location of each magazine and each *vulnerable place at the site as well as the location of each vulnerable place outside the site that is exposed to the hazards (for example, debris or blast effect) that could result from ignition of the explosives to be stored at the site, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the distance in metres between each magazine at the site, between each magazine and each vulnerable place at the site as well as between each magazine at the site and each vulnerable place outside the site that is exposed to the hazards (for example, debris or blast effect) that could result from ignition of the explosives to be stored at the site; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if one or more magazines occupies only a part of a building or structure, a drawing that shows the location of each magazine in the building or structure and the location of each entrance to and exit from the room or area in which each magazine is located and to which the public has access.

Subsection.Text: The application must include the following information about the site:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the proposed use of the site and the proposed use of each building and structure at the site;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the distance in metres between each magazine and any potential source of ignition at the site;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the distance in metres between each magazine at the site, between each magazine and each vulnerable place at the site as well as between each magazine at the site and each vulnerable place outside the site that is exposed to the hazards (for example, debris or blast effect) that could result from ignition of the explosives to be stored at the site;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the minimum distance in metres that must be maintained between each magazine at the site and each vulnerable place shown on the site plan, as set out in the National Standard of Canada Standard CAN/BNQ 2910–510/2015 entitled Explosives — Quantity Distances as amended from time to time;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the safety and security features of the site (for example, signs, alarm systems, barriers, fencing and berms); and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: for each magazine at the site,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the tag number, if any, issued by the Explosives Regulatory Division, Department of Natural Resources,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the applicable magazine type number, as set out in the National Standard of Canada Standard CAN/BNQ 2910–500/2015 entitled Explosives — Magazines for Industrial Explosives, as amended from time to time or, if the magazine does not correspond to any of those types, its specifications, including its construction materials and its safety and security features, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: its internal dimensions (length, width and height) in metres to the nearest 0.1 m.

Subsection.Text: The application must include a fire safety plan that sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the measures to be taken to minimize the likelihood of a fire at the site and to control the spread of any fire;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the emergency procedures to be followed in case of a fire, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: activation of the alarms,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: notification of the fire department, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: evacuation procedures, including evacuation routes and safe assembly places;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the circumstances in which a fire should or should not be fought and a procedure for determining whether a fire should be fought; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the measures to be taken to train employees in the measures, procedures and circumstances described in the plan.

Subsection.Text: If type E, I or D explosives are to be stored at the site, the application must include a security plan that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
