Paragraph.Text: an assessment of the security risks resulting from the presence of explosives at the site;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the measures to be taken to minimize those risks;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the procedures to be followed in response to security incidents; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the procedures to be followed to report security incidents.

Subsection.Text: If the site is a distribution establishment at which marine flares (type S.1 or S.2) are to be stored, the application must include a plan for destroying expired marine flares that are returned to the site. The plan must set out where and how the marine flares will be stored and destroyed.

Every magazine and vulnerable place that is shown on a site plan must be identified by a number, letter or distinctive name, which must be used to identify the magazine or vulnerable place on the site plan and in the site description.
Every drawing or plan must be drawn to scale or be a reasonable approximation of actual distances and dimensions and must include a legend.
If the application is for a user magazine zone licence, the requirements of subsections (1) to (8) apply to the initial magazine site.
An applicant for a magazine licence must pay the applicable fees set out in Part 19.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.TitleText: Requirements for Holders of Magazine Licences

Section.Text: A holder of a magazine licence must ensure that the requirements of sections 147 to 160 are met and that the people referred to in section 161 are aware of their obligations under that section.

Subsection.Text: Every magazine must be located at an acceptable distance from surrounding structures, infrastructure and places where people are likely to be present.

In the case of a vendor magazine licence and a user magazine licence, acceptable distance is determined by the Minister on the basis of risk of harm to people or property, taking into account the quantity and type of *explosives to be stored in the magazine, the strength, proximity and use of surrounding structures and infrastructure and the number of people likely to be in the vicinity of the magazine at any one time.

In the case of a user magazine zone licence, acceptable distance is the minimum distance in metres to be maintained between each magazine at the site and each *vulnerable place shown on the site plan, as set out in the National Standard of Canada Standard CAN/BNQ 2910–510/2015 entitled Explosives — Quantity Distances as amended from time to time.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: Every magazine must be constructed and maintained so that it is well-ventilated and resistant to theft, weather and fire. A magazine for the storage of *explosives that are classified as hazard category PE 1 must also be bullet-resistant, unless the magazine licence specifies otherwise.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: An *explosive may be stored in a magazine only if the licence authorizes the storage of that explosive in that magazine.

Materials and equipment may be brought into or stored in a magazine only if they are required for operations, including handling explosives, in the magazine and they do not increase the likelihood of an ignition.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: Packages and containers of *explosives must be stacked so that they will not fall over, collapse or be deformed, torn or crushed. They must not be stacked higher than the stacking line for the magazine.
Packages and containers of explosives must not be used as supports for conveyors or ramps.
There must be enough space between the stacks of explosives, the walls, the ceiling and the ventilation openings to permit air circulation.

Packages or containers that are made from wood or have metal fasteners or strapping must not be opened in a magazine. Other packages or containers may be opened in a magazine for inspection or to remove explosives, but they must be opened one at a time.
Any package or container of explosives that has been opened outside a magazine must be dry, clean and free of grit and other contamination before it is taken into the magazine.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: Precautions must be taken that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near a magazine.
Smoking must be prohibited in a magazine.
On the approach of a thunderstorm, all people in a magazine must be immediately moved to a safe place and until the storm passes must not be permitted to return.

Section.Text: The following activities must not be carried out inside a magazine unless the magazine licence authorizes them to be carried out there:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: packing or repacking *explosives;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: adding a detonator to, or inserting a detonator in, an explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: assembling explosive components;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: uncoiling the leg wires of, or removing the shunt from, an electric detonator or an electric initiator;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: opening a package or container of explosives to expose an *explosive substance; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: stripping, cutting or slitting the wrapping of an *explosive article to expose an explosive substance.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A magazine must be *attended in person when it is unlocked.
A key control plan that includes the following requirements must be put in place for each magazine:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: every key to the magazine must be numbered;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person may have possession of a key to the magazine only if they are named in the plan;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number of people named in the plan must not exceed the number necessary for the operation of the magazine;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: each key must be kept in a locked and secure location when it is not in the possession of a person named in the plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an *industrial explosive or a type D explosive, the lock on the magazine must be of a type for which keys can be obtained only from the lock’s manufacturer or a certified locksmith designated by the manufacturer.

Subsection.Text: The plan must be updated to reflect any change in circumstances that could adversely affect the security of the magazine site.
If a key is lost or stolen, the lock must be immediately replaced.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A copy of the fire safety plan included in the licence application must be sent to the local fire department and made available to employees.

The plan must be updated to reflect any change in circumstances that could adversely affect the safety of the site. A copy of the updated plan must be sent to the local fire department as soon as the circumstances permit.
If a site security plan is included in the licence application, it must be implemented.

The plan must be updated to reflect any change in circumstances that could adversely affect the security of the magazine site. A copy of the updated plan must be sent to the Chief Inspector of Explosives as soon as the circumstances permit.
A copy of the most recent version of the plan must be made available to the people who are responsible for implementing it.

Section.Text: A record for each magazine must be kept for two years after the date on which it is made. The record must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: each type of *explosive that is stored;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of each type of explosive that is stored; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the dates on which each explosive was placed in and removed from the magazine.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A magazine must be kept clean, dry and organized. Any spill, leakage or other contamination must be cleaned up immediately.
A magazine must be kept free of grit, combustible or abrasive material, any fire-producing, spark-producing or flame-producing device and any substance that might spontaneously combust.

The lighting (including portable lighting), electrical fixtures and wiring systems that are used in a magazine must not increase the likelihood of an ignition. All portable lighting must be impact-resistant.
Before any repair work that could increase the likelihood of an ignition begins in or on a magazine, the *explosives in the magazine must be either

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: put into another magazine; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: taken to a location where the presence of the explosives will not increase the likelihood of harm to people or property, the explosives are protected from weather and the repair work will not cause an ignition.

Subsection.Text: Any explosives that are not put into another magazine must be *attended in person.
Explosives must not be returned to a magazine until the repairs to the magazine no longer increase the likelihood of an ignition.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A sign that indicates the type of *explosives, and the maximum quantity of each type, that may be stored in the magazine, as specified in the licence, must be posted inside every magazine in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The *explosives in a magazine must be checked regularly for signs of deterioration and to ensure that the manufacturer’s expiry date has not passed.
Every deteriorated, expired or misfired explosive must be clearly marked “Deteriorated/Détérioré” or “Expired/Périmé” or “Misfired/Raté”, as the case may be.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Destruction of deteriorated, expired or misfired explosives
Subsection.Text: Explosives that have deteriorated, expired or misfired must be safely destroyed as soon as the circumstances permit. However, explosives that have deteriorated to the extent that they are unstable or in a very dangerous condition must be destroyed immediately in a manner that does not increase the likelihood of an accidental ignition during or after the destruction.
Subsection (3) does not authorize a person to destroy deteriorated, expired or misfired explosives. The destruction must be authorized by these Regulations or otherwise under the Explosives Act.
A deteriorated, expired or misfired explosive may be stored in a magazine with other *compatible explosives if the storage would not increase the likelihood of an ignition.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Storage until destruction — more than normal hazard
Subsection.Text: A deteriorated, expired or misfired explosive must be stored in a magazine that does not contain other explosives if storing it with other explosives could increase the likelihood of an ignition.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A person who is in possession of a key that is subject to a key control plan referred to in subsection 153(2) must not duplicate the key. After using it, the person must return the key to a locked location to which access is controlled.

Heading.TitleText: Requirements for Holders of User Magazine Zone Licences

Subsection.Text: When the storage of explosives that is authorized by a user magazine zone licence is moved to a new site, within 24 hours after the move the holder of the licence must complete, sign and send a notice of change of site, in the form provided by the Department of Natural Resources, to the Minister, to the police force in the locality of the previous site and to the police force in the locality of the new site. The notice must be dated and include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone and cellphone number, fax number and email address of both the licence holder and a contact person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the holder’s licence number and its expiry date;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name, telephone number and cellphone number of the person who is responsible for the new site;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the storage of explosives began at the new site;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the geographic coordinates of the previous and new sites;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the directions by road to the new site;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the safety and security features of the new site (for example, signs, alarm systems, barriers, fencing and berms); and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the magazines to be used at the new site that sets out

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a magazine that has been moved, its number, letter or distinctive name as shown on the previous site plan,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: its tag number, if any,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the applicable magazine type number, as set out in the National Standard of Canada Standard CAN/BNQ 2910–500/2015 entitled Explosives — Magazines for Industrial Explosives, as amended from time to time, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: each type of *explosive, and the quantity of each type, to be stored.

Subsection.Text: The notice must include a site plan that shows

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the location of each magazine and each *vulnerable place at the site as well as the location of each vulnerable place outside the site that is exposed to the hazards (for example, debris or blast effect) that could result from ignition of the explosives to be stored;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the distance in metres between each magazine at the site, between each magazine and each vulnerable place at the site as well as between each magazine at the site and each vulnerable place outside the site that is exposed to the hazards (for example, debris or blast effect) that could result from ignition of the explosives to be stored at the site; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the minimum distance in metres to be maintained between each magazine at the site and each vulnerable place shown on the site plan, as set out in the National Standard of Canada Standard CAN/BNQ 2910–510/2015 entitled Explosives — Quantity Distances, as amended from time to time.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The holder must ensure that a copy of the user magazine zone licence and of the notice are posted in each magazine.

This Part sets out certain terms and conditions that apply to holders of the documents (licences, permits and certificates) issued by the Minister under section 7 of the Explosives Act. It also sets out the procedures for changing or renewing these documents and provides for their suspension and cancellation.

Subsection.Text: A holder of a licence, permit or certificate may carry out any *activity involving an explosive that is authorized by the document and must do so in the manner specified in it.
The holder must ensure that their employees and other workers carry out the activities authorized by the document in the manner specified in it.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.MarginalNote: Presentation of licence, permit or certificate
Section.Text: A holder of a licence, permit or certificate must present their document for review at the request of a peace officer.

Subsection.Text: A holder of a licence, permit or certificate must immediately inform the local fire department of any fire that involves an *explosive under their control.
A holder of a licence, permit or certificate must inform an inspector as soon as the circumstances permit of any of the following incidents that involves an explosive under their control:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the theft, attempted theft or loss of an explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a fire, spill or accidental explosion;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an injury or death; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any accidental property damage.

Subsection.Text: The holder must provide the Chief Inspector of Explosives with a detailed follow-up report about the incident as soon as the circumstances permit. The report must include the likely cause of the incident and the steps that the holder will take to prevent such an incident from happening again.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A holder of a licence, permit or certificate who has not applied to renew the document or obtain a new document must ensure that on or before the expiry date of their document the *explosives under their control

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are destroyed in a manner that does not increase the likelihood of an accidental ignition during or after the destruction;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are returned to the person from whom they were bought; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are delivered to a holder of a factory licence that authorizes storage of those explosives.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: Before decommissioning a factory, a holder of a division 1 factory licence must send a written decommissioning plan to the Minister.

Before decommissioning a workplace or magazine, a holder of a division 2 factory licence, a magazine licence or a manufacturing certificate must send a written decomissioning plan to the Minister if the workplace or magazine contains any *explosive residue.
A decommissioning plan must include a description of the safety measures that the holder will take to minimize the likelihood of harm to people or property during and after the decommissioning.
The Minister may require the holder to implement additional safety measures that are necessary to minimize the likelihood of harm to people or property.

The holder must implement the decommissioning plan and ensure that the factory, workplace or magazine is decommissioned in a safe manner and that any possibility of harm to people or property is eliminated after the factory or magazine is decommissioned. They must inform the Minister when the decommissioning is complete.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: For any calendar year during which a holder of a factory licence, an import or export permit or a manufacturing certificate carries out an *activity involving an explosive, the holder must submit a report to the Chief Inspector of Explosives in the form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The report must include, for each explosive,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its UN number;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for each UN number, the quantity of explosive that was acquired, *manufactured, imported, exported, used, sold, lost, stolen or destroyed during the calendar year; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of each explosive in the holder’s inventory on December 31 of the calendar year or, if the holder ceased operations during the year, on the date on which operations ceased.

Subsection.Text: The report must be submitted

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when the holder applies to renew their licence, permit or certificate, if the application for renewal is between the end of the calendar year and March 31 of the following year; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on or before March 31 of the year following the calendar year if the holder has not applied for a renewal before that day.

Subsection.Text: Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply to a holder that reports the importation of explosives by electronic means in accordance with section 4 of the Reporting of Imported Goods Regulations.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A licence holder who intends to suspend an activity for which their licence was issued must, no later than 14 days before the date on which the suspension is to begin, give the Minister written notice of the date of suspension and the anticipated date, if any, for resuming the activity.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for an amendment of a licence, permit or certificate, or for a renewal with amendment, must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must state whether the amendment requested is to a licence, a permit or a certificate and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address of both the applicant and a contact person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of the applicant’s licence, permit or certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the amendment requested; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all the information that differs from that provided in the previous application.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for a renewal without amendment of a licence, permit or certificate must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address of both the applicant and a contact person; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of the applicant’s licence, permit or certificate.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsections (1) and (2), a person who applies for the renewal of a manufacturing certificate must comply with section 109.
An applicant must pay the applicable fees set out in Part 19.

The Chief Inspector of Explosives may suspend a licence, permit or certificate, in whole or in part, if the holder fails to comply with the Explosives Act, these Regulations or any term or condition of the document. The suspension continues until the measures required to bring the holder into compliance are taken.
The Chief Inspector may cancel a licence, permit or certificate if the holder

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: fails more than one time to comply with the Explosives Act, these Regulations or any term or condition of the document; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: jeopardizes the safety of the public or the holder’s employees by failing to follow the practices of the *explosives industry.

Subsection.Text: Before suspending or cancelling a licence, permit or certificate, the Chief Inspector must provide the holder with written notice of the reasons for the suspension or cancellation and its effective date and give them an opportunity to provide reasons why the licence, permit or certificate should not be suspended or cancelled.

The holder may request that the Minister review the Chief Inspector’s decision to suspend or cancel. The request must be made in writing within 15 days after the Chief Inspector has given the holder notice of the decision. The Minister must confirm, revoke or amend the decision.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: This Part sets out the screening requirements for people who have access to high hazard explosives. Division 1 sets out the requirements that must be met by applicants for licences, permits or certificates if they intend to *manufacture, store, import or export high hazard explosives or transport them in transit. Division 2 sets out the duties of licence, permit and certificate holders to control access to high hazard explosives. It also sets out the requirements for obtaining letters of approval.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: approval letter means an approval letter issued by the Minister under section 183. (lettre d’approbation)
certificate means a certificate that authorizes the manufacture or storage of a high hazard explosive. (certificat)
equivalent document means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a permis général issued under Quebec’s An Act respecting explosives, as amended from time to time;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a FAST card (free and secure trade card) issued by the Canada Border Services Agency;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a NEXUS card issued by the Canada Border Services Agency; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a Firearms Possession and Acquisition Licence issued under the Firearms Act. (document équivalent)

Definition.Text: high hazard explosive refers to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: military explosives or law enforcement explosives (type D);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: high explosives (type E); or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: initiation systems (type I). (explosif à risque élevé)

Definition.Text: licence means a licence that authorizes the storage of a high hazard explosive. (licence)
permit means a permit that authorizes the importation, exportation or in transit transportation of a high hazard explosive. (permis)

Subsection.Text: A person is considered to have access to a high hazard explosive if it is possible for them to come into contact, even momentary contact, with such an explosive.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 1
Heading.TitleText: Application for Licence, Permit or Certificate

Subsection.Text: An individual who applies for a licence, permit or certificate or for the renewal of one must include with their application proof that they have an approval letter or equivalent document.

Every applicant for a licence, permit or certificate, or for the renewal of one, must also include a list of their employees who are required by this Part to have an approval letter and must indicate whether the employee has applied for the letter and whether it has been received.

If the applicant’s criminal record check does not reveal any of the circumstances set out in subsection (2) or the applicant has an equivalent document, the Minister may issue or renew the licence, permit or certificate.

The Minister must refuse to issue or renew the licence, permit or certificate and must give the applicant written notice of the refusal and the reason for the refusal, if the criminal record check reveals any of the following circumstances:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant is subject to a court order prohibiting them from possessing an *explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant has, within the five years before the date on which the application was received by the Minister, been convicted of any of the following offences:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an indictable offence under the Explosives Act,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an indictable offence under Quebec’s An Act respecting Explosives, as amended from time to time,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: an offence under any of the following provisions of the Criminal Code:

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: section 82 (possession of explosives without lawful excuse),

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the applicant has, within the five years before the date on which the application was received, been convicted more than once of either of the following offences or has been convicted at least once of each of them:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: an indictable offence in the commission of which violence against another person was used, threatened or attempted, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: an offence under section 264 of the Criminal Code (criminal harassment).

Subsection.Text: An applicant may, within 30 days after the date on which they receive a notice of refusal, send the Minister written information or documents to establish that the information on which the refusal was based is incorrect.
After reviewing the new information or documents, the Minister must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: issue or renew the licence, permit or certificate if the information on which the refusal was based is incorrect; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: give the applicant written notice of the refusal and the reasons for the refusal if the information on which it was based is correct.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.TitleText: Requirements for Holders of a Licence, Permit or Certificate

Subsection.Text: A holder of a licence, permit or certificate must ensure that an approval letter or equivalent document is held by every employee, director or contractor who, in carrying out their functions for the holder,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has access to a high hazard explosive;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: permits others to have access to a high hazard explosive; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: controls, directly or indirectly, a person who has access to a high hazard explosive or permits others to have access to such an explosive.

Subsection.Text: A holder of a licence, permit or certificate must ensure that a person who does not have an approval letter or an equivalent document does not occupy a position in which they control, directly or indirectly, a person who, in carrying out their functions for the holder, has access to a high hazard explosive.

A holder of a licence, permit or certificate must ensure that a person who does not have an approval letter or an equivalent document does not have access to a high hazard explosive that is being *manufactured, stored, sold, imported, exported or transported by the holder.

Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of a person who does not hold an equivalent document, has applied for an approval letter and was either refused or is still waiting for a response if, when they have access to a high hazard explosive, they are at all times under the direct supervision of another person who has an approval letter or equivalent document.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A holder of a licence or certificate must ensure that a visitor to their factory, magazine site, satellite site or workplace who does not have an approval letter and who could have access to a high hazard explosive is at all times under the direct supervision of a person who has an approval letter or an equivalent document.
Subsection 179(1) and section 180 do not apply in respect of the following people when they are acting in the course of their duties:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a peace officer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an employee of the federal government; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an inspector appointed under the Explosives Act.

Subsection.Text: A person may apply for an approval letter by completing, signing and sending to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, address, telephone number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s date of birth; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the applicant is employed by or is a director of a holder of a licence, permit or certificate, the holder’s name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address and, if applicable, the name of the applicant’s supervisor.

Subsection.Text: The application must include the original of a criminal record check carried out on the applicant within one year before the date on which the application is received by the Minister.

If the applicant’s criminal record check does not reveal any of the circumstances set out in subsection (2), the Minister must issue a dated approval letter to the applicant and send a copy of the letter to any holder of a licence, permit or certificate mentioned in the application.

The Minister must refuse to issue an approval letter and must give the applicant written notice of the refusal, and the reasons for the refusal, if the applicant’s criminal record check reveals any of the following circumstances:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant is subject to a court order prohibiting them from possessing any *explosives;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant has, within the five years before the date on which the application was received by the Minister, been convicted of any of the following offences:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an indictable offence under the Explosives Act,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an indictable offence under Quebec’s An Act respecting Explosives, as amended from time to time,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: an offence under any of the following provisions of the Criminal Code:

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: section 82 (possession of explosives without lawful excuse),

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the applicant has, within the five years before the date on which the application was received, been convicted more than once of either of the following offences or has been convicted at least once of each of them:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: an indictable offence in the commission of which violence against another person was used, threatened or attempted, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: an offence under section 264 of the Criminal Code (criminal harassment).

Subsection.Text: An applicant may, within 30 days after the date on which they receive a notice of refusal, send the Minister written information or documents to establish that the information on which the refusal was based is incorrect.
After reviewing the new information or documents, the Minister must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: issue the approval letter if the information on which the refusal was based is incorrect; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: give the applicant written notice of the refusal, and the reasons for the refusal, and send a copy of the notice to any licence, permit or certificate holder mentioned in the application, if the information on which the refusal was based is correct.

Subsection.Text: If the applicant does not request a review, the Minister must, at the end of the period mentioned in subsection (3), send a copy of the notice of refusal to any licence, permit or certificate holder mentioned in the application.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: An approval letter remains valid for five years after the date on which it is issued.

Subsection.Text: A person who has been issued an approval letter may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: obtain a copy of the letter by sending a request to the Chief Inspector of Explosives that sets out the person’s name, address, telephone number and email address and the date of the letter; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have a copy of the letter sent to a holder of a licence, permit or certificate by sending a request to the Chief Inspector of Explosives that sets out the person’s name, address, telephone number and email address, the date of the letter and the holder’s name, address and email address.

Subsection.Text: A holder of a licence, permit or certificate who wishes to verify that a director or employee of the holder, or a person seeking employment from the holder, has an approval letter must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address of both the holder and a contact person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name and date of birth of the person whose approval letter is to be verified; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that person’s written consent, witnessed and signed by a witness.

Section.Text: This Part sets out the requirements for transporting *explosives, including in transit transportation and the loading and unloading of explosives, that must be met by owners, shippers, carriers and drivers. When a small quantity of certain explosives is to be shipped, the requirements of section 190 apply. In all other cases, the requirements of sections 191 to 201 (dealing with transportation by vehicle) and sections 202 and 203 (dealing with transportation by other means) apply.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: carrier means a person who transports explosives or who provides the service of transporting explosives.
shipper means a person who arranges for a carrier, prepares the *explosives for transport and delivers them to the carrier.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A reference to the mass of an *explosive in this Part is a reference to its net quantity (the mass of the explosive excluding the mass of any packaging or container and, in the case of an *explosive article, also excluding any component that is not an *explosive substance), except in section 190 where it is a reference to its gross quantity (the mass of the explosive plus the mass of any packaging or container).

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.MarginalNote: Driver who is not a carrier
Section.Text: A driver is not subject to the requirements for carriers that are set out in this Part if the driver is an employee, or an agent or mandatary, of the carrier.

Subsection.Text: A carrier or driver is not subject to the requirements of sections 191 to 203 if they transport

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: no more than 12 kg of an explosive with the number UN 0027, BLACK POWDER (GUNPOWDER) or UN 0028, BLACK POWDER (GUNPOWDER) COMPRESSED;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no more than 150 kg of an explosive with the number

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0161, POWDER, SMOKELESS,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0186, ROCKET MOTORS,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0191, SIGNAL DEVICES, HAND,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0197, SIGNALS, SMOKE,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0276, CARTRIDGES, POWER DEVICE,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0312, CARTRIDGES, SIGNAL,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0336, FIREWORKS,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0351, ARTICLES, EXPLOSIVE, N.O.S.,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0403, FLARES, AERIAL,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0431, ARTICLES, PYROTECHNIC,

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0453, ROCKETS, LINE THROWING,

Subparagraph.Label: (xii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0499, PROPELLANT, SOLID,

Subparagraph.Label: (xiii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0501, PROPELLANT, SOLID,

Subparagraph.Label: (xiv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0503, AIR BAG INFLATORS, AIR BAG MODULES, SEAT-BELT PRETENSIONERS,

Subparagraph.Label: (xv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0505, SIGNALS, DISTRESS,

Subparagraph.Label: (xvi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0509, POWDER, SMOKELESS; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any quantity of an explosive with the number

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0012, CARTRIDGES, SMALL ARMS,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0014, CARTRIDGES, SMALL ARMS, BLANK or CARTRIDGES FOR TOOLS, BLANK,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0044, PRIMERS, CAP,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0055, CASES, CARTRIDGE, EMPTY, WITH PRIMER,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0105, FUSE, SAFETY,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0131, LIGHTERS, FUSE,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0173, RELEASE DEVICES, EXPLOSIVE,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0323, CARTRIDGES, POWER DEVICE;

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0337, FIREWORKS,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0373, SIGNAL DEVICES, HAND,

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0404, FLARES, AERIAL,

Subparagraph.Label: (xii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0405, CARTRIDGES, SIGNAL,

Subparagraph.Label: (xiii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0432, ARTICLES, PYROTECHNIC,

Subparagraph.Label: (xiv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0454, IGNITERS,

Subparagraph.Label: (xv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0506, SIGNALS, DISTRESS, or

Subparagraph.Label: (xvi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0507, SIGNALS, SMOKE.

Subsection.Text: However, the carrier and driver must ensure that the explosives are transported in a package or container that is designed, constructed, filled, closed, secured and maintained so that under normal conditions of transport the likelihood of an ignition is minimized.
A carrier of *explosives by vehicle must ensure that the portion of the vehicle that contains the explosives

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is either an intermodal container or is fully enclosed and fire resistant; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is kept locked except when the explosives are being loaded or unloaded.

Subsection.Text: The driver of the vehicle must also ensure that the portion of the vehicle that contains the explosives is kept locked except when the explosives are being loaded or unloaded.
A carrier of explosives must not transport explosives in a towed vehicle unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the explosives are in a semi-trailer attached to a truck tractor or in a fifth-wheel trailer; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the explosives are in a trailer that is part of a road train travelling over ice roads and the Minister has determined that precautions minimizing the likelihood of an ignition have been taken.

Subsection.Text: If an *explosive article or equipment that is contaminated with an *explosive substance is too large to be contained in a fully enclosed portion of a vehicle or an intermodal container, the article or equipment may be transported on a flatbed if the carrier obtains a permit to do so issued by the Minister under paragraph 7(1)(b) of the Explosives Act. The carrier and the driver must ensure that the article or equipment is secured to the flatbed and covered.

A carrier who applies for a permit to use a flatbed to transport an explosive article or equipment that is contaminated with an explosive substance must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the licence plate number and vehicle identification number of the flatbed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number of the division 1 factory licence or magazine licence that authorizes the *manufacture or storage of the explosive article or the explosive that contaminated the equipment, along with the address of the factory or magazine from which or to which the article or equipment is to be transported;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the explosive article or contaminated equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the method to be used to cover the article or equipment and to secure it to the flatbed.

Subsection.Text: If an iron or steel part of a portion of the vehicle that will contain explosives could come into contact with the explosives or their packaging during transport so as to increase the likelihood of an ignition, the carrier must ensure that the part is covered with material that will prevent the contact, unless the iron or steel is part of the means of containment for in bulk transportation of the explosives numbered

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: UN 0331, EXPLOSIVE, BLASTING, type B; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: UN 0332, EXPLOSIVE, BLASTING, type E.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Vehicle transporting more than 2 000 kg of explosives
Subsection.Text: If the vehicle will be used to transport more than 2 000 kg of explosives, the carrier must ensure that the vehicle is not gasoline-powered. The carrier must also ensure that the fuel tank and fuel lines are not located in, under, beside or over the portion of the vehicle that contains the explosives, unless there is no possible alternative and precautions that minimize the likelihood of an ignition have been taken.
The carrier must ensure that the vehicle that contains explosives is equipped with two fire extinguishers that have a rating of at least 4-A :40-B:C and are easily accessible.

The carrier must ensure that the portion of the vehicle that contains explosives does not have a heater or light — other than a heater or light installed in the portion of the vehicle occupied by the driver — unless the Minister determines that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a heater or light is required because of the properties of the explosives or the operations to be carried out in the vehicle; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of an ignition have been taken.

Subsection.Text: The carrier must ensure that the portion of the vehicle that contains explosives does not have a refrigeration or climate-control system with its own fuel tank unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the fuel system is drained and purged or removed and any battery is isolated by a cut-off switch or removed; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister determines that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the system has to be operational because of the properties of the explosives or the operations to be carried out in the vehicle, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: precautions that will minimize the likelihood of an ignition have been taken.

Subsection.Text: The carrier must ensure that the portion of the vehicle that contains explosives is protected from any component of an exhaust system that could, by heating up, increase the likelihood of an ignition.

The carrier and the driver must ensure that any dangerous goods safety marks that are required by the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations to be displayed when the vehicle is transporting explosives on a public highway are also displayed when the vehicle contains explosives and is not on a public highway.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When detonators are to be transported in a vehicle that contains other *explosives, the shipper and the carrier must ensure that no more than 20 000 detonators will be transported with the other explosives. They must also ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a vehicle that contains no more than 2 000 kg of explosives, the detonators are stowed apart from the other explosives so that an explosion of one or more detonators will not ignite any of the other explosives; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a vehicle that contains more than 2 000 kg of explosives, the detonators are stowed in a container in or compartment of the vehicle that is fully enclosed, cannot be accessed from the portion of the vehicle that contains the other explosives and will prevent the detonators from exploding during a fire for at least one hour.

Subsection.Text: The shipper and the carrier must not transport damaged or deteriorated explosives unless the Minister determines that the explosives must be transported to another location for the purpose of storing them, making them fit for use, remaking or repairing them or destroying them and that precautions that minimize the likelihood of an ignition have been taken.
The shipper and the carrier must ensure that things other than explosives are not transported with explosives unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a vehicle that contains no more than 2 000 kg of explosives, the things are stowed, or separated from, the explosives so as to minimize the likelihood of an ignition; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a vehicle that contains more than 2 000 kg of explosives, the vehicle has been authorized to transport the things by a permit issued by the Minister under paragraph 7(1)(b) of the Explosives Act and the permit is in the vehicle.

Subsection.Text: A shipper or a carrier who applies for a permit to transport things other than explosives in a vehicle that will contain explosives must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the non-explosive items to be transported with the explosives in the vehicle; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the precautions that will be taken to eliminate any possibility of an ignition.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Limit for road trains on ice roads
Subsection.Text: In the case of a road train travelling over ice roads, the carrier must ensure that no more than 20 000 kg of explosives are transported in any trailer forming part of the train.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The carrier must ensure that the vehicle to be used to transport *explosives is in sound mechanical condition and capable of safely transporting explosives.

The carrier and the driver must ensure that the portion of the vehicle containing explosives is free of grit, combustible or abrasive material, any fire-producing, spark-producing or flame-producing device and any substance that might ignite spontaneously.
The driver must ensure that the vehicle, while transporting explosives, is inspected daily to verify that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the fire extinguishers are filled and in good working order;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the electric wiring is completely insulated and firmly secured;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the fuel tank and fuel lines have no leaks;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the chassis, engine, pan and bottom of the body are clean and free from excess oil and grease;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the brakes and steering apparatus are in good condition; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the tires are not worn smooth or visibly defective.

Subsection.Text: The driver must ensure that any deficiencies found on the vehicle during an inspection are corrected before it is used to transport explosives.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The carrier must ensure that, while *explosives are being loaded into or unloaded from a vehicle, precautions that minimize the possibility of an ignition are taken. The carrier must also ensure that only activities that are necessary for loading or unloading the explosives are carried out in the immediate vicinity.

The carrier must ensure that precautions are taken that will prevent unauthorized people from having access to the explosives during loading or unloading and that will prevent any person in the immediate vicinity from doing anything that could increase the likelihood of an ignition.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Fuel, oil and tire pressure check
Subsection.Text: The carrier must ensure that the vehicle is fuelled, the oil level and tire pressure are checked and all required servicing of the vehicle is carried out before the loading of explosives begins.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Engine turned off and brakes set
Subsection.Text: During the loading or unloading of explosives, the driver must ensure that the engine is turned off and the brakes are set. However, the engine may be left running if it is needed to operate a power take-off or if cold and wind conditions could make restarting the engine difficult.
The carrier must ensure that once the loading or unloading begins, it continues without stopping until it is completed.
The carrier must ensure that packages or containers of explosives are not thrown or dropped during the loading or unloading of explosives.

The carrier must ensure that the explosives are stowed and secured in a manner that eliminates any possibility of an ignition, including ignition by another item or substance that is also being transported.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: Before delivering the *explosives to the carrier, the shipper must obtain confirmation from the intended recipient that the explosives will be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: used on the same day they are delivered and *attended in person until they are used;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: stored in a factory magazine, licensed magazine, *storage unit or dwelling in accordance with these Regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shipped immediately to the next recipient.

Subsection.Text: A carrier must not load explosives into a vehicle unless they have obtained confirmation from the intended recipient that they will be able to receive them at the time of delivery.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A person who is less than 21 years old must not drive a vehicle that is transporting more than 2 000 kg of *explosives.
A person must not smoke while they are in a vehicle that contains explosives, or while they are *attending one.

A person who is under the influence of alcohol or another performance-diminishing substance must not be in or attend a vehicle that contains explosives. However, a person who has taken a prescription drug may be in or attend a vehicle containing explosives if they have medical proof that they need the drug and that it will not impede their ability to function safely.
A driver and any person assisting the driver must not carry alcohol or another performance-diminishing substance for their personal use while transporting explosives.

The driver of a vehicle transporting explosives must not stop en route unnecessarily. If a stop is necessary, the driver must stop for no longer than required under the circumstances and must park the vehicle away from areas where people gather.
The driver must ensure that repairs that involve power tools or heat-producing devices or that could increase the likelihood of an ignition are not made to the vehicle while it contains explosives.

The driver of a vehicle transporting explosives must follow dangerous goods routes. If there are no dangerous goods routes, the driver must, if possible, avoid routes that pass through densely populated areas.

A driver of a vehicle transporting more than 2 000 kg of explosives must maintain a distance of at least 300 m between their vehicle and any other vehicle that is transporting more than 2 000 kg of explosives.
The driver of a vehicle transporting explosives must ensure that the vehicle is not towed unless the Minister or a police officer directs that it be towed because of an emergency or a breakdown.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The carrier must ensure that the driver of a vehicle transporting more than 2 000 kg of *explosives is able to rely on assistance from one or more of the following people:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an assistant who is accompanying the driver;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is in another vehicle that is not transporting explosives following the vehicle transporting explosives and with whom the driver is in constant communication;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is monitoring a two-way radio or equivalent communication system.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: If a vehicle — other than a vehicle in which a *manufacturing operation may be carried out — is used to transport the following quantity of an *explosive that is listed in subsection (2), the carrier must ensure that it is equipped with a tracking and communication system no later than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one year after these Regulations are made, if the vehicle is transporting 1 000 or more detonators;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one year after these Regulations are made, if the vehicle is transporting 15 000 kg or more of explosives;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: two years after these Regulations are made, if the vehicle is transporting at least 10 000 kg but less than 15 000 kg of explosives; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: three years after these Regulations are made if transporting at least 2 000 kg but less than 10 000 kg of explosives.

Subsection.Text: The tracking and communication system is required if the vehicle is transporting explosives that are classified under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Class 1, Division 1, 2 or 3;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Class 1, Division 4 with one of the following UN numbers:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0104, CORD DETONATING, MILD EFFECT or FUSE DETONATING, MILD EFFECT,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0237, CHARGES, SHAPED, FLEXIBLE, LINEAR,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0255, DETONATORS, ELECTRIC,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0267, DETONATORS, NON-ELECTRIC,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0289, CORD, DETONATING,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0361, DETONATOR ASSEMBLIES, NON-ELECTRIC,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0365, DETONATORS FOR AMMUNITION,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0366, DETONATORS FOR AMMUNITION,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0440, CHARGES, SHAPED,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0441, CHARGES, SHAPED,

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0445, CHARGES, EXPLOSIVE, COMMERCIAL,

Subparagraph.Label: (xii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0456, DETONATORS, ELECTRIC,

Subparagraph.Label: (xiii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN 0500, DETONATOR ASSEMBLIES, NON-ELECTRIC; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Class 1, Division 5 or 6.

Subsection.Text: The tracking and communication system must allow the person who is monitoring the system to locate the vehicle at all times and must allow the driver and the person to communicate with one another.
The carrier must ensure that a person is monitoring the tracking and communication system at all times while the explosives are being transported and will notify the police in case of an emergency.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The carrier and the driver of a vehicle that contains *explosives must ensure that it is *attended in person when it is not at a licensed factory.
However, up to 25 kg of high explosives (type E) and up to 100 detonators (type I) may be left unattended in a vehicle if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the explosives have been removed from a factory magazine or licensed magazine for a specific purpose set out in their authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the explosives are stored in a *storage unit that has been serviced at the factory or magazine and is bolted or welded to the vehicle or, if the explosives are perforating guns, the guns are securely locked to the vehicle;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: no other item or substance that could increase the likelihood of an ignition is in the vehicle;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a device or system is in place that will ensure that the vehicle is immobilized and that an alarm will alert the driver if an attempt is made to steal the explosives, tamper with the storage unit or tamper with or steal the vehicle; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if it is parked overnight, the vehicle is parked at least 30 m from any dwelling, highway or railway line and any place where flammable substances (for example, gasoline pumps, propane tanks or above-ground storage tanks for a flammable liquid or flammable gas) are stored.

Subsection.Text: When the specific purpose for which the explosives were removed has been carried out or abandoned, the carrier and driver must ensure that any explosives remaining in the vehicle are stored in a factory or licensed magazine as soon as the circumstances permit.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: If a vehicle that contains *explosives is to be parked overnight, the driver must park at a place where there is no open flame, match or any other thing that could increase the likelihood of an ignition. The distance between the parking place and any dwelling, any place where flammable substances (for example, gasoline pumps, propane tanks or above-ground storage tanks for flammable liquid or flammable gas) are stored and any area where people are likely to gather must be great enough to eliminate any possibility of harm to people and property in case of an ignition.
The driver must ensure that the parked vehicle is *attended.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The driver of a vehicle that contains *explosives and is involved in an accident or incident that is likely to delay the delivery of the explosives must, as soon as the circumstances permit, notify the police and the carrier of the accident or incident and the delay.

The carrier must, as soon as the circumstances permit, report the accident or incident to an inspector. The carrier must ensure that any damaged explosives are transported as soon as the circumstances permit to any location that the Minister designates and any undamaged explosives are transported to their destination or to a safe and secure location as soon as the circumstances permit.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.TitleText: Transporting Explosives in a Means of Transport Other Than a Vehicle

Subsection.Text: The carrier must ensure that, while *explosives are being loaded into or unloaded from a means of transport other than a vehicle, precautions that minimize the likelihood of an ignition are taken. The carrier must also ensure that only activities that are necessary for loading or unloading the explosives are carried out in the immediate vicinity.

The carrier must ensure that precautions that prevent unauthorized people from having access to the explosives during loading or unloading are taken, as well as precautions that prevent any person in the immediate vicinity from doing anything that might increase the likelihood of an ignition.
The carrier must ensure that packages or containers of explosives are not thrown or dropped during the loading or unloading of the explosives.

The carrier must ensure that the explosives are stowed and secured in a manner that eliminates any possibility of an ignition, including ignition by another item or substance that is also being transported.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: Before delivering the *explosives to the carrier, the shipper must obtain confirmation from the intended recipient of the explosives that the explosives will be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: used on the same day they are delivered and *attended until they are used;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: stored in a factory magazine, licensed magazine, *storage unit or dwelling in accordance with these Regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shipped immediately to the next recipient.

Subsection.Text: A carrier must not load explosives into a means of transport other than a vehicle unless they have obtained confirmation from the intended recipient that they will be able to receive them at the time of delivery.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.Label: PART 10
Heading.TitleText: Military Explosives and Law Enforcement Explosives

Section.Text: This Part authorizes the acquisition, storage and sale of military explosives (type D) and law enforcement explosives (type D) and sets out the rules for sellers and users.
The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: law enforcement agency means a police force, the Correctional Service of Canada or the Canada Border Services Agency. (organisme d’application de la loi)
licence means a licence that authorizes the storage of the military explosives or law enforcement explosives to be sold or acquired. (licence)
user means a person, or a law enforcement agency, that acquires military explosives or law enforcement explosives for use. (utilisateur)

Section.Text: A seller may acquire, store and sell military explosives or law enforcement explosives if they hold a licence. A seller who acquires military explosives or law enforcement explosives must comply with this Part.

Subsection.Text: A seller must store their military explosives and law enforcement explosives in the magazine specified in their licence.
A seller must not display military explosives or law enforcement explosives for sale.
A seller may sell military explosives or law enforcement explosives only to a buyer who holds a licence.
A seller must not sell more military explosives or law enforcement explosives to a buyer than the buyer is authorized by their licence to store.
Despite subsection (1), a seller may sell the following explosives to the following buyers even if the buyer is unlicensed:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: military explosives and law enforcement explosives to the Department of National Defence and to any armed forces cooperating with the Canadian Forces; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: military explosives, hazard category PE 3 or PE 4, and law enforcement explosives, hazard category PE 3 or PE 4, to a police force operating in Canada.

Section.Text: A seller must keep a record of every sale of military explosives or law enforcement explosives in a secure location for two years after the date of the sale. The record must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the individual who bought the explosives and, if applicable, the name of the entity for which the explosives were acquired;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a licensed buyer, the licence number and expiry date;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name of each explosive sold and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of explosives sold under each *product name; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the sale.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A user may acquire and store military explosives or law enforcement explosives if they hold a licence. A user who acquires military explosives or law enforcement explosives must comply with subsection (2).
A user must store their military explosives and law enforcement explosives in the magazine specified in their licence.

Despite subsection 210(1), a law enforcement agency may acquire and store military explosives, hazard category PE 3 or PE 4, or law enforcement explosives, hazard category PE 3 or PE 4, even if the agency is unlicensed. A law enforcement agency that acquires such explosives must comply with subsection (2).

The explosives must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition, in a manner that prevents them from being stolen and ensures that access to them is limited to people authorized by the law enforcement agency.

Section.Text: This Part authorizes the acquisition, storage and sale of explosives that are used for industrial purposes and sets out the rules for sellers and users.
The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: industrial explosive means the following types of explosive:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: E.1 — blasting explosives;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: E.2 — perforating explosives;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: E.3 — special-application explosives;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: I — initiation systems; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: P.1 — black powder and hazard category PE 1 black powder substitutes, when they are used in mining, quarrying, construction or avalanche control. (explosif industriel)

Definition.Text: licence means a licence that is issued by the Minister and authorizes storage of the type of industrial explosive to be sold or acquired. (licence)
manufacturing certificate means a certificate that authorizes the *manufacture and storage of the type of industrial explosive to be acquired or manufactured. (certificat de fabrication)
user means a person who acquires *industrial explosives for use or conveyance. (utilisateur)

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A seller may acquire, store and sell industrial explosives if they hold a licence. A seller who acquires industrial explosives must comply with this Part.
A seller must store their industrial explosives in the magazine specified in their licence.
A seller must not display industrial explosives for sale.

Subsection.Text: A seller may sell industrial explosives only to a buyer who holds a licence or a manufacturing certificate or who is authorized by a competent provincial or territorial authority to store industrial explosives at a mine site or quarry.
A seller must not sell more industrial explosives to a buyer than the buyer is authorized by their licence, certificate or provincial or territorial authorization to store.
A seller must mark the number of the buyer’s licence, manufacturing certificate or provincial or territorial authorization in a clear and permanent manner

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the outer packaging or container of the *explosives if the outer packaging or the container is sealed; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the inner packaging of each explosive or each reel of detonating cord if the outer packaging or the container is not sealed.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply to intermediate bulk containers or containers holding explosives in bulk.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A seller must keep a record of each sale of industrial explosives for two years after the date of the sale. The record must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the buyer’s name and address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of the buyer’s licence, certificate or authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the type, *product name and dimensions of each explosive sold and name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of explosives sold under each *product name; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the sale.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A seller must ensure that any packaging or container that has been used for industrial explosives is not reused unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is in good condition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it contains no explosive residue;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it is reused for the same type of explosive that it previously contained; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all information on the packaging or container remains accurate.

Subsection.Text: A seller must ensure that any packaging or container that has been used for a nitroglycerine-based explosive or any other explosive that is *manufactured from a liquid explosive is destroyed (for example, by breaking the packaging or container) as soon as the circumstances permit after the packaging or container is emptied.

A seller must ensure that any packaging or container that is not in good condition when it is emptied of explosives is destroyed (for example, by breaking the packaging or container) as soon as the circumstances permit.
Subsection (3) does not apply to intermediate bulk containers or containers holding explosives in bulk.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A user may acquire and store industrial explosives if they hold a licence or a manufacturing certificate or are authorized by a competent provincial or territorial authority to store such explosives at a mine site or quarry. A user who acquires industrial explosives must comply with this Part.

A user who acquires industrial explosives that are in a sealed container or sealed outer packaging must, after opening the packaging or container, mark the number of their licence, certificate or authorization in a clear and permanent manner on the inner packaging of each explosive or on each reel of detonating cord.

Subsection.Text: A user who holds a licence must store their industrial explosives in the magazine specified in their licence.
A user who holds a licence or a manufacturing certificate must ensure that their industrial explosives are *attended when they are at a site of use.
Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply to industrial explosives that are stored on offshore platforms for use in offshore oil or gas wells.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A user must ensure that any packaging or container that has been used for industrial explosives is not reused unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is in good condition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it contains no explosive residue;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it is reused for the same type of explosive that it previously contained; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all information on the packaging or container remains accurate.

Subsection.Text: A user must ensure that any packaging or container that has been used for a nitroglycerine-based explosive or any other explosive that is manufactured from a liquid explosive is destroyed so that it cannot be reused (for example, by breaking the packaging or container) as soon as the circumstances permit after the packaging or container is emptied.

A user must ensure that any packaging or container that is not in good condition when it is emptied of explosives is destroyed so that it cannot be reused (for example, by breaking the packaging or container) as soon as the circumstances permit.
Subsection (3) does not apply to intermediate bulk containers or containers holding explosives in bulk.

Section.Text: This Part authorizes the acquisition, storage and sale of blank cartridges for tools (type C.2). Division 1 sets out the rules for sellers, while Division 2 sets out the rules for users.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: distributor means a person who sells blank cartridges for tools to other distributors or to retailers, whether or not they sell to users. (distributeur)
licence means a licence that authorizes the storage of blank cartridges for tools. (licence)
retailer means a person, other than a distributor, who sells blank cartridges for tools. (détaillant)
seller means a distributor or a retailer. (vendeur)
user means a person who acquires blank cartridges for tools for use. (utilisateur)

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Part, blank cartridges for tools are stored in a sales establishment, including a dwelling, if they are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: inside the sales establishment, whether or not they are in a *storage unit or displayed for sale;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: outside the sales establishment in a storage unit that is used in operating the establishment; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in a licensed magazine that is either inside or outside the establishment.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A distributor may acquire, store and sell blank cartridges for tools if they hold a licence. A distributor who acquires blank cartridges for tools must comply with this Division.
A retailer may acquire, store and sell blank cartridges for tools, whether or not they hold a licence. A retailer who acquires blank cartridges for tools must comply with this Division.
A seller who holds a licence must store their blank cartridges for tools in the magazine specified in their licence.
A retailer who does not hold a licence must store their blank cartridges for tools in a sales establishment and must ensure that the requirements of sections 229 to 231 are met.
Blank cartridges for tools must not be displayed for sale in a dwelling.
Blank cartridges for tools that are displayed for sale in a sales establishment other than a dwelling must be kept behind a sales counter or locked up (for example, in a cabinet).
Only people authorized by the retailer may have access to the area behind a sales counter.
In the case of a sales establishment that is a dwelling, no more than 50 000 blank cartridges for tools may be stored at any one time.

In the case of a sales establishment that is not a dwelling, no more than 150 000 blank cartridges for tools may be stored at any one time, including those that are displayed for sale. Blank cartridges for tools that are not displayed for sale must be stored in a *storage unit.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When blank cartridges for tools are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition, in a manner that protects them from theft and ensures that access to them is limited to people authorized by the retailer.
When blank cartridges for tools are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than blank cartridges for tools may be stored in the storage unit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
