Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A seller must not sell more blank cartridges for tools to a licensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by their licence to store.
A seller must not sell more blank cartridges for tools to an unlicensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by this Part to store.

Section.Text: A retailer may sell blank cartridges for tools only to users.
A user may acquire and store blank cartridges for tools, whether or not they hold a licence. A user who acquires blank cartridges for tools must comply with this Division.

Subsection.Text: A user who holds a licence must store their blank cartridges for tools in the magazine specified in their licence.
A user who does not hold a licence must store their blank cartridges for tools in a dwelling or a *storage unit and must ensure that the storage requirements of sections 236 and 237 are met.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: No more than 50 000 blank cartridges for tools may be stored at any one time.

Subsection.Text: When blank cartridges for tools are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition, in a manner that protects them from theft and ensures that access to them is limited to people authorized by the user.
When blank cartridges for tools are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than blank cartridges for tools may be stored in the storage unit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: This Part authorizes the acquisition, storage and sale of special purpose explosives. Division 1 sets out the rules for sellers and users of low-hazard special purpose explosives (type S.1: for example, highway flares, personal distress flares, bird scaring cartridges and fire extinguisher cartridges). Division 2 sets out the rules for sellers and users of high-hazard special purpose explosives (type S.2: for example, reactive targets, explosive bolts and cable cutters). Division 3 deals with the destruction of expired marine flares (type S.1 or S.2).

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: distributor means a person who sells special purpose explosives to other distributors or to retailers, whether or not they sell to users.
retailer means a person, other than a distributor, who sells special purpose explosives.
seller means a distributor or a retailer.
user means a person who acquires special purpose explosives for use.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Part, special purpose explosives are stored in a sales establishment if the explosives are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: inside the sales establishment, whether in a *storage unit or displayed for sale;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: outside the sales establishment in a storage unit that is used in operating the establishment; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in a licensed magazine that is either inside or outside the establishment.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A reference to the mass of a special purpose explosive in this Part is a reference to its gross mass (the mass of the explosives plus the mass of any packaging or container).
In this Division, licence means a licence that authorizes the storage of low-hazard special purpose explosives.

Subsection.Text: A distributor may acquire, store and sell low-hazard special purpose explosives if they hold a licence. A distributor who acquires low-hazard special purpose explosives must comply with this Division.

A retailer may acquire, store and sell low-hazard special purpose explosives, whether or not they hold a licence. A retailer who acquires low-hazard special purpose explosives must comply with this Division.
A seller who holds a licence must store their low-hazard special purpose explosives in the magazine specified in their licence.

A retailer who does not hold a licence must store their low-hazard special purpose explosives in a sales establishment other than a dwelling and ensure that the requirements of sections 244 to 246 are met.
Only highway flares, marine flares and personal distress flares may be displayed for sale.
No more than 1 000 kg of flares may be displayed for sale at any one time.
Flares that are displayed for sale must be kept behind a sales counter or locked up (for example, in a cabinet) unless the flares are in consumer packs.
Only people authorized by the retailer may have access to the area behind a sales counter.

Flares that are displayed for sale must be separated into lots of 25 kg or less. Each lot must be separated from the other lots by a fire break. The lots must be kept away from flammable substances and sources of ignition.

No more than 1 000 kg of low-hazard special purpose explosives may be stored in a sales establishment at any one time, including those that are displayed for sale. If the sales establishment is located in a building that contains a dwelling, no more than 100 kg may be stored in the establishment at any one time, including explosives that are displayed for sale.
Low-hazard special purpose explosives that are not displayed for sale must be stored in a *storage unit.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: When low-hazard special purpose explosives are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be constructed from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than special purpose explosives may be stored in the storage unit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A seller must not sell low-hazard special purpose explosives from a dwelling.

Subsection.Text: A seller must not sell more low-hazard special purpose explosives to a licensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by their licence to store.
A seller must not sell more low-hazard special purpose explosives to an unlicensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by this Division to store.

Section.Text: A retailer may sell low-hazard special purpose explosives only to a user.

A seller must keep a record of every sale of more than 100 kg of low-hazard special purpose explosives. The record must be kept for two years after the date of the sale and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the buyer’s name and address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a licensed buyer, the licence number and expiry date;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name of each explosive sold and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of explosives sold under each *product name; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the sale.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A user may acquire and store low-hazard special purpose explosives, whether or not they hold a licence. A user who acquires low-hazard special purpose explosives must comply with this Division.

Subsection.Text: A user who holds a licence must store their low-hazard special purpose explosives in the magazine specified in their licence.
A user who does not hold a licence must store their low-hazard special purpose explosives in a dwelling or a *storage unit and ensure that the requirements of sections 253 and 254 are met.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: No more than 1 000 kg of low-hazard special purpose explosives may be stored at any one time, of which no more than 40 kg may be stored in a dwelling.

Subsection.Text: When low-hazard special purpose explosives are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition, in a manner that protects them from theft and ensures that access to them is limited to people authorized by the user.
When low-hazard special purpose explosives are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than special purpose explosives may be stored in the storage unit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: In this Division, licence means a licence that authorizes the storage of high-hazard special purpose explosives.
A seller may acquire, store and sell high-hazard special purpose explosives if they hold a licence. A seller who acquires high-hazard special purpose explosives must comply with this Division.
A seller must store their high-hazard special purpose explosives in the magazine specified in their licence.
A seller must not display high-hazard special purpose explosives for sale.

Subsection.Text: A seller must not sell more high-hazard special purpose explosives to a licensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by their licence to store.
A seller must not sell more high-hazard special purpose explosives to an unlicensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by this Division to store.

Section.Text: A retailer may sell high-hazard special purpose explosives only to a user.
A seller must keep a record of every sale of high-hazard special purpose explosives for two years after the date of the sale. The record must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the buyer’s name and address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a licensed buyer, the licence number and expiry date;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name of each explosive sold and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of explosives sold under each *product name; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the sale.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A user may acquire and store high-hazard special purpose explosives, whether or not they hold a licence. A user who acquires high-hazard special purpose explosives must comply with this Division.

Subsection.Text: A user who holds a licence must store their high-hazard special purpose explosives in the magazine specified in their licence.
A user who does not hold a licence must store their high-hazard special purpose explosives in a *storage unit and ensure that the requirements of sections 264 and 265 are met.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: No more than 20 kg of high-hazard special purpose explosives may be stored at any one time.
When high-hazard special purpose explosives are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than special purpose explosives may be stored in the storage unit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A distributor who sells marine flares, whether low-hazard or high-hazard, must implement the marine flare disposal plan included in their licence application.
A distributor must accept the return of any marine flares sold by them that have expired.

The distributor must store any expired marine flares that are returned to them in the magazine specified in their licence and destroy them in a manner that does not increase the likelihood of an accidental ignition during or after the destruction.

If any expired marine flares are returned during a calendar year, the distributor must submit to the Chief Inspector of Explosives, by March 31 of the following year, a report that sets out the number of each type returned, whether low-hazard or high-hazard, and the number of each type destroyed, during the calendar year.

Heading.Label: PART 14
Heading.TitleText: Small Arms Cartridges, Propellant Powder and Percussion Caps

Section.Text: This Part authorizes the acquisition, storage and sale of small arms cartridges and the *manufacture of small arms cartridges and black powder cartouches. Division 1 sets out the rules for sellers and users of commercially manufactured small arms cartridges (type C.1). It also sets out rules for storing small arms cartridges that are manufactured under Division 2. Division 2 sets out the rules for sellers and users of propellant powder (type P) and percussion caps (also known as primer) (type C.3) and for manufacturers of small arms cartridges and black powder cartouches.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: black powder means an explosive classified as type P.1.
propellant powder means black powder and smokeless powder.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: cartouche pour armes de petit calibre

Definition.Text: small arms cartridge means a cartridge that is designed to be used in small arms, has a calibre of no more than 19.1 mm (.75 calibre), is fitted with centre or rim fire priming and contains a propelling charge, with or without a solid projectile. It includes a shotgun shell of any gauge.
smokeless powder means an explosive classified as type P.2.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Part, small arms cartridges, propellant powder and percussion caps are stored in a sales establishment, including a dwelling, if they are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: inside the sales establishment, whether or not they are in a *storage unit or displayed for sale;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: outside the sales establishment in a storage unit that is used in operating the establishment; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in a licensed magazine that is either inside or outside the establishment.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.MarginalNote: Quantity of cartridges, powder or cartouches
Section.Text: A reference in this Part to the mass of a small arms cartridge, propellant powder or a black powder cartouche is a reference to its net quantity (the mass of the *explosive excluding the mass of any packaging, container, shell casing or projectile).

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Division.

Definition.Text: distributor means a person who sells small arms cartridges to other distributors or to retailers, whether or not they sell to users.
licence means a licence that authorizes the storage of small arms cartridges.
Definition.Note: Note: A licence that authorizes the storage of small arms cartridges may also authorize the storage of propellant powder, percussion caps and black powder cartouches.

Definition.Text: retailer means a person, other than a distributor, who sells small arms cartridges.
seller means a distributor or a retailer.
user means a person who acquires small arms cartridges for use.

Subsection.Text: A distributor may acquire, store and sell small arms cartridges if they hold a licence. A distributor who acquires small arms cartridges must comply with this Division.
A retailer may acquire, store and sell small arms cartridges, whether or not they hold a licence. A retailer who acquires small arms cartridges must comply with this Division.
A seller who holds a licence must store their small arms cartridges in the magazine specified in their licence.
A retailer who does not hold a licence must store their small arms cartridges in a sales establishment and must ensure that the requirements of sections 273 to 275 are met.
When a sales establishment is unlocked, small arms cartridges that are displayed for sale must be *attended, kept behind a sales counter or locked up (for example, in a cabinet).
Only people authorized by the retailer may have access to the area behind a sales counter.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: No more than 225 kg of small arms cartridges may be stored in a sales establishment at any one time, including cartridges that are displayed for sale.
Subsection.Note: Note: In accordance with section 269, the reference to 225 kg of small arms cartridges is a reference to their net quantity (the mass of the explosive excluding the mass of any packaging, container, shell casing or projectile).

Subsection.Text: Small arms cartridges that are not displayed for sale must be stored in a dwelling or a *storage unit.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When small arms cartridges are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition. People not authorized by the retailer must not be given unlimited access to the cartridges.
When small arms cartridges are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than propellant powder and percussion caps may be stored with the small arms cartridges;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: small arms cartridges, propellant powder and percussion caps must be stored separately from one another (for example, on different shelves or separated by a wooden barrier);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A seller must not sell more small arms cartridges to a licensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by their licence to store.
A seller must not sell more small arms cartridges to an unlicensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by this Division to store.

Section.Text: A retailer may sell small arms cartridges only to a user.
A user may acquire and store small arms cartridges, whether or not they hold a licence. A user who acquires small arms cartridges must comply with this Division.

Subsection.Text: A user who holds a licence must store their small arms cartridges in the magazine specified in their licence.

A user who does not hold a licence must store their small arms cartridges, including any small arms cartridges *manufactured by the user under Division 2, in a dwelling or a *storage unit and ensure that the requirements of sections 280 and 281 are met.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: No more than 225 kg of small arms cartridges may be stored at any one time.
Section.Note: Note: In accordance with section 269, the reference to 225 kg of small arms cartridges is a reference to their net quantity (the mass of the explosive excluding the mass of any packaging, container, shell casing or projectile).

Subsection.Text: When small arms cartridges are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition. People not authorized by the user must not be given unlimited access to the cartridges.
When small arms cartridges are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than propellant powder, percussion caps or black powder cartouches may be stored with the small arms cartridges;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: small arms cartridges, propellant powder, percussion caps and black powder cartouches must be stored separately from one another (for example, on different shelves or separated by a wooden barrier);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 2
Heading.TitleText: Propellant Powder and Percussion Caps and the Manufacture of Small Arms Cartridges and Black Powder Cartouches

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this Division.

Definition.Text: distributor means a person who sells propellant powder or percussion caps to other distributors or to retailers, whether or not they sell to users.

licence means a licence issued under the Explosives Act that authorizes the storage of the *explosive, whether propellant powder, percussion caps or black powder cartouches, that are to be sold, acquired or *manufactured.
Definition.Note: Note: A licence that authorizes the storage of propellant powder, percussion caps or black powder cartouches may also authorize the storage of small arms cartridges.

Definition.Text: retailer means a person, other than a distributor, who sells propellant powder or percussion caps.
seller means a distributor or a retailer.
user means a person who acquires propellant powder or percussion caps for use.

Subsection.Text: A reference in this Division to a mass of propellant powder does not include propellant powder that is in a small arms cartridge.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A distributor may acquire, store and sell propellant powder and percussion caps if they hold a licence. A distributor who acquires propellant powder or percussion caps must comply with this Division.

A retailer may acquire, store and sell propellant powder and percussion caps, whether or not they hold a licence. A retailer who acquires propellant powder or percussion caps must comply with this Division.
A seller who holds a licence must store their propellant powder and percussion caps in the magazine specified in their licence.
A seller must not store propellant powder and percussion caps in the same magazine.

Section.Text: A retailer who does not hold a licence must store their propellant powder and percussion caps in a sales establishment and must ensure that the requirements of sections 286 to 288 are met.

Subsection.Text: No more than 12 kg of propellant powder, of which no more than 500 g may be black powder, may be displayed for sale.
Propellant powder that is displayed for sale must be in a container that holds no more than 500 g.
No more than 10 000 percussion caps may be displayed for sale.
Percussion caps that are displayed for sale must be in their original packaging.
Propellant powder and percussion caps that are displayed for sale must be kept behind a counter or locked up (for example, in a cabinet).
Only people authorized by the retailer may have access to the area behind a sales counter.
Propellant powder and percussion caps that are not displayed for sale must be stored in a dwelling or a *storage unit.
Percussion caps must be stored in their original packaging.
Subsection.Note: Note: These Regulations do not limit the number of percussion caps that may be stored in their original packaging in a dwelling or a storage unit.

Subsection.Text: The maximum quantity of propellant powder that may be stored at any one time in a detached dwelling, or in a storage unit attached to a detached dwelling, is 25 kg of which no more than 10 kg may be black powder.

The maximum quantity of smokeless powder that may be stored at any one time in a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, or in a storage unit attached to a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 20 kg, if all the smokeless powder is in containers that hold no more than 1 kg; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 5 kg, if any of the smokeless powder is in a container that holds more than 1 kg.

Subsection.Text: The maximum quantity of black powder that may be stored at any one time in a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, or in a storage unit attached to a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 1 kg, if the black powder is in containers; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 3 kg less any quantity that is in containers, if the black powder is in small arms cartridges or black powder cartouches.

Subsection.Text: The maximum quantity of propellant powder that may be stored at any one time in storage units that are not attached to a dwelling, whether in a single unit or in several, is 75 kg.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When propellant powder or percussion caps are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition. People not authorized by the retailer must not be given unlimited access to the propellant powder or percussion caps.
When propellant powder or percussion caps are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than small arms cartridges may be stored with the propellant powder or percussion caps;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: propellant powder, percussion caps and small arms cartridges must be stored separately from one another (for example, on different shelves or separated by a wooden barrier);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A seller must not transfer propellant powder from one container to another for the purpose of sale unless they hold a licence that authorizes them to do so.

A retailer who does not hold a licence must, before beginning to sell propellant powder, send the Chief Inspector of Explosives a written notice that sets out their name, address, telephone number, fax number and email address and the date on which they will begin to sell. If such a retailer stops selling propellant powder, they must send the Chief Inspector a written notice to that effect as soon as the circumstances permit.
A seller may sell percussion caps only if they are in their original packaging.

Subsection.Text: A seller must not sell more propellant powder or percussion caps to a licensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by their licence to store.
A seller must not sell more propellant powder to an unlicensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by this Division to store.

Section.Text: A retailer may sell propellant powder or percussion caps only to a user.

Subsection.Text: Before selling propellant powder to a buyer, the seller must require the buyer to establish their identity by providing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a piece of identification, issued by the Government of Canada or a provincial, municipal or foreign government, that bears a photograph of the buyer; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two pieces of identification, each of which sets out the buyer’s name, at least one of which is issued by the Government of Canada or a provincial, municipal or foreign government and at least one of which sets out the buyer’s address.

Subsection.Text: If the buyer provides a piece of identification that bears a photograph, the seller must ensure, before selling the propellant powder, that the photograph is that of the buyer.

Section.Text: A seller must keep a record of each sale of propellant powder for two years after the date of the sale. The record must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the buyer’s name and address or the number of their licence, if any, issued under the Firearms Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a licensed buyer, the licence number and expiry date;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the type and *product name of the powder sold, the size of the container in which it was sold and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of powder sold under each *product name; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the sale.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A user may acquire and store propellant powder and percussion caps, whether or not they hold a licence. A user may *manufacture small arms cartridges and black powder cartouches for their own personal use and may store them, whether or not they hold a licence. A user who acquires propellant powder or percussion caps or manufactures small arms cartridges or black powder cartouches must comply with this Division.
Section.Note: Note: Part 5 regulates the commercial manufacture of small arms cartridges.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A user who holds a licence must store their propellant powder, percussion caps and black powder cartouches in the magazine specified in their licence.
A user must not store propellant powder and percussion caps in the same magazine.

Section.Text: A user who does not hold a licence must store their propellant powder, percussion caps and black powder cartouches in a dwelling or a *storage unit and ensure that the requirements of sections 299 to 304 are met.
Section.Note: Note: Subsection 279(2) provides that users must store small arms cartridges in accordance with sections 280 and 281.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: Percussion caps must be stored in their original packaging.
Subsection.Note: Note: These Regulations do not limit the number of percussion caps that may be stored in their original packaging in a dwelling or a *storage unit.

Subsection.Text: Smokeless powder must be stored in its original container or in small arms cartridges.
Black powder must be stored in its original container, in small arms cartridges or in black powder cartouches.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The maximum quantity of propellant powder that may be stored by a user at any one time under sections 301 to 303 is reduced by the quantity of any propellant powder that the user is storing under section 375 and any quantity that they are storing under section 389.

The maximum quantity of propellant powder that may be stored at any one time in a detached dwelling, or in a *storage unit attached to a detached dwelling, is 25 kg of which no more than 10 kg may be black powder.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The maximum quantity of smokeless powder that may be stored at any one time in a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, or in a storage unit attached to a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 20 kg, if all the smokeless powder is in containers that hold no more than 1 kg; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 5 kg, if any of the smokeless powder is in a container that holds more than 1 kg.

Subsection.Text: The maximum quantity of black powder that may be stored at any one time in a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, or in a storage unit attached to a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 1 kg, if the black powder is in containers; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 3 kg less any quantity that is in containers, if the black powder is in small arms cartridges or black powder cartouches.

Section.Text: The maximum quantity of propellant powder that may be stored at any one time in *storage units that are not attached to a dwelling, whether in a single unit or in several, is 75 kg.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When propellant powder, percussion caps or black power cartouches are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition. People not authorized by the user must not be given unlimited access to the propellant powder, percussion caps or black powder cartouches.
When propellant powder, percussion caps or black powder cartouches are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than small arms cartridges may be stored with the propellant powder, percussion caps or black powder cartouches;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: propellant powder, percussion caps, small arms cartridges and black powder cartouches must be stored separately from one another (for example, on different shelves or separated by a wooden barrier);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A person who *manufactures small arms cartridges or black powder cartouches must be at least 18 years old or under the supervision of a person who is at least 18 years old.
A person who manufactures small arms cartridges or black powder cartouches must ensure that the following requirements are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the place where the manufacturing is carried out must have a means of escape that will permit all people in the place to leave it quickly and easily in an emergency;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of an ignition must be taken;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all containers of explosives must be labelled to identify their contents and must be kept closed when not in use;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: no more than 2 kg of smokeless powder may be within 1 m of the loading area;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: no more than 500 g of black powder may be within 1 m of the loading area;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the small arms cartridges must not include an incendiary or similar military component or device; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: no more than 150 percussion caps may be kept in the loader mechanism of the reloading equipment.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of transporting small arms cartridges or black powder cartouches manufactured under this Division, the small arms cartridges are classified as UN 0012 and the black powder cartouches are classified as UN 0014.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: This Part authorizes the acquisition, storage and sale of rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters. Division 1 sets out the rules for sellers and users of model rocket motors (type R.1), model rocket motor reloading kits (type R.1) and igniters for model rocket motors (type R.3). Division 2 sets out the rules for sellers and users of high-power rocket motors (type R.2), high-power rocket motor reloading kits (type R.2) and igniters for high-power rocket motors (type R.3).

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: distributor means a person who sells rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters to other distributors or to retailers, whether or not they sell to users.
licence means a licence that authorizes storage of the type of rocket motor, reloading kit or igniter to be sold or acquired.

high-power rocket motor means a recreational rocket motor with an impulse that is produced by combustion of a solid propellent and exceeds 160 newton-seconds but does not exceed 40 960 newton-seconds.
model rocket motor means a recreational rocket motor with an impulse that is produced by combustion of a solid propellent and does not exceed 160 newton-seconds.
reloading kit means a package that contains a solid propellant and other components that are designed to be used in a reloadable rocket motor.
retailer means a person, other than a distributor, who sells rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters.
seller means a distributor or a retailer.
user means a person who acquires rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters for use.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Part, rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters are stored in a sales establishment, including a dwelling, if they are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: inside the sales establishment, whether or not they are in a *storage unit or displayed for sale;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: outside the sales establishment in a storage unit that is used in operating the establishment; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in a licensed magazine that is either inside or outside the establishment.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A reference to the mass of a rocket motor or reloading kit in this Part is a reference to its gross mass (the mass of the motor or kit plus the mass of any packaging or container).

In this Division, unless otherwise indicated, a reference to a rocket motor, a reloading kit or an igniter is a reference to a model rocket motor, a reloading kit for a model rocket motor or an igniter for a model rocket motor.

Subsection.Text: A distributor may acquire, store and sell rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters if they hold a licence. A distributor who acquires rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters must comply with this Division.

A retailer may acquire, store and sell rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters, whether or not they hold a licence. A retailer who acquires rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters must comply with this Division.
A seller who holds a licence must store their rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters in the magazine specified in their licence.
A retailer who does not hold a licence must store their rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters in a sales establishment and must ensure that the requirements of sections 312 to 315 are met.
Rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters must not be displayed for sale in a dwelling.
In the case of a sales establishment that is not a dwelling, no more than 25 kg of rocket motors and reloading kits (combined quantity) and no more than 300 igniters may be displayed for sale.

Rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters that are displayed for sale must be kept behind a sales counter or locked up (for example, in a cabinet) unless they are in consumer packs that meet the requirements of section 313.
Only people authorized by the retailer may have access to the area behind a sales counter.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Separation of motors, kits and igniters
Subsection.Text: When displayed for sale, rocket motors and reloading kits that are not in consumer packs must be separated by a fire break, or kept at least 1 m , from igniters that are not in consumer packs.

Section.Text: For the purposes of this Division, a consumer pack must meet the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it must be of sufficient strength to withstand normal handling;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it must be designed so that it prevents a person who is handling it from being able to ignite the rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters it contains; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it must be designed so that it prevents any shifting of the rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters during handling or transportation.

Subsection.Text: No more than 200 kg of rocket motors and reloading kits (combined quantity) and no more than 2 500 igniters may be stored at any one time, including those that are displayed for sale.
Rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters that are not displayed for sale must be stored in a dwelling or a *storage unit.
A model rocket in which a motor has been installed must not be stored.
Rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters must not be exposed to heat or dampness that could cause them to deteriorate.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition, in a manner that protects them from theft and ensures that access to them is limited to people authorized by the retailer.
When rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be constructed from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters may be stored in the storage unit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: if the rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters are not in consumer packs, the motors and kits must be stored separately from the igniters (for example, on different shelves or separated by a wooden barrier);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A seller must not sell more rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters to a licensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by their licence to store.
A seller must not sell more rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters to an unlicensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by this Division to store.

Section.Text: A retailer may sell rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters only to a user.

Subsection.Text: A user who is at least 18 years old may acquire and store rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters, whether or not they hold a licence. A user who acquires rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters must comply with this Division.

A user who is at least 12 years old may acquire and store single use rocket motors with an impulse that does not exceed 80 newton-seconds and igniters for those motors without a licence. A user who acquires such motors or igniters must comply with this Division.
A user who holds a licence must store their rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters in the magazine specified in their licence.
A user who does not hold a licence must store their rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters in a dwelling or a *storage unit and must ensure that the requirements of sections 320 and 321 are met.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: No more than 200 kg of rocket motors and reloading kits (combined quantity) and no more than 2 500 igniters may be stored at any one time. If high-power rocket motors or reloading kits for high-power rocket motors are stored with rocket motors or reloading kits, the combined quantity must not exceed 200 kg. If igniters for high-power rocket motors are stored with igniters, the combined quantity must not exceed 2 500.
A user who is less than 18 years old may store no more than 6 single use rocket motors with an impulse that does not exceed 80 newton-seconds, and no more than 10 igniters.
Rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters must be stored in a dwelling or a *storage unit.
A model rocket in which the motor has been installed must not be stored.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition, in a manner that protects them from theft and ensures that access to them is limited to people authorized by the user.
When rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than high-power rocket motors and reloading kits and igniters for high-power rocket motors may be stored with the rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: if the rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters, and any high-power rocket motors or reloading kits and igniters for high-power rocket motors, are not in consumer packs, the motors and kits must be stored separately from the igniters (for example, on different shelves or separated by a wooden barrier);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: In this Division, unless otherwise indicated, a reference to a rocket motor, a reloading kit or an igniter is a reference to a high-power rocket motor, a reloading kit for a high-power rocket motor or an igniter for a high-power rocket motor.
A seller may acquire, store and sell rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters if they hold a licence. A seller who acquires rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters must comply with this Division.
A seller must store their rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters in the magazine specified in their licence.
A seller must not display rocket motors or reloading kits for sale.

Subsection.Text: A seller must not sell more rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters to a licensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by their licence to store.
A seller must not sell more rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters to an unlicensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by this Division to store.

Section.Text: A retailer may sell rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters only to a user.
A seller must keep a record of every sale of a rocket motor, reloading kit or igniter for two years after the date of the sale. The record must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the buyer’s name and address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a licensed buyer, the licence number and expiry date;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the type, *product name and power level of each rocket motor and each reloading kit sold and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name of each igniter sold and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the number of motors, kits and igniters sold under each *product name; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the sale.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A user may acquire and store rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters, whether or not they hold a licence. A user who acquires rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters must comply with this Division.

Subsection.Text: A user who holds a licence must store their rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters in the magazine specified in their licence.
A user who does not hold a licence must store their rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters in a dwelling or a *storage unit and ensure that the requirements of sections 331 to 333 are met.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: In the case of storage in a dwelling, no more than 10 kg of rocket motors and reloading kits (combined quantity) and no more than 40 igniters may be stored at any one time. If model rocket motors or reloading kits for model rocket motors are stored with rocket motors or reloading kits, the combined quantity must not exceed 10 kg. If igniters for model rocket motors are stored with igniters, the combined quantity must not exceed 40.

In the case of storage in a *storage unit, no more than 200 kg of rocket motors and reloading kits (combined quantity) and no more than 200 igniters may be stored at any one time. If model rocket motors or reloading kits for model rocket motors are stored with rocket motors or reloading kits, the combined quantity must not exceed 200 kg. If igniters for model rocket motors are stored with igniters, the combined quantity must not exceed 200.
A high-power rocket in which a motor has been installed must not be stored.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition, in a manner that protects them from theft and ensures that access to them is limited to people authorized by the user.
When rocket motors, reloading kits or igniters are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than model rocket motors and reloading kits and igniters for model rocket motors may be stored with the rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: if the rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters, and any model rocket motors or reloading kits or igniters for model rocket motors, are not in consumer packs, the motors and kits must be stored separately from the igniters (for example, on different shelves or separated by a wooden barrier);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: Rocket motors, reloading kits and igniters must be *attended when they are not in storage.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: This Part authorizes the acquisition, storage and sale of consumer fireworks (type F.1) and regulates their use. Division 1 sets out rules for sellers, while Division 2 sets out rules for users.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: distributor means a person who sells consumer fireworks to other distributors or to retailers, whether or not they sell to users.
licence means a licence that authorizes the storage of consumer fireworks.
retailer means a person, other than a distributor, who sells consumer fireworks.
seller means a distributor or a retailer.
user means a person who acquires consumer fireworks for use.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Part, consumer fireworks are stored in a sales establishment if they are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: inside the sales establishment, whether or not they are in a *storage unit or displayed for sale;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: outside the sales establishment in a storage unit that is used in operating the establishment; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in a licensed magazine that is either inside or outside the establishment.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A reference to a mass of consumer fireworks in this Part is a reference to their gross mass (the mass of the fireworks plus the mass of any packaging or container).
Except as authorized by this Part, it is prohibited for a person to use consumer fireworks.

Subsection.Text: A distributor may acquire, store and sell consumer fireworks if they hold a licence. A distributor who acquires consumer fireworks must comply with this Division.
A retailer may acquire, store and sell consumer fireworks, whether or not they hold a licence. A retailer who acquires consumer fireworks must comply with this Division.

Section.Text: A seller must not sell consumer fireworks from a dwelling.

A seller must ensure that their sales establishment has at least two unobstructed exits, that all aisles containing consumer fireworks are at least 1.2 m wide and that the aisles are not blocked at either end.

Subsection.Text: The sales establishment of a retailer who does not hold a licence may be permanent (located in a permanent structure) or temporary (located in a tent, trailer or other temporary shelter).
Whether the establishment is permanent or temporary, the retailer must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the sales establishment is protected from unauthorized access when it is not open for business; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all places where consumer fireworks are stored, whether inside or outside the establishment, must be at least 100 m from all above-ground storage tanks for flammable substances in bulk and at least 8 m from the following:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: fuel dispensers at a fuel dispensing station,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: retail propane-dispensing tanks and cylinders,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: above-ground storage tanks for flammable substances, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: dispensing facilities for compressed natural gas.

Subsection.Text: If the sales establishment is temporary, the retailer must also ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all places where consumer fireworks are stored, whether inside or outside the establishment, are at least 8 m from all flammable materials, sources of ignition, thoroughfares, buildings or other temporary sales establishments and at least 3 m from any vehicle parking area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the fireworks are*attended at all times; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the sales establishment is a tent, the tent is made from flame-retardant material.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A seller who holds a licence must store all their consumer fireworks in the magazine specified in their licence and ensure that the requirement of section 343 is met.
A retailer who does not hold a licence must store their consumer fireworks in a sales establishment other than a dwelling and ensure that the requirements of sections 343 to 349 are met.

Section.Text: Consumer fireworks may be handled by a buyer only after they have been sold, unless they are in consumer packs that meet the requirements of section 345 or in packaging or containers that comply with the safety standards for means of containment under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992.

Subsection.Text: Non-aerial fireworks (flares, fountains, snakes, ground spinners, strobe pots, wheels and ground whistles) may be displayed for sale only if they are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: kept behind a sales counter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: locked up (for example, in a cabinet);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in consumer packs that meet the requirements of section 345; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in packaging or containers that comply with the safety standards for means of containment under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992.

Subsection.Text: Aerial fireworks may be displayed for sale only if they are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: kept behind a sales counter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: locked up (for example, in a cabinet); or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in packaging or containers that comply with the safety standards for means of containment under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992.

Subsection.Text: Non-aerial and aerial fireworks may be displayed for sale only if they are displayed in accordance with section 346.

Section.Text: For the purposes of this Part, a consumer pack must meet the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it must be of sufficient strength to withstand normal handling;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it must be designed so that it prevents a person who is handling it from being able to ignite the consumer fireworks it contains; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it must be designed so that it prevents any shifting of the consumer fireworks during handling or transportation; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name of all consumer fireworks in the pack must be printed on it, along with the words “Non-aerial Fireworks/Pièces pyrotechniques non aériennes”, in a location that is clearly visible.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: When consumer fireworks are displayed for sale, the following requirements must be met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: non-aerial fireworks in consumer packs that meet the requirements of section 345 or in packaging or containers that comply with the safety standards for means of containment under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992 must be separated into lots of 100 kg or less;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: aerial fireworks in packaging or containers that comply with the safety standards for means of containment under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992 must be separated into lots of 100 kg or less;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all other fireworks, whether aerial or non-aerial, must be separated into lots of 25 kg or less;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: each lot must be separated from the other lots by a fire break;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the fireworks must be kept away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the fireworks must not be exposed to heat or dampness that might cause them to deteriorate;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the fireworks must be separated from the ceiling and from any fire prevention system by at least 0.6 m;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: only people authorized by the retailer may have access to the area behind a sales counter;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: smoking must be prohibited within 8 m of the fireworks; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the fireworks must be *attended when the sales establishment is unlocked.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: Sections 343 to 346 do not apply to sparklers and toy pistol caps.

Subsection.Text: No more than 1 000 kg of consumer fireworks may be stored in a sales establishment at any one time, including fireworks that are displayed for sale. If the sales establishment is located in a building that contains a dwelling, no more than 100 kg may be stored at any one time, including fireworks that are displayed for sale.
Consumer fireworks that are not displayed for sale must be stored in a *storage unit.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: When consumer fireworks are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be constructed from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than consumer fireworks may be stored in the storage unit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A seller must not sell more consumer fireworks to a licensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by their licence to store.
A seller must not sell more consumer fireworks to an unlicensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by this Division to store.

Section.Text: A retailer may sell only to users.

Subsection.Text: A distributor who sells consumer fireworks to a retailer must offer the retailer a copy of this Division.
A seller who sells consumer fireworks to a user must offer the user either a copy of the table at the end of this Part or a document that includes the same information.
Subsection (2) does not apply to the sale of toy pistol caps.

Section.Text: A seller must keep a record of every sale of 150 kg or more of consumer fireworks for two years after the date of the sale. The record must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the buyer’s name and address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a licensed buyer, the licence number and expiry date;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name of each firework sold and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of fireworks sold under each *product name;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a sale by a distributor, an indication of whether the fireworks were purchased for re-sale or for use; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the sale.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A user who is at least 18 years old may acquire, store and use consumer fireworks, whether or not they hold a licence. A user who acquires consumer fireworks must comply with this Division.
A user who is less than 18 years old may acquire and use toy pistol caps.
A user who holds a licence must store their consumer fireworks in the magazine specified in the licence.
A user who does not hold a licence must store their consumer fireworks in a dwelling or a *storage unit and ensure that the requirements of sections 356 and 357 are met.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The maximum quantity of consumer fireworks that may be stored at any one time in a dwelling is 10 kg.
The maximum quantity of consumer fireworks that may be stored at any one time in *storage units, whether in a single unit or in several, is 1 000 kg.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When consumer fireworks are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition, in a manner that protects them from theft and ensures that access to them is limited to people authorized by the user.
When consumer fireworks are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be constructed from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than consumer fireworks may be stored in the storage unit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When using consumer fireworks, a user must follow the instructions of the person who obtained their authorization. If there are no such instructions, the fireworks must not be used.
A user must not use an electric match to fire fireworks.
A user must not smoke, and must prohibit all others from smoking, within 8 m of the site of use of the fireworks.
A user who is under the age of 18 may use consumer fireworks if they are supervised by a person who is at least 18 years old.
A person who acquires consumer fireworks may give them to a user who is under the age of 18 if the person ensures that the user is supervised by a person who is at least 18 years old.
The supervision requirement in subsections (1) and (2) does not apply in respect of toy pistol caps.

Language.Emphasis: UTILISATION DE PIÈCES PYROTECHNIQUES À L’USAGE DES CONSOMMATEURS

entry.Language: Part 16 of the Explosives Regulations, 2013 provides additional safety rules for consumer fireworks.
La partie 16 du Règlement sur les explosifs prévoit des règles de sécurité additionnelles.

ImageGroup.AlternateText: This image illustrates the rule that follows.

entry.Language: PEOPLE UNDER 18 YEARS OLD who use fireworks must be supervised by an adult.
