LES PERSONNES DE MOINS DE 18 ANS qui utilisent des pièces pyrotechniques doivent le faire sous la surpervision d’un adulte.

ImageGroup.AlternateText: This image illustrates the rule that follows.

entry.Language: CHOOSE a wide, clear site away from all obstacles. Refer to the safety instructions on the fireworks label for minimum distances from spectators.

CHOISIR un emplacement spacieux, bien dégagé et loin de tout obstacle. Consulter les consignes de sécurité sur l’étiquette des pièces pyrotechniques pour connaître les distances minimales entre les pièces et les spectateurs.

ImageGroup.AlternateText: This image illustrates the rule that follows.

entry.Language: DO NOT FIRE IN WINDY CONDITIONS.
NE PAS METTRE À FEU LES PIÈCES PYROTECHNIQUES PAR TEMPS VENTEUX.

ImageGroup.AlternateText: This image illustrates the rule that follows.

entry.Language: READ all instructions on the fireworks. PLAN the order of firing before you begin.
LIRE toutes les instructions sur les pièces pyrotechniques. DÉTERMINER l’ordre de mise à feu avant de débuter.

ImageGroup.AlternateText: This image illustrates the rule that follows.

entry.Language: USE A GOOD FIRING BASE such as a pail filled with earth or sand.
UTILISER UNE BONNE BASE DE MISE À FEU, tel un seau, remplie de terre ou de sable.

ImageGroup.AlternateText: This image illustrates the rule that follows.

entry.Language: BURY fireworks that do not have a base HALFWAY in a container of earth or sand (such as a pail, box or wheelbarrow) unless the label on the firework indicates otherwise. Set them at a 10-degree angle, pointing away from people.

ENFOUIR À MOITIÉ les pièces pyrotechniques qui ne possèdent pas de base dans un contenant (par exemple, un seau, une boîte ou une brouette) renfermant du sable ou de la terre, sauf indication contraire sur l’étiquette. Les installer à un angle de 10 degrés et les pointer en direction opposée des spectateurs.

ImageGroup.AlternateText: This image illustrates the rule that follows.

entry.Language: NEVER try to light a firework or hold a lit firework in your hand unless the instructions of the person who obtained its authorization indicate that they are designed to be hand-held.

NE JAMAIS tenir dans la main des pièces pyrotechniques qui sont allumées ou que vous tentez d’allumer, sauf si les instructions de la personne qui a obtenu l’autorisation des pièces indiquent qu’elles sont conçues pour être tenues dans la main.

ImageGroup.AlternateText: This image illustrates the rule that follows.

entry.Language: LIGHT CAREFULLY: Always light the fuse at its tip.
ALLUMER PRUDEMMENT : toujours allumer la mèche à l’extrémité.

ImageGroup.AlternateText: This image illustrates the rule that follows.

entry.Language: KEEP WATER NEARBY: Dispose of used fireworks (including debris) in a pail of water.
GARDER DE L’EAU À PORTÉE DE LA MAIN : mettre les pièces pyrotechniques utilisées et les débris dans un seau d’eau.

ImageGroup.AlternateText: This image illustrates the rule that follows.

entry.Language: WAIT at least 30 minutes before approaching a firework that did not go off. NEVER try to RELIGHT a firework that did not go off. NEVER try to fix a firework that is defective.

ATTENDRE au moins 30 minutes avant de s’approcher d’une pièce pyrotechnique dont la mise à feu n’a pas fonctionné. NE JAMAIS tenter de RALLUMER une pièce pyrotechnique dont la mise à feu n’a pas fonctionné. NE JAMAIS tenter de réparer une pièce pyrotechnique qui est défectueuse.

ImageGroup.AlternateText: This image illustrates the rule that follows.

entry.Language: KEEP fireworks in a cool, dry, ventilated place, out of the reach of children.
CONSERVER les pièces pyrotechniques dans un endroit frais, sec, aéré et hors de la portée des enfants.

ImageGroup.AlternateText: This image illustrates the rule that follows.

entry.Language: IT IS RECOMMENDED that safety glasses be worn.
IL EST RECOMMANDÉ de porter des lunettes de sécurité.

Section.Text: This Part authorizes the acquisition, storage and sale of special effect pyrotechnics and regulates their use. Division 1 sets out rules for sellers. Division 2 sets out rules for users and other acquirers and indicates how to obtain a fireworks operator certificate.
The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: black powder means an explosive classified as type P.1.
licence means a licence that authorizes the storage of the type of pyrotechnics to be sold or acquired.
propellant powder means black powder and smokeless powder.
pyrotechnic event means an event at which special effect pyrotechnics are used and includes a film or television production in which special effect pyrotechnics are used.

special effect pyrotechnics means, in addition to any explosive classified as type F.3, the following types of explosive if they will be used to produce a special effect in a film or television production or a performance before a live audience:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: fireworks accessories (type F.4);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: black powder and hazard category PE 1 black powder substitutes (type P.1);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: smokeless powder and hazard category PE 3 black powder substitutes (type P.2);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: initiation systems (type I) (for example, blasting accessories); and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: detonating cord (type E.1).

Definition.Text: smokeless powder means an explosive classified as type P.2.
special purpose pyrotechnics means special effect pyrotechnics that are combined with a flammable liquid, solid or gas to produce custom-made special effects.
user means a person who acquires special effect pyrotechnics for use, which includes setting them up and firing them.

Section.Text: A reference to the mass of a special effect pyrotechnic in this Part is a reference to its gross mass (the mass of the pyrotechnic plus the mass of any packing or container) except in the case of propellant powder, where it is a reference to its net quantity (the mass of the powder excluding the mass of any packaging or container and, in the case of an *explosive article, also excluding any component that is not an *explosive substance).

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: Except as authorized by this Part, it is prohibited for a person to use special effect pyrotechnics.
A seller may acquire, store and sell special effect pyrotechnics if they hold a licence. A seller who acquires special effect pyrotechnics must comply with this Division.

Subsection.Text: A seller must store their special effect pyrotechnics in the magazine specified in their licence.
A seller must not store electric matches in a magazine in which other special effect pyrotechnics are stored.

Section.Text: A seller must not display special effect pyrotechnics for sale.
A seller must not transfer propellant powder from one container to another for the purpose of sale unless their licence authorizes them to do so.

Subsection.Text: A seller may sell special effect pyrotechnics only to a buyer who holds the fireworks operator certificate that is required for use of the pyrotechnics that are to be bought.
A seller may sell initiation systems or detonating cord only to a buyer who holds a licence and a fireworks operator certificate (special effects pyrotechnician — detonating cord).
Despite subsection 1, a seller may sell flash cotton, flash paper, flash string, sparkle string or propellant powder to a buyer who holds neither a licence nor a fireworks operator certificate.
A seller may sell special effect pyrotechnics to a buyer who is not a user only if the buyer holds a licence.
A seller must not sell more special effect pyrotechnics to a licensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by their licence to store.
A seller must not sell more special effect pyrotechnics to an unlicensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by this Part to store.
Before selling special effect pyrotechnics, the seller must require the buyer to establish their identity by showing either

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a piece of identification, issued by the Government of Canada or a provincial, municipal or foreign government, that bears a photograph of the user; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two pieces of identification, each of which sets out the buyer’s name, at least one of which is issued by the Government of Canada or a provincial, municipal or foreign government and at least one of which sets out the buyer’s address.

Subsection.Text: If the buyer provides a piece of identification that bears a photograph, the seller must, before selling the special effect pyrotechnics, ensure that the photograph is that of the buyer.

Section.Text: A seller must keep a record of every sale of special effect pyrotechnics for two years after the date of the sale. The record must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the buyer’s name and address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the number and expiry date of the buyer’s licence and, if applicable, the number and expiry date of the buyer’s fireworks operator certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the type and *product name of each special effect pyrotechnic sold and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of special effect pyrotechnics sold under each *product name;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a short description of the effects of any *explosive article sold;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the size of the container in which any propellant powder was sold; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the sale.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 2
Heading.TitleText: Rules for Users and Other Acquirers

Heading.Label: SUBDIVISION a
Heading.TitleText: Users without a Licence or Certificate
Flash Cotton, Flash Paper, Flash String and Sparkle String

Section.Text: A user who holds neither a fireworks operator certificate nor a licence may acquire, store and use flash cotton, flash paper, flash string and sparkle string.
A user who acquires flash cotton, flash paper, flash string or sparkle string must store it in a dwelling or a *storage unit and ensure that the requirements of sections 374, 382 and 383 are met.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: No more than 200 g of flash cotton, 1 kg of flash paper, 200 g of flash string and 200 g of sparkle string may be stored at any one time.

Heading.TitleText: Percussion Caps and Propellant Powder Used in Historical Re-enactments

Subsection.Text: A user who holds neither a fireworks operator certificate nor a licence may acquire, store and use percussion caps and propellant powder, if the caps and powder are acquired for use in original or reproduction firearms in an historical re-enactment.
A user who acquires percussion caps and propellant powder for an historical re-enactment

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: must have the written approval of the *local authority to hold the re-enactment or must be under the supervision of a person who has that approval; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: must have experience in the safe use of explosives in historical re-enactments, have completed a course on this use certified by the Minister or be under the supervision of a person who has that experience or has completed such a course.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A user must store their percussion caps and propellant powder in a dwelling or in a *storage unit and ensure that the requirements of sections 377 to 380, 382 and 383 are met.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: Percussion caps must be stored in their original packaging.
Smokeless powder must be stored in its original container or in *small arms cartridges.
Black powder must be stored in its original container, in small arms cartridges or in black powder cartouches.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.MarginalNote: Detached dwellings or site of use
Section.Text: The maximum quantity of propellant powder that may be stored at any one time in a detached dwelling, in a *storage unit attached to a detached dwelling or in a storage unit at the site of use is 25 kg, of which no more than 10 kg may be black powder.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The maximum quantity of smokeless powder that may be stored at any one time in a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, or in a *storage unit attached to a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 20 kg, if all the smokeless powder is in containers that hold no more than 1 kg; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 5 kg, if any of the smokeless powder is in a container that holds more than 1 kg.

Subsection.Text: The maximum quantity of black powder that may be stored at any one time in a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, or in a storage unit attached to a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 1 kg, if the black powder is in containers; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 3 kg less any quantity that is in containers, if the black powder is in small arms cartridges or black powder cartouches.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The maximum quantity of propellant powder that may be stored at any one time in *storage units that are not attached to a dwelling and are not at the site of use, whether in a single unit or in several, is 75 kg.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A user who holds neither a fireworks operating certificate nor a licence and who is taking a college or university course on special effect pyrotechnics that is certified by the Minister may, during their training and while under the supervision of a holder of a fireworks operator certificate (senior pyrotechnician) or a fireworks operator certificate (special effects pyrotechnician), use any special effect pyrotechnics that their supervisor is authorized to use.

Subsection.Text: When special effect pyrotechnics are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition, in a manner that protects them from theft and ensures that access to them is limited to people authorized by the user.
When special effect pyrotechnics are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than special effect pyrotechnics may be stored in the storage unit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: propellant powder, firework accessories and other special effect pyrotechnics must be stored separately from one another (for example, on different shelves or separated by a wooden partition);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When special effect pyrotechnics are stored in a *storage unit at the site of use, the unit must be made from, or lined with, a non-sparking material, marked with the words “Pyrotechnics/Pièces pyrotechniques” and kept locked. Nothing other than special effect pyrotechnics may be stored in the storage unit.
The storage unit must be kept away from other flammable substances and sources of ignition and in an area that is not accessible to the public.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A user must, when using special effect pyrotechnics, follow the instructions of the person who obtained their authorization.
A user must not use special effect pyrotechnics if they show any signs of deterioration (for example, discoloration or a vinegary smell).
A user must not use an electric match to ignite flash cotton, flash paper, flash string or sparkle string.

Section.Text: A person who does not hold a fireworks operator certificate may acquire and store special effect pyrotechnics if they hold a licence. They must store their special effect pyrotechnics in the magazine specified in their licence.
The fireworks operator certificates issued by the Minister that are required for the use of special effect pyrotechnics are the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: fireworks operator certificate (pyrotechnician);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fireworks operator certificate (senior pyrotechnician);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: fireworks operator certificate (special effects pyrotechnician);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: fireworks operator certificate (special effects pyrotechnician — detonating cord); and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: fireworks operator certificate (visitor pyrotechnician).

Subsection.Text: To obtain a fireworks operator certificate (pyrotechnician), a person must successfully complete the special effects pyrotechnics safety and legal awareness course offered by the Explosives Regulatory Division, Department of Natural Resources or a course certified as equivalent by the Minister.

To obtain a fireworks operator certificate (senior pyrotechnician), a person must have acted as a pyrotechnician for two years and must be able to safely use explosives that are classified as type F.3 and propellant powder.

To obtain a fireworks operator certificate (special effects pyrotechnician), a person must have acted as a senior pyrotechnician for two years and must be able to safely use explosives that are classified as type F.3, propellant powder and special purpose pyrotechnics.

To obtain a fireworks operators certificate (special effects pyrotechnician — detonating cord), a person must have a fireworks operator certificate (special effects pyrotechnician) and must be able to safely use initiation systems and detonating cords.

To obtain a fireworks operator certificate (visitor pyrotechnician), a person must reside outside Canada and have the necessary experience using special effect pyrotechnics to safely carry out the activities of a holder of a fireworks operator certificate (pyrotechnician).

An applicant for a fireworks operator certificate (pyrotechnician) must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, date of birth, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of any organization of pyrotechnicians to which the applicant belongs;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a photograph of the applicant taken within the previous 12 months; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: proof that the applicant has successfully completed the pyrotechnics safety and legal awareness course offered by the Explosives Regulatory Division, Department of Natural Resources or a course certified as equivalent by the Minister.

Subsection.Text: An applicant who has not completed the display fireworks safety and legal awareness course or a certified equivalent on the date their application is submitted may, within six months after that date, submit to the Chief Inspector of Explosives proof of their successful completion.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Application — senior pyrotechnician and special effects pyrotechnician
Subsection.Text: An applicant for a fireworks operator certificate (senior pyrotechnician) or a fireworks operator certificate (special effects pyrotechnician) must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, date of birth, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of any organization of pyrotechnicians to which the applicant belongs;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number and expiry date of the applicant’s fireworks operator certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a photograph of the applicant taken within the previous 12 months;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the applicant’s work journal that sets out

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the date and place of each pyrotechnic event at which the applicant has worked and the types of explosives used,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the capacity in which the applicant acted at each pyrotechnic event, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of the applicant’s supervisor at each pyrotechnic event; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: three letters of recommendation.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for one of the following certificates must provide the information and documents referred to in subsection (3) and, in addition, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for a fireworks operator certificate (senior pyrotechnician), establish that they have acted as a pyrotechnician for two years and submit a letter from a supervisor which attests that the applicant is able to safely use explosives classified as type F.3 and propellant powder;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for a fireworks operator certificate (special effects pyrotechnician), establish that they have acted as a senior pyrotechnician for two years and submit a letter from a supervisor which attests that the applicant is able to safely use explosives classified as type F.3, propellent powder and special purpose pyrotechnics; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for a fireworks operator certificate (special effects pyrotechnician — detonating cord), establish that they have acted as a special effects pyrotechnician for two years and submit a letter from a supervisor which attests that the applicant is able to safely use initiation systems and detonating cords.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for a fireworks operator certificate (visitor pyrotechnician) must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, date of birth, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of any organization of pyrotechnicians to which the applicant belongs;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a photograph of the applicant taken within the previous 12 months;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the applicant’s resumé which sets out the *pyrotechnic events at which they have used special effect pyrotechnics and the people and organizations for which they have worked;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the pyrotechnic events in which they plan to participate in Canada and the dates of the events; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the name, telephone number and number of the fireworks operator certificate of the pyrotechnician in charge at each event in which they plan to participate.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for a fireworks operator certificate or a modification to or change of a certificate must pay the applicable fees set out in Part 19.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A user may acquire and store special effect pyrotechnics, whether or not they hold a licence, if they hold the fireworks operator certificate required for use of the pyrotechnics to be acquired. However, a user who does not hold a licence must not acquire initiation systems or detonating cords. A user who acquires special effect pyrotechnics must comply with this subdivision.

Subsection.Text: A user who holds a licence must store their special effect pyrotechnics in the magazine specified in their licence.

Despite subsection (1), a user who holds a licence may store up to 500 electric matches and up to 25 kg of other special effect pyrotechnics in a dwelling or a *storage unit. A user who does so must ensure that the requirements of sections 393 to 397 are met.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A user who does not hold a licence must store their special effect pyrotechnics in a dwelling or a *storage unit and ensure that the requirements of sections 392 to 397 are met.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: No more than 500 electric matches and 25 kg of other special effect pyrotechnics may be stored at any one time.

Subsection.Text: Smokeless powder must be stored in its original container or in small arms cartridges.
Black powder must be stored in its original container, in small arms cartridges or in black powder cartouches.

Section.Text: The maximum quantity of propellant powder that may be stored at any one time in a detached dwelling, or in a *storage unit attached to a detached dwelling, is 25 kg of which no more than 10 kg may be black powder.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The maximum quantity of smokeless powder that may be stored at any one time in a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, or in a storage unit that is attached to a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 20 kg, if all the smokeless powder is in containers that hold no more than 1 kg; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 5 kg, if any of the smokeless powder is in a container that holds more than 1 kg.

Subsection.Text: The maximum quantity of black powder that may be stored at any one time in a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, or in a storage unit that is attached to a dwelling other than a detached dwelling, is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 1 kg, if the black powder is in containers; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 3 kg less any quantity that is in containers, if the black powder is in *small arms cartridges or black powder cartouches.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The maximum quantity of propellant powder that a user may store at any one time in a *storage unit that is not attached to a dwelling, whether in a single unit or in several, is 75 kg.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When special effects pyrotechnics are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition, in a manner that protects the pyrotechnics from theft and ensures that access to them is limited to people authorized by the user.
When special effect pyrotechnics are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than special effect pyrotechnics may be stored in the storage unit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: propellant powder, firework accessories and other special effect pyrotechnics must be stored separately from one another (for example, on different shelves or separated by a wooden partition);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: Despite sections 393 to 397, a pyrotechnician in charge of a pyrotechnic event may store up to 5 kg of special effect pyrotechnics in a *storage unit at the site of use if they comply with this section.
Of the 5 kg of special effect pyrotechnics that may be stored in the storage unit, no more than 3 kg may be propellant powder.

The storage unit must be made from, or lined with, a non-sparking material, marked with the words “Pyrotechnics/Pièces pyrotechniques” and kept locked, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition in an area that is not accessible to the public. Nothing other than special effects pyrotechnics may be stored in the storage unit.
Special effect pyrotechnics that are not stored in a locked storage unit must be stored in a magazine.
Special effect pyrotechnics must be *attended when they are not in a storage unit or a magazine.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A user who holds a fireworks operator certificate (pyrotechnician) or a fireworks operator certificate (visitor pyrotechnician) may use the following explosives:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: explosives that are classified as type F.3 and whose use by pyrotechnicians or visitor pyrotechnicians has been authorized by the Chief Inspector of Explosives under section 32 or 33 as well as all fireworks accessories;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: smokeless powder;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: explosives classified as type F.3, other than those referred to in paragraph (a), and black powder, but only under the direct supervision of a senior pyrotechnician or special effects pyrotechnician;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: special purpose pyrotechnics, but only under the direct supervision of a special effects pyrotechnician; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: initiation systems and detonating cord, but only under the direct supervision of a special effects pyrotechnician who holds a fireworks operating certificate (special effects pyrotechnician — detonating cord).

Section.Text: A user who holds a fireworks operator certificate (senior pyrotechnician) may use the following explosives:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: explosives classified as type F.3, fireworks accessories, black powder and smokeless powder;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: special purpose pyrotechnics, but only under the direct supervision of a special effects pyrotechnician; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: initiation systems and detonating cords, but only under the direct supervision of a special effects pyrotechnician who holds a fireworks operating certificate (special effects pyrotechnician — detonating cord).

Subsection.Text: A user who holds a fireworks operator certificate (special effects pyrotechnician) may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: assemble at the site of use and use special purpose pyrotechnics, explosives classified as type F.3, fireworks accessories, black powder and smokeless powder; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: use initiation systems and detonating cords, but only under the direct supervision of a special effects pyrotechnician who holds a fireworks operating certificate (special effects pyrotechnician — detonating cord).

Subsection.Text: A user who holds a fireworks operator certificate (special effects pyrotechnician — detonating cord) may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: assemble at the site of use and use special purpose pyrotechnics, explosives classified as type F.3, fireworks accessories, black powder and smokeless powder; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: use initiation systems and detonating cords.

Subsection.Text: Every organizer of a pyrotechnic event must ensure that the event is supervised by a pyrotechnician in charge.
The pyrotechnician in charge must ensure that the event is carried out safely and that the requirements of sections 403 to 408 are complied with.
A pyrotechnic event plan must be prepared in writing and kept for two years after the date of the pyrotechnic event. The plan must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the pyrotechnician in charge and the number and expiry date of their fireworks operator certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the site of the event, including the placement of the special effect pyrotechnics, the proximity of the audience and the location of every exit, every storage area for the pyrotechnics and every smoke detector that may be triggered by the pyrotechnics used in the event;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the type and *product name of each special effect pyrotechnic that will be used and name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of each special effect pyrotechnic;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the anticipated height, duration and fallout effect of the effects of each special effect pyrotechnic;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the anticipated effects of each special purpose pyrotechnic;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the method and sequence of firing the special effect pyrotechnics; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: an assessment of the likelihood of harm to people or property resulting from the use of the special effect pyrotechnics.

Subsection.Text: The plan must be submitted to the *local authority. The written approval of the local authority to hold the pyrotechnic event must be obtained before the event takes place.

Meetings must be held with the people who will participate in presenting the pyrotechnic event (for example, security guards, artists and technicians) to inform them of the special effect pyrotechnics that will be used and the safety precautions to be taken during the event. Subsequent meetings must be held if the event is changed in a way that increases the likelihood of harm to people or property resulting from the use of the pyrotechnics.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A danger zone must be established, taking into account the properties of the special effect pyrotechnics to be used, how they will be positioned, the instructions of the person who obtained their authorization, the weather conditions if the pyrotechnic event is to be held outdoors and the likelihood of harm to people or property resulting from the use of the pyrotechnics.
The danger zone must not contain any flammables or other items that are likely to catch fire.

Only people authorized by the pyrotechnician in charge may enter or be in the danger zone from the time any special effect pyrotechnics are brought into the zone until the pyrotechnician in charge declares the zone to be free of explosives.
Smoking must be prohibited in the danger zone.

Section.Text: During the pyrotechnic event, fire prevention measures that minimize the possibility of harm to people or property must be put in place and facilities, equipment and personnel for fire fighting and administering first aid that minimize the possibility of harm must be present at the site.

Subsection.Text: When setting up and firing the special effect pyrotechnics, the instructions of the person who obtained their authorization must be followed.
Only the pyrotechnician in charge, or a person designated by the pyrotechnician in charge, may have access to the firing unit.
The pyrotechnician in charge, or a person designated by the pyrotechnician in charge, must have control of any physical keying device at all times.
The firing unit must be equipped with a safety interlock that has at least two steps.
Precautions that minimize the likelihood of extraneous electricity igniting an electric match must be taken.
Any device that is used to contain special effect pyrotechnics and is hand-held or attached to a person’s body must be equipped with a firing system that has two switches.

A firing unit must not be connected to a power supply except during a test of circuit continuity or immediately before a special effect pyrotechnic is to be fired. The circuit continuity tester must be current-limited and intrinsically safe so as to eliminate the possibility of an ignition of any pyrotechnic.
Any device that is used to contain special effect pyrotechnics must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: designed and manufactured to prevent fragmentation or distortion of the device;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: designed and manufactured to prevent or contain fragmentation of the pyrotechnics;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: mounted so as to prevent any change in position or direction when used;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: positioned and secured in a manner that minimizes the likelihood of harm to people and property; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: maintained in good condition.

Subsection.Text: Special effect pyrotechnics that are damaged, leaking, damp or contaminated must not be used.
A special effect pyrotechnic must not be fired if a circumstance occurs that could increase the likelihood of harm to people or property.

A pyrotechnic event must be postponed or stopped if unfavourable weather conditions develop, a special effect pyrotechnic malfunctions or any other circumstance occurs that could increase the likelihood of harm to people or property.

The firing unit must be disconnected immediately after the pyrotechnic event, as well as during a pause in the event if keeping the unit connected could increase the likelihood of harm to people or property. When a unit is disconnected, any physical keying device must be removed and kept in the possession of the pyrotechnician in charge or a person designated by the pyrotechnician in charge.
Misfired special effect pyrotechnics must not be approached until at least

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one minute after firing, if the firing was initiated by an electric match; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 30 minutes after firing, if the firing was initiated by other means.

Subsection.Text: Precautions that minimize the likelihood of harm to people and property from misfired special effect pyrotechnics must be taken.
As soon as the circumstances permit after the periods referred to in subsection (2), the site of the pyrotechnic event must be searched and all explosives must be removed from the site.

After the event, only people designated to do a search by the pyrotechnician in charge may enter or be in the danger zone until the pyrotechnician in charge declares the zone to be free of explosives.

Section.Text: A record of the pyrotechnic event must be made in a logbook that sets out the name of the pyrotechnician in charge and the number and expiry date of their fireworks operator certificate. The logbook must be kept for two years after the date of the last recorded event. The record must include the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the pyrotechnic event plan prepared for the event;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the *local authority’s approval to hold the event;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of every person who worked at the event under the supervision of the pyrotechnician in charge; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any unusual circumstance, a statement of the number of misfires and a description of how each misfire was dealt with.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: When a pyrotechnic event is held on behalf of a licence holder, the holder must keep a record of the event for two years after the date of the event. The record must include the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the licence holder’s name and address and the number and expiry date of their licence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the pyrotechnician in charge and the number and expiry date of their fireworks operator certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the *local authority’s approval to hold the event;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the type and *product name of each special effect pyrotechnic used and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity used under each *product name; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the date and site of the event.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: This Part authorizes the acquisition, storage and sale of display fireworks (type F.2) and their accessories and regulates their use. Division 1 sets out rules for sellers and users of display fireworks and fireworks accessories, including how to obtain a fireworks operator certificate. Division 2 sets out additional rules for display fireworks that are firecrackers.
The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: licence means a licence that authorizes the storage of display fireworks and their accessories.
user means a person who acquires display fireworks or their accessories for use, which includes setting them up and firing them.

Section.Text: A reference to a mass of display fireworks or their accessories in this Part is a reference to their gross mass (the mass of the fireworks plus the mass of any packaging or container).
Except as authorized by this Part, it is prohibited for a person to use display fireworks or their accessories.
In this Division, fireworks means display fireworks and fireworks accessories that are used with display fireworks.
A seller may acquire, store and sell fireworks if they hold a licence. A seller who acquires fireworks must comply with this Division.

Subsection.Text: A seller must store their fireworks in the magazine specified in their licence.
A seller must not store electric matches in a magazine in which other fireworks are stored.

Section.Text: A seller must not display fireworks for sale.
A seller may sell fireworks only to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a person who holds a licence; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a user who holds the fireworks operator certificate that is required for use of the fireworks to be bought and who provides the seller with a copy of a *local authority’s approval to hold the fireworks display in which the fireworks will be used.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: A seller must not sell more fireworks to a licensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by their licence to store.
A seller must not sell more fireworks to an unlicensed buyer than the buyer is authorized by the *local authority to store or the quantity set out in section 426, whichever is less.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A seller must keep a record of every sale of fireworks for two years after the date of the sale. The record must include the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the buyer’s name and address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number and expiry date of their licence or fireworks operator certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of a *local authority’s approval to hold the fireworks display in which the fireworks will be used;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the type and *product name of each firework sold and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of fireworks sold under each *product name; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the sale.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The certificates issued by the Minister that are required for the use of fireworks are the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: fireworks operator certificate (display assistant);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor with endorsement); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: fireworks operator certificate (display visitor).

Subsection.Text: To obtain a fireworks operator certificate (display assistant), a person must successfully complete the display fireworks safety and legal awareness course offered by the Explosives Regulatory Division, Department of Natural Resources or a course certified as equivalent by the Minister.

To obtain a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor), a person must have acted as a display assistant in at least three fireworks displays within five years after the date on which the applicant completed the display fireworks safety and legal awareness course or its equivalent.
To obtain a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor with endorsement), a person must hold a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor) and must either

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: successfully complete an advanced safety course, certified by the Minister, on the fireworks or display sites covered by the endorsement; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: demonstrate to the Minister that, working under the direct supervision of a display supervisor in charge, they have obtained the necessary experience to safely carry out the activities covered by the endorsement.

Subsection.Text: To obtain a fireworks operator certificate (display visitor), a person must reside outside Canada and must have the experience necessary to safely carry out the activities of a holder of a fireworks operator certificate (display assistant).

An applicant for a fireworks operator certificate (display assistant) must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, date of birth, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of any organization of fireworks operators to which the applicant belongs;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a photograph of the applicant taken within the previous 12 months; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: proof that the applicant has successfully completed the display fireworks safety and legal awareness course offered by the Explosives Regulatory Division, Department of Natural Resources or a course certified as equivalent by the Minister.

Subsection.Text: An applicant who has not completed the display fireworks safety and legal awareness course or a certified equivalent on the date their application is submitted may, within six months after that date, submit to the Chief Inspector of Explosives proof of their successful completion.

An applicant for a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor) must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, date of birth, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of any organization of fireworks operators to which the applicant belongs;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number and expiry date of the applicant’s fireworks operator certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a photograph of the applicant taken within the previous 12 months;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the applicant’s work journal that sets out

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the date and place of each fireworks display at which the applicant has worked and a description of the fireworks used,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the capacity in which the applicant acted at each fireworks display, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of the display supervisor in charge at each fireworks display; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a letter of recommendation.

Subsection.Text: In an application for a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor with endorsement), in addition to providing the information and documents referred to in subsection (3), the applicant must establish that they have acted as a display supervisor in charge in at least three fireworks displays within the previous five years and,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for a large shell endorsement, establish that they hold a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor) and submit a letter that is signed by the display supervisor in charge of a display at which the applicant was trained in the use of large shells and which attests that the applicant is able to safely use the shells;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for a nautical effects endorsement, establish that they hold a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor) and submit a letter that is signed by the display supervisor in charge of a display at which the applicant was trained in the use of nautical effects and which attests that the applicant is able to safely use the effects;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for a flying saucer endorsement, establish that they hold a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor) and submit a letter that is signed by the display supervisor in charge of a display at which the applicant was trained in the use of flying saucers and which attests that the applicant is able to safely use flying saucers;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for a rooftop site endorsement, establish that they hold a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor) and submit a letter that is signed by the display supervisor in charge of a display at which the applicant was trained to fire fireworks from a rooftop and which attests that the applicant is able to safely fire from a rooftop site;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: for a bridge site endorsement, establish that they hold a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor) and submit a letter that is signed by the display supervisor in charge of a display at which the applicant was trained to fire fireworks from a bridge and which attests that the applicant can safely fire from a bridge site;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: for a flatbed site endorsement, establish that they hold a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor) and submit a letter that is signed by the display supervisor in charge of a display at which the applicant was trained to fire fireworks from a flatbed and which attests that the applicant can safely fire from a flatbed site; or

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: for a floating platform site endorsement, establish that they hold a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor) and submit a letter that is signed by the display supervisor in charge of a display in which the applicant was trained to fire fireworks from a floating platform and which attests that the applicant can safely fire from a floating platform site.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for a fireworks operator certificate (display visitor) must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, date of birth, address, telephone number, fax number and email address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of any organization of fireworks operators to which the applicant belongs;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a photograph of the applicant taken within the previous 12 months;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the applicant’s resumé that sets out the displays in which they have used display fireworks and the people and organizations for which they have worked;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the fireworks displays in which they plan to participate while in Canada and the dates of the events; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the name, telephone number and number of the fireworks operator certificate of the supervisor in charge at each fireworks display in which they plan to participate.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for a fireworks operator certificate or for a modification to, or change of, a certificate must pay the applicable fees set out in Part 19.

Section.Text: A user may acquire fireworks, whether or not they hold a licence, if they hold the fireworks operator certificate required for the use of the fireworks to be acquired. A user who acquires fireworks must comply with this Division.

Subsection.Text: A user who holds a licence must store their fireworks in the magazine specified in their licence.
A user must not store electric matches in a magazine in which other fireworks are stored.

Section.Text: A user who is the display supervisor in charge of a display, whether or not they hold a licence, may store the fireworks to be used in a display –– to a maximum of 500 electric matches and 125 kg of other fireworks — in a *storage unit if they obtain the written approval of the *local authority to do so. The user must ensure that the requirements in section 427 are met.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: When fireworks are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than *explosives classified as type F may be stored in the storage unit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: electric matches must be stored separately from other explosives (for example, on different shelves or separated by a wooden partition);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A user may use fireworks if they hold a fireworks operator certificate (display assistant) or a fireworks operator certificate (display visitor) and use them under the direct supervision of the display supervisor in charge.

Subsection.Text: A user may use fireworks other than aerial shells with a diameter of more than 155 mm, nautical shells and flying saucers if they hold a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor) and fire them from a site other than a rooftop, bridge, flatbed or floating platform.
A user may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: use aerial shells with a diameter of more than 155 mm, nautical shells and flying saucers if they hold a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor) that includes the required endorsement or they are under the direct supervision of a display supervisor in charge whose certificate includes the required endorsement; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fire fireworks from a rooftop site, bridge site, flatbed site or floating platform site if they hold a fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor) that includes the required endorsement or they are under the direct supervision of a display supervisor in charge whose certificate includes the required endorsement.

Section.Text: In this subdivision, firing site means the area within a display site where the fireworks are set up and fired.

Subsection.Text: Every person who organizes a fireworks display must ensure that it is supervised by a display supervisor in charge.
The display supervisor in charge must ensure that the display is carried out safely and that the requirements in sections 432 to 438 are met.
A fireworks display plan must be prepared in writing and kept for two years after the date of the display. The plan must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the display supervisor in charge and the number and expiry date of their fireworks operator certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the location of any *storage units in which the fireworks to be displayed will be stored before or after the display;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the display site, including the distance in metres from the firing site to the nearest spectators, buildings, structures and *vulnerable sites;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the type and *product name of each firework to be used and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of fireworks to be used under each *product name;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of how the fireworks will be positioned within the firing site and how they will be fired;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the crowd-control measures that will be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: an assessment of the likelihood of harm to people and property resulting from the use of the fireworks.

Subsection.Text: The plan must be submitted to the *local authority. The written approval of the local authority to hold the fireworks display must be obtained before the display takes place.

Meetings must be held with all people who will participate in presenting the fireworks display (for example, security guards and technicians) to inform them of the fireworks that will be used and the safety precautions to be taken during the display. Subsequent meetings must be held if the display is changed in a way that increases the likelihood of harm to people or property resulting from the use of the fireworks.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: The fireworks must be *attended when they are not in a *storage unit or a magazine.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: When the fireworks are brought to the firing site, a danger zone must be established whose outer boundary is at least 30 m from the perimeter of the firing site. A smaller danger zone may be established only with the written approval of the *local authority.
The danger zone must not contain any flammables or other items that are likely to catch fire.

Before the continuity of the circuits is tested or, in the case of manually fired fireworks, before the first firework is fired, a fallout zone must be established that encompasses the area in which fireworks debris is likely to fall, taking into account the properties of the fireworks to be used, the angle from which they will be fired and the anticipated weather conditions.

Only people authorized by the display supervisor in charge may enter or be in the danger zone or the fallout zone from the time any fireworks are brought into the zone until the supervisor in charge declares the zone to be free of *explosives.

Only a person who holds a fireworks operator certificate (display assistant), fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor), fireworks operator certificate (display supervisor with endorsement) or fireworks operator certificate (display visitor) may handle fireworks in the danger zone or fallout zone.
Smoking must be prohibited in the danger zone.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: During the fireworks display, fire prevention measures that minimize the possibility of harm to people or property must be put in place and facilities, equipment and personnel for fire fighting and administering first aid that minimize the possibility of harm must be present at the site.

Subsection.Text: Fireworks must be positioned and aimed so that after firing they will not cross over or burst directly above the spectators and any debris from the fireworks will fall within the fallout zone.
When aerial shells are fired,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the mortars and mortar racks that are used to fire the shells must be robust, in sound condition and otherwise safe and effective;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the mortars and mortar racks must be assembled, arranged and secured in a manner that minimizes the likelihood of harm to people and property if there is a premature explosion of a shell;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any support structures must be secured so that they do not fall over when a shell is fired; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: multi-break shells in racks, report shells and shells with a diameter of more than 155 mm must be fired with electric matches.

Subsection.Text: Only the display supervisor in charge, or a person designated by the display supervisor in charge, may have access to a firing unit.
The display supervisor in charge, or a person designated by the display supervisor in charge, must have control of any physical keying device at all times.
All firing units must be equipped with a safety interlock that has at least two steps.
Precautions must be taken that minimize the likelihood of extraneous electricity igniting an electric match.

A firing unit must not be connected to a power supply except during a test of circuit continuity or immediately before fireworks are to be fired. The circuit continuity tester must be current-limited and intrinsically safe so as to eliminate any possibility of an ignition.
Fireworks that are damaged, leaking, damp or contaminated must not be used.
Fireworks must not be fired if a circumstance occurs that could increase the likelihood of harm to people or property.

A fireworks display must be postponed or stopped if unfavourable weather conditions develop, a firework malfunctions or any other circumstance occurs that could increase the likelihood of harm to people or property.

The firing unit must be disconnected immediately after the fireworks display as well as during a pause in the display if keeping the unit connected could increase the likelihood of harm to people or property. When a unit is disconnected, any physical keying device must be removed and kept in the possession of the display supervisor in charge or a person designated by the display supervisor in charge.
The firing site must not be approached until 30 minutes after the display has ended if any fireworks used in the display were fired with an electric match.
Misfired fireworks must not be approached until 30 minutes after the display has ended if the fireworks used in the display were manually fired.
Precautions must be taken that minimize the likelihood of harm to people and property from misfired fireworks.
As soon as the circumstances permit after the periods referred to in subsections (2) and (3), the fallout zone must be searched and all *explosives must be removed.

After the display, only people designated to do a search by the display supervisor in charge may enter or be in the fallout zone until the display supervisor in charge declares the zone to be free of explosives.
The fallout zone must be searched more thoroughly as soon as light and weather conditions permit.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A record of the display must be made in a logbook that sets out the name of the display supervisor in charge and the number and expiry date of their fireworks operator certificate. The logbook must be kept for two years after the date of the last recorded display. The record must include the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the fireworks display plan prepared for the display;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the *local authority’s approval to hold the display;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of every person who worked at the display under the supervision of the display supervisor in charge; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any unusual circumstance, a statement of the number of misfires and a description of how each misfire was dealt with.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: When a fireworks display is held on behalf of a licence holder, the licence holder must keep a record of the display for two years after the date of the display. The record must include the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the licence holder’s name and address and the number and expiry date of the licence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the *local authority’s approval to hold the display;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the display supervisor in charge and the number and expiry date of their fireworks operators certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the *product name and diameter of each firework used and the name of the person who obtained its authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of fireworks used under each *product name; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the date and site of the display.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A seller may sell firecrackers to a buyer who provides the seller with a copy of their firecracker use certificate. However, the quantity of firecrackers sold must not exceed the quantity that the buyer is authorized by their certificate to use.
A seller must keep a record of every sale of firecrackers for two years after the date of the sale. The record must include the following information and documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the buyer’s name and address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the buyer’s firecracker use certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of firecrackers sold; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the sale.

Section.Text: A seller must accept any unused or misfired firecrackers that are returned.

To obtain a firecracker use certificate, a person must demonstrate to the Minister that they are able to safely use firecrackers and that precautions will be taken that minimize the likelihood of harm to people and property resulting from their use.

An applicant for a firecracker use certificate must complete, sign and send to the Chief Inspector of Explosives the application form provided by the Department of Natural Resources. The application must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, date of birth, address and telephone number;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of their past experience using firecrackers;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of firecrackers that the applicant intends to use and the time, date and site of use;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the *local authority’s written approval to use the firecrackers; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the safety precautions that will be taken when using the firecrackers.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: A user may acquire, store and use firecrackers, whether or not they hold a licence, if they hold a firecracker use certificate. A user who acquires firecrackers must comply with this subdivision.

Subsection.Text: A user who holds a licence must store their firecrackers in the magazine specified in the licence.
A user who does not hold a licence must store their firecrackers in a dwelling or a *storage unit and ensure that the requirements of sections 447 and 448 are met.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: No more than five cases of firecrackers — not exceeding 16 000 firecrackers per case — may be stored at any one time.

Subsection.Text: When firecrackers are stored in a dwelling, they must be stored away from flammable substances and sources of ignition, in a manner that protects the firecrackers against theft and ensures that access to them is limited to people authorized by the user.
When firecrackers are stored in a *storage unit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be located in a dry place, away from flammable substances and sources of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be constructed and maintained to prevent unauthorized access and to protect the contents from weather;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is a container, it must not impede exit in case of fire;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the storage unit is not a container, all exits must be kept unobstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shelving in the storage unit must be made from a non-sparking material (for example, wood or painted metal);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nothing other than firecrackers may be stored in the storage unit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be *attended when it is unlocked;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the storage unit must be kept clean, dry, organized and free of grit;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any spill, leakage or other contamination in the storage unit must be cleaned up immediately;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: precautions that minimize the likelihood of fire in or near the storage unit must be taken; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a sign that displays the words “Danger — Fire Hazard/Risque d’incendie” in letters at least 10 cm high and that prohibits smoking using letters, or a symbol, at least 10 cm high must be posted on the storage unit in a clearly visible location.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: Before using firecrackers, a user must obtain written approval from the *local authority.
When using firecrackers, the user must take the following precautions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: non-flammable clothing and protective equipment that minimizes the likelihood of harm to the user must be worn; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least one fire extinguisher with a capacity of at least 3–A :60–B:C must be easily accessible.

Subsection.Text: A user must remove any misfired firecrackers from the site of use as soon as the circumstances permit after the display.
A user must return all misfired and unused firecrackers to the seller as soon as the circumstances permit after the date of use specified in the firecracker certificate.

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Section.Text: This Part sets out the fees payable for obtaining authorizations, permits, licences and certificates.
The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: distribution establishment has the same meaning as in section 144.

MarginalNote.DefinedTermFr: licence de fabrique de la section 1

manufacturing certificate has the same meaning as in section 106.
mobile process unit has the same meaning as in section 56.
process unit has the same meaning as in section 56.
retail establishment has the same meaning as in section 144.
user magazine licence has the same meaning as in section 144.
user magazine zone licence has the same meaning as in section 144.
vendor magazine licence has the same meaning as in section 144.

Section.Text: In this Part, NEQ means net explosive quantity (the mass of the *explosive excluding the mass of any packaging or container).

Footnote.Text: Terms preceded by an asterisk are defined in section 6.

Subsection.Text: The fees to be paid for obtaining the authorizations, licences, permits and certificates set out in column 1 of the table to this section are set out in column 2.

The fees are payable at the time the application is submitted. However, the fees referred to in items 1 and 3 of the table are payable within 30 days after the date of the invoice from the Department of Natural Resources.
